PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY COMMISSION OF INQUIRY (REPEAL) BILL 1986[COGNATE PAPERS:PARLIAMENTARY COMMISSION OF INQUIRY]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Madam Speaker, this Bill is to repeal the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Act 1986 and thereby to terminate the inquiry which the Commission was established to carry out. The Commission was set up to inquire and advise the Parliament whether any conduct of Mr Justice Lionel Murphy had been such as to amount, in its opinion, to proved misbehaviour within the meaning of section 72 of the Constitution. The Act requires the report to be made on or before 30 September 1986 unless that date is extended by resolution of each House of the Parliament.

Honourable members will be aware of the distressing news of Mr Justice Murphy's illness. In a statement issued on 1 August 1986, he said that his medical advice is that he has an advanced state of cancer in its secondary stages, and that there is no cure and no treatment. The advice is that in the absence of a remission he will not live very long. This advice was confirmed in a Special Report of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry to the Presiding Officers dated 5 August 1986, which was circulated to the leaders of the various parties in the Parliament and tabled yesterday. I inform the House that I was advised by Mr Justice Murphy on 5 August that his health was such that he was unable to travel; that he was going on sick leave and that he was proposing to devote himself to writing up judgments upon which he has yet to make delivery.

It was with profound sadness that we all learnt of Mr Justice Murphy's illness. I know that all honourable members will have the same feeling. As already stated on behalf of the Government, Lionel Murphy and his family have already had to bear more stress in the last two and a half years than most people experience in a lifetime. They will have the sympathy of every compassionate and fair-minded Australian as they face this severest ordeal of all.

We all acknowledge the precious value of life. We are very much aware of the sadness that illness can cause and we are very mindful of the great support that one gets from one's family in these times. We all wish the judge well in the future and we hope and pray that there will be a remission of his illness that may allow him to restore his health and be able to continue the great work that he has been able to do for this country.

However, the matter this Parliament must now address is the inquiry. The Special Report of the Commission tabled yesterday states that the illness of the judge, in combination with the fact that its inquiry will take at least four more months, raises the question whether the statutory task set for the Commission can be discharged at all. The Commission has made plain its own views, which are that to continue hearings if the judge were too ill to take part in them would be contrary to established practice and to natural justice. Accordingly, the Commission's inquiry should be terminated forthwith, and that is what the Bill before the House now does.

The Bill also includes special consequential provisions. These are made necessary by the fact that the Commission has not made, and will not be able to make, any findings in relation to matters before it. In particular it is necessary to protect from access and publication any allegations against Mr Justice Murphy. For these purposes, clause 7 has the effect of transferring the documents in the possession of the Commission immediately before the commencement of the repealing Act to the care of the Presiding Officers. Clause 8 makes it an offence to publish allegations derived from materials before the Commission.

I turn to clauses 7 and 8. Sub-clauses (1) and (2) of clause 7 make provision for the transfer into the care of the President of the Senate and yourself, Madam Speaker, as Speaker of the House of Representatives of the documents in the physical possession of the Commission immediately before the commencement of the repealing Act.

As regards documents which contain any material relating to the conduct of Mr Justice Murphy, provision is made in clause 7 (3) to exclude access under any other Federal, State or Territory law, including the Freedom of Information Act 1982, the Archives Act 1983 and any law which provides for the production of documents. Evidence concerning these documents by the persons referred to in clause 7 (3) is also excluded.

As regards documents which do not contain material relating to the conduct of Mr Justice Murphy, access may be obtained but only under the exclusive code provided in clause 7 (4). Specific reference is made to any material relating to the meaning of section 72 of the Constitution. Such material could be of general public interest, and it would be able to be released if it does not contain material relating to the conduct of Mr Justice Murphy. Access will be a matter to be decided by the Presiding Officers. As indicated, clause 7 (4) is an exclusive code; in particular, access under the Freedom of Information Act or the Archives Act will be excluded, as will any law which provides for the production of documents.

At the winding up of the Commission there will be some documents with agencies covered by the Freedom of Information Act. Clause 7 (5) has the effect that the agencies are exempt from the operation of the Freedom of Information Act in relation to documents which have been created for the purposes of the Commission.

Clause 8 is an overriding provision that makes it a criminal offence to disclose any allegations derived from materials before the Commission relating to Mr Justice Murphy or any information relating to consideration in the Commission of any particular allegation. Now that the inquiry is being wound up, it would be oppressive and unconscionable to allow the circulation of allegations derived from materials before the Commission but on which no report by the Commission will ever be available. The provision is limited to allegations derived-and I emphasise the word `derived'-from materials before the Commission, and any information relating to the Commission's own consideration of any particular allegation. The Provision says nothing about materials that exist independently of the Commission.

Finally, I want to emphasise to the House in the plainest way that the commissioners themselves see enormous difficulties in their ever being able to complete their inquiry into any of the allegations in any satisfactory way. My own conclusion, based on what they have said, is that to continue the inquiry would be a futile and oppressive exercise.

I express my thanks and appreciation to each commissioner for undertaking the inquiry that Parliament set up. Each is a distinguished retired senior judge. The presiding member of the Commission is Sir George Lush, a former judge of the Supreme Court of Victoria. Sir George retired from the Supreme Court in October 1983 after 17 years on the Bench. He was Chairman of the Victorian Bar Council and President of the Australian Bar Association from 1964 to 1966. Sir Richard Blackburn, a former Chief Justice of the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court, was appointed as the Australian Capital Territory's Chief Judge in 1977. Sir Richard was also a member of the Federal Court of Australia, and a judge of the Northern Territory Supreme Court from 1966 to 1971. The Hon. Andrew Wells, QC, is a former judge of the Supreme Court of South Australia. Mr Wells retired in 1984 after 14 years on the Bench. The two former State judges were chosen after consultation by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) with the Premiers of Victoria and South Australia. Sir Richard Blackburn accepted my invitation to serve on the Commission. The appointments were finally made after consultation with the Opposition and the Australian Democrats.
I commend the Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill. I seek leave for the debate to continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?
—No, it is not. We saw the draft of this Bill last night around 6 o'clock and the actual Bill itself for the first time a few minutes ago.
—Leave is not granted.

That, pursuant to contingent notice, so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the second reading being made an order of the day for a later hour.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before the debate is continued, I suggest that it may suit the convenience of the House to have a general debate covering the Bill and the motion to take note of papers presented yesterday in relation to the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry. If there is not objection, I shall allow this course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The presentation of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry (Repeal) Bill 1986 to Parliament has been marked by haste and incompetence. We first got a copy of the draft of the Bill last night around about 6 o'clock; and we first saw the Bill to be presented to the House today as the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) presented his second reading speech.

SPEECH.PARA: Our position has been made plain and I make it again to this House. Despite the very deep natural sympathy we must all feel and, I believe, we all do feel, for Mr Justice Murphy and his family in this time of great pain and great personal darkness, there has been no change in the constitutional considerations which led to the establishment of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry. There cannot be one set of constitutional rules for a healthy judge and another set for a sick judge. There is no alternative to the inquiry continuing so long as Mr Justice Murphy remains publicly determined to sit on the High Court of Australia. I remind honourable members that all we have had from Mr Justice Murphy is a statement of that public determination. Today the Attorney-General said-and I agree with him entirely-that we hope that Mr Justice Murphy has a remission. He went on to say that he hoped that he would be able to continue with his great work. That, of course, referred directly, and could only refer, to his returning to the High Court. That is our first objection-that is, that the constitutional considerations which led to the establishment of this Commission have not changed.

Our second objection relates to the Bill itself. This is not a Bill simply to abolish the Commission of Inquiry. It is a Bill which sets up what the Attorney-General has called `an exclusive code', which is designed to bury in perpetuity any material before the Commission of Inquiry in any way relating to the conduct of Mr Justice Murphy and which has the effect of denying access to that material in perpetuity, even if it is directly relevant to the proof of a criminal offence against some third person.

The Government's determination to end the inquiry must be judged in the context of that inquiry and the reasons that led to its establishment. Let me remind the House of those reasons and that context. The inquiry was established on 8 May 1986. It was set up after months of delay by this Government and an unprincipled abdication of its constitutional responsibility to protect the standing and integrity of the High Court. It was established to assist the Parliament in determining Mr Justice Murphy's fitness to remain on the Bench of the High Court of Australia and not, as some mistakenly believe, to determine any questions of criminal guilt or innocence on any issues on which he had been previously tried. It was commonly understood-and I challenge any member of the Government to deny this-that Mr Justice Murphy would refrain from sitting on the Court while the inquiry was being held. No one whom I recall on the Government front bench suggested that he should do other than refrain from sitting on the Court while the inquiry was being held. No one mentioned Mr Justice Murphy's constitutional right to sit on the Court and that he should exercise that constitutional right while the Commission was on foot. How could that be suggested in terms, very simply, of judicial propriety? It was self-evident that to sit while his very fitness to sit was under examination by this Parliament and by the Commission established by the Parliament for that purpose must inevitably be damaging to the integrity and standing of the High Court, since one outcome of the Commission could be a resolution by both Houses under section 72 of the Constitution.

What would be, in that circumstance, the views of litigants who had been before the Court? What would be the views of litigants who had been before the Court and whose position had been judged by a judge who was himself then under judgment? How could it conceivably be argued that it was proper or desirable in those circumstances for the justice to sit? It cannot, and nobody at the time sought to advance that argument. The only reason it has been advanced now is out of sympathy. We all feel sympathy for Mr Justice Murphy. Many of us have known him outside of this House and have no feelings of political animosity towards him. I and many others, and I believe and hope everybody on my side of the House, would exclude any such question. There are no politics involved in this matter; there is no political credit to be gained, save credit that might be and should be gained for upholding constitutional principle-an odium that should be wreaked by those in the Government who would abdicate once again constitutional principle.

The Commission of three retired judges was to report to this Parliament its findings of fact and its conclusions as to whether the conduct of Mr Justice Murphy had been such as to amount, in its opinion, to `proved misbehaviour' for the purposes of section 72 of the Constitution. The report and accompanying evidence were to be presented by 30 September, unless that date was extended by resolution of the two Houses. The report was intended, under the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Act setting up the Commission of Inquiry, to form the basis for Parliament's decision. Regardless of whatever opinions the Commission might form, the ultimate judgment under the Constitution was for this Parliament itself.

I remind the House of the circumstances of Mr Justice Murphy's return to the High Court bench. There was news of his grievous ill health, evoking feelings of sympathy across the country from every decent Australian. Then there was his unilateral decision to return. There was the disapproval of that decision voiced by the Chief Justice. I must say that it was contemptible of the Attorney-General on behalf of the Government yesterday to suggest that there was dissent from other justices. I remind the House that not a single justice has expressed such dissent. The Chief Justice, who will retire in a few months time, was in the position where he had to express a view since otherwise silence on his part would have been judged by many to be assent to Mr Justice Murphy's return. He said-and has anybody here quarrelled with this proposition:

It is essential that the integrity and reputation of any Justice of this Court be seen to be beyond question. That being so, I regard it as most undesirable that Mr Justice Murphy should sit while matters into which the Commission is inquiring remain unresolved, and before the Commission has made its report.

Does anyone suggest that that is wrong? Does anyone suggest that, Mr Justice Murphy's health having been put to one side, he should return to the Court while those matters remain unresolved? Such an argument cannot in all conscience be put to this House or to the Australian people. To their very great discredit the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Senator Gareth Evans, as Acting Attorney-General, have taken a different view. They spoke of Mr Justice Murphy's constitutional right to sit on the High Court of Australia, the constitutional right of a judge under investigation by this Parliament. What of their constitutional duties? When the Bill to establish the Commission was before this House, the Attorney-General spoke of the need `of protecting the standing and integrity of the High Court and the preservation of public confidence in it'. He then said that the reasons that led the Government to decide that this Commission should be established without delay were those very considerations. Forced into accepting responsibility, he stated what he said were the Government's views. Now that has disappeared; those views have vanished. Yet in constitutional terms nothing has changed. That is not simply the view expressed on this side of the House; it is a view which is unequivocally confirmed by the special report of the Commission of Inquiry which was tabled yesterday in this House. I quote from that report, which states:

The situation which existed at the date when the Act became law, 13 May 1986, was such that Parliament regarded the task allotted to the Commission as one of national importance. That situation remains unchanged.

So it does. The only thing that has changed is the knowledge we all have of the justice's grievous ill health, but that has nothing to do with whether it is right or was right or desirable for Mr Justice Murphy to resume his position on the High Court. It is characteristic of this Government that it should jettison constitutional principles and seek to justify its actions on the ground of the justice's ill health and to contrive by that means that sympathy should blur and bury the constitutional issues.

I fear that Mr Justice Murphy's own views cannot pass examination, nor can they pass challenge, since he stated his own view of the Commission. He asserted the right to sit for so long as he believes he should, and that is all we have from him in public terms. I quote from his own recent statement where he said:

Between 15 and 30 July I received from those assisting the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry a number of purported allegations. In my view they are either untrue or do not constitute misbehaviour. I have already been cleared of many of them by the unanimous decision of the first Senate Committee.

Who in the House embraces that position? Apparently the Prime Minister, the Attorney-General and the Government itself. Mr Justice Murphy's answer was to arrogate to himself the task of judgment and, it must be said, to treat with plain and deep contempt the Commission and Parliament itself. His answer is in flat opposition to the character Parliament gave to the Commission to determine the relevance of allegations and to determine their truth, and it is directly contradicted by the special report which makes plain that the task of the Commission was no easy or trivial one but one of weight, gravity and complexity. Before quoting from that report I ask the House: How could it possibly be accepted that the justice himself was to be allowed to make the judgment as to whether or not an allegation should be answered? How could it possibly be suggested that it was open to him to make the judgment as to whether an allegation was true? These were matters reposed by the Houses in the Commission, and on which the Commission was bound by its charter to report to the Houses. The Houses were then to make their own judgment on the report.
I quote from the report which was tabled yesterday in this House. I start with paragraph 5, which reads:

The situation which existed at the date when the Act became law, 13 May 1986, was such that Parliament regarded the task allotted to the Commission as one of national importance. That situation remains unchanged. The Commission, through counsel assisting it, has considered a great quantity of materials which, in combination with further inquiries, has led to the drafting of `specific allegations made in precise terms'. Those completed have been delivered to the Judge. Some are still in preparation. Evidence on the first allegation to be considered was to begin today. In the result no evidence has been heard and therefore nothing decided.

6. Counsel assisting the Commission estimate that the hearing of evidence on all present allegations, including cross-examination, up to the stage at which the Judge might be called upon to give evidence would last at least four months and possibly longer. The Act fixes 30 September 1986 as the date for the making of the Commission's report, but under section 9 (2) that time may be extended.

It is perfectly plain, therefore, that the material before the Commission was of great bulk, weight and complexity; otherwise the time required by it for examination of the material would be very much less than four months. The report continues:

7. If Parliament were to leave the Act in operation, with the requirement that the Commission make its report by 30 September, the Commission might be unable to complete the hearing of evidence relating to even one allegation, and certainly would not be able to deal with most of the allegations. If no case to answer were disclosed in the allegations so heard, and they were in effect dismissed, the other allegations would remain in the air, and the situation which the Act was intended to correct would remain unchanged. If a case to answer were disclosed, the Judge could be required to give evidence and could be cross-examined. If the final decision were adverse to the Judge, the fact that most of the allegations remained unheard would lead to the result that the Houses would have incomplete materials for their further deliberations.
The Commission does not favour the course of selecting a few allegations for immediate hearing on the sole or principal ground that they could be rapidly disposed of.
8. If the Commission is to carry through its task to completion, it will be necessary for the Houses to extend time to a date not earlier than 31 March 1987.

It is for the Government to make plain what Mr Justice Murphy's intentions are. It has the responsibility to do that because it has responsibility for the administration of justice. The High Court stands at the pinnacle of our system of administration of justice. So long as Mr Justice Murphy remains publicly determined to sit as a justice of the High Court, I regret to say, the Commission of Inquiry must continue. His health entitles him to deep sympathy, but it does not give him special rights. The High Court as an institution is far more important than the personal interests of any one member of it.

In summary, therefore, there have been no changes to the constitutional considerations that led to the establishment of the Parliamentary Commission. It is undesirable for Mr Justice Murphy to sit while the issues before the Commission remain unresolved. His health is irrelevant to both those matters, although the unwisdom of a man sitting, in his health, on reserved judgments is all too obvious. If his health became such that he were unable to take part in the inquiry, it would be contrary to natural justice for it to continue. I repeat my expressed hope that he will reconsider his decision, make his intentions clear and public and make it plain that he does not propose to sit further on the High Court and will resign.

Before passing to the Bill itself, I must say something about the Attorney-General's second reading speech. The Attorney-General said that the medical advice was confirmed in a Special Report of the Parliamentary Commission. I have not seen the medical advice which was before the Commission, but the Commission does not confirm anything save that, and I quote from paragraph 2:
At the sitting this morning, counsel for the Judge tendered a statutory declaration to which was exhibited a copy of the medical certificate which you have already seen.
`You' being the Presiding Officers. The quote continued:
On this material, supported by statements from the bar table that the Judge was unable to travel, counsel applied for an adjournment of hearings until parliament next sits.

I wish, therefore, to emphasise the point that the Commission is making no final judgment and, indeed, so far as I could see, could make no final judgment, about Mr Justice Murphy's continued health or about the course of this dreadful affliction from which he suffers.

Turning now to the Bill itself, the Bill is not simply a repeal of the Commission; it is a burial of the Commission and of all of the evidence before it. This is effected by clause 7 and by what the Attorney-General has quaintly referred to as `an exclusive code'. Under clause 7 the Presiding Officers jointly have the exclusive right to possession of any document that was in the possession of the Commission immediately before the commencement of the clause as a law. Further, under clause 7, notwithstanding any other law, no person other than a Presiding Officer-let me repeat the words `other than a Presiding Officer'- is entitled to access to a class A document. A class A document is defined as meaning a document that contains material relating to the conduct of the Hon. Lionel Keith Murphy. It does not say: `adversely reflecting on the conduct of Lionel Keith Murphy'. It says `relating', and that means, of course, relating in any way, for good or for bad, even if the way in which it relates is purely in passing and even though it contains material which is directly relevant to the proof of criminal activities by some third person. So long, therefore, as a document falls within the description of a class A document, it is to remain in the possession of the Presiding Officers.

The effect of the Bill is not limited to documents brought into existence for the purposes of the inquiry, and here lies one of the cardinal problems. Under the Act which set up the Commission, the Commission was to have access, by section 13, to documents and materials held by the National Crime Authority relating to the Stewart inquiries. Therefore, so long as any of the Stewart documents contain references to the conduct of Mr Justice Murphy, and regardless of what that reference is or what else appears in those documents, access is barred forever, for all time, to such material as may be in the possession of the Commission at the time this Bill becomes law. That prohibition is deliberately based on the full sanction of parliamentary privilege. Even Parliament itself, even the Houses or the committees of the Houses, are to be denied access to those documents. Could anything be more extraordinary?

Class B documents-that is, any other documents in the Commission's possession at the time this Bill becomes a law-are also to be excluded from any external inquiry or access and, once again, forever, save with the written authority of the Presiding Officers. I would read that as meaning the written authority of both Presiding Officers; so if one disagrees, access to those documents can never be had. Once again, this Parliament and its committees are to be denied access to those documents. Quite extraordinary powers are here vested in the Presiding Officers. It is they who are to determine questions of access, not the Houses themselves, unless this law is changed. What are we dealing with? What are the reasons for this?

The result is not simply to bury forever documents relating to the conduct of Mr Justice Murphy, even where those documents may contain material directly relevant to the proof of a criminal offence committed by some third person, but to deny this Parliament and the Australian people forever access to class A material and to deny this Parliament and the people forever access to class B material, save on the terms provided for by the Presiding Officers, if they so provide.

Surely this is the most extraordinary attempt we have ever seen to seek to preserve in perpetuity documents from public scrutiny, regardless of the public interest in having those documents scrutinised and regardless of the public interest in having those documents, or some of them, turned over to the law enforcement authorities. I wish to make it perfectly plain that I am not suggesting in any way that we are here concerned with criminal offences committed by Mr Justice Murphy. I am talking about criminal offences which may be disclosed and material which may be relevant to criminal offences committed by third persons. These provisions will remain for the next 500 or 1,000 years if the Bill becomes a law of this country.

The Petrov documents themselves have been released. We all know that under the release provisions of the Archives Act, Cabinet documents are released after a certain period. Documents dealing with the most sensitive matters of national importance are released. Documents containing allegations of the most serious kind relating to high officials have been released. The Petrov documents were one such case, where the Prime Minister spoke of the public need to have these documents released. They were released, I recall very clearly, containing as they did the wildest, most bizarre and unsubstantiated allegations against some great Australians.

There are other public policy objections to the Bill. I shall now deal with one further major objection to it. Under section 34 of the Act, the Commission may communicate information that it receives relevant to the commission of an offence against a law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory to the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth or of a State or of the Northern Territory, or to the National Crime Authority or to the police. With the repeal of the Act, once this Bill comes into force, the Commission's power to communicate such information will cease and all the material in its possession will then become subject to the defences of the legal fortress that the Government has erected by this Bill.

There are further objections to be found in the terms of clauses 5 and 8 of the Bill and the very wide exclusions contained in those clauses on the use of information. Time does not permit an examination. I point to it so that it will be remarked on at a later time and in a different place.

I conclude: In government, we believe that fairness should be accorded to Mr Justice Murphy and we shall accord that fairness to him and to his reputation. I do not speak of a revival of the Commission. I am talking here about the Bill and the effect that it has on the preservation of documents within the legal fortress. But we believe that the law enforcement authorities should have access to relevant material and that not to give them access would be a denial of public duty at which this Government, whose flexible morality is notorious, is willing to connive. While we believe that the interests of fairness must be closely considered, all the material must, in due course, be open to public examination. To adopt any other course would be to give to this material a status and secrecy quite unknown to our democratic processes and quite opposed to basic public principles. For those reasons, we oppose the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable gentleman's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support fully the words of the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), on the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry (Repeal) Bill. I am as concerned as he is about many aspects of the repeal of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Act. The shadow Attorney-General has very clearly identified one of the critical problems relating to the legislation with which we are dealing, and that is the body of material that will remain after the inquiry has concluded. When one considers that only a short time ago the parliamentary commissioners were seeking an extra six months to investigate fully a number of the allegations made in relation to Mr Justice Murphy, one must have cause to be very much concerned about where the material will go and when the people of this country and members of this Parliament will have proper access to it.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it, there were very good reasons for the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry seeking an extra six months for the examination of the allegations made against Mr Justice Murphy. I understand that it had reached the point where it was considering in particular 12 counts on which a prima facie case could be made out to indict Mr Justice Murphy for criminal offences. The mere fact that so many prima facie counts could be subject to consideration and require further investigation must make one gravely concerned about what will happen to this material.

I suggest that the reason the inquiry has been closed down relates not so much to the purported state of health of Mr Justice Murphy but more to the enormity of the material that has been put together by the Commission and the ramifications that flow from that material for this Government and for the national security of Australia.

If I can deal specifically with some of the criminal matters that were subject to investigation, I gather that several of those prima facie counts that were being looked at were built very much around the alleged criminal association of Mr Justice Murphy with well-known Sydney crime figure Abe Saffron. As the inquiry moved on its course of investigation, Mr Justice Murphy, on learning of these developments, made a statement that the purported allegations were baseless. As we have heard from the shadow Attorney-General, Mr Justice Murphy indicated clearly that he intended to sit again in the High Court of Australia. In doing that, he has effectively judged himself, without proper examination of the material, and has not allowed the Commission to conclude its deliberations in a proper way.

As I understand it, a number of matters that were laid before the Commission go beyond matters of criminal association and go to other areas of great concern. In that regard I wish to take honourable members back to a document that I discussed in this House in the earlier session of this year. I refer to the evidence given before a committee of the New South Wales Legislative Assembly, the Select Committee of the Legislative Assembly upon Prostitution, on Tuesday, 15 November 1983, by one James McCartney Anderson, a former business associate of Abe Saffron. I do not intend to transgress all that material in its entirety again but I wish to draw the attention of the House to one particular element of that transcript of evidence, in particular page 104 of the in camera evidence, because it goes to the very matter that I am talking about-not the primary matter of the alleged criminal associations of Mr Justice Murphy but his alleged associations in other areas and the implications that may have for our national security. I can deal with this document with full liberty because, at the invitation of the Attorney-General, I did subsequently draw that document to the attention of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry. I forwarded my Hansard speech and I understand that subsequently the full in camera evidence was obtained and studied by the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry.
I especially draw the attention of honourable members to page 104 of Mr Anderson's in camera evidence before that Select Committee upon Prostitution on 15 November 1983 where he said:

The greatest security risk that Australia faces is the corruption that exists in New South Wales and other States, only this one more than others. You could start a spy ring here without any problems at all.
This was followed by a question from the Committee:
By using Mata Hari type spies, you mean?
The answer was:

Using ladies to compromise politicians, members of the armed forces; it is nothing new. But for some reason or other Australian politics find it very difficult to comprehend that it could happen here. This is why the drug scene got out of control because nobody thought it could happen in Australia.

In relation to that material, which I understand was studied very closely by the Parliamentary Commission in association with other accompanying material laying down a similar line of investigation for the Commission to follow, I draw the attention of honourable members to an article that appeared in the Melbourne Age on Tuesday, 19 August. We are talking about a fairly recently published article. In that article there is a lengthy discussion about the political pressure that has been exerted by people, including politicians, over a long period in relation to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's Four Corners program and the attempts made to repress the material in that program. I will not read the article in its entirety because not all of it is relevant to the subject at hand. But I would like particularly to draw attention to one critical section of that article about the suppression over the years of various ABC Four Corners programs. The article was written by Jane Sullivan, Green Guide editor of the Age, and was in the Age of Tuesday, 19 August. It states:

In 1977, Mr Justice Murphy promised the then producer of `Four Corners', Mr Brian Davies, that he would sue the ABC ``to its back teeth'' if it put to air an interview with the retiring head of the CIA, Mr James Angleton, saying that Mr Murphy's raid on the ASIO headquarters in 1973 when he was Attorney-General had ``worried and angered Washington''. The interview was never shown on television but was later broadcast on the ABC radio program `Correspondents Report'. Mr Murphy did not sue.
Referring back to Mr Anderson's comments and considering them in relation to the Murphy raid on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation in 1973, one wonders what the motivation then was.

TALK.START.PARA: -I just draw the honorable member's attention to the fact that he does seem to be straying a little bit off the subject, which is the repeal of an Act. He might just bear relevance in mind.

—I will bear that very much in mind, Mr Deputy Speaker. But I understand that these are among the matters that were the subject of investigation by the Commission, and I find it of great interest that the Government attempts to close down a commission which was attempting to pursue these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I just leave the House with the following questions: What was the real purpose behind the Murphy raid on ASIO in 1973? What particular documents were taken away by the then Attorney-General? What events happened elsewhere in the world subsequent to that? Who was the ASIO officer who helped the Attorney-General to acquire those documents at the time? What later happened to that ASIO officer in terms of his promotion in ASIO? In relation to what I said about Mr Anderson's testimony before the Select Committee upon Prostitution, what other possible ramifications might that have? That is why I say that we are really looking at a subject that has enormous implications. One realistically has to say that in fact what the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry was looking into goes far beyond the matter of criminal associations.

Just briefly, on that same matter, I draw the attention of honourable members to statements in recent times by the former senior MI5 officer, Peter Wright, who has been attempting to get material published here in Australia. He has indicated quite clearly in discussions that he believes the former Director-General of MI5 in the United Kingdom, Sir Roger Hollis, had acted for the Soviets for a long period and that that had an overflow to the situation here in Australia. One then brings that back to the Murphy raid on ASIO in 1973 and the statements of Mr Anderson.

There are many unanswered questions if this material is to be buried. What does it all really mean? Who really was Mr Justice Lionel Murphy and was he doing something other than just acting in an improper manner in a criminal sense? I lay those questions before the House because we have not had a clear answer to them. If the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry had been allowed to pursue its full and proper course, it might have been very interesting to see whether these matters could have been studied further. I do not think we have heard here today the end of any of these matters. The Government has attempted to close off debate on this subject by closing down the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry. But a lot of the material that the inquiry has been looking at is held in other places and I think we will see developments in various areas that will go beyond the inquiry. The attempt by the Government to close it down will prove to be abortive in the longer term in terms of suppressing proof.

I draw the attention of honourable members to one other related matter in relation to the Anderson material which, as I have said, was studied in great detail by the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry and also in relation to other material that it then uncovered that flowed from this. If I may just be indulged I will read the lead-in question to Mr Anderson's testimony in order to give it a sense of perspective. This is the beginning of Mr Anderson's testimony and it refers to a separate but related matter relating to the national well-being of this country. I understand that this too was the subject of consideration by the inquiry. The questioning went as follows:

CHAIRMAN: Mr Anderson, I would ask you now to further pursue the point at which I cut you off. I feel it is necessary even though it may not be terribly relevant to our terms of reference. Having started on a line I think it has to be pursued. You started talking about Cabinet Ministers, judges and the like, and their involvement. Could you elaborate on that?

Mr DOWD: Perhaps, Mr Chairman, you might indicate that Mr Anderson should indicate (a) what he knows and (b) those things which he personally observed and where he was present at conversations, as best he can?-A. As you will appreciate, I did not realise I was coming here until I spoke to Mr Dowd at 8 o'clock last night.

Q. Mr Chairman, I had spoken to Mr Anderson a fortnight ago before he was going overseas with this date in mind and told him about this date. Of course, then, he went overseas and I could not contact him until he got back yesterday?-A. The prostitution side of it, and judges, you may find this a bit embarrassing, but I can certainly substantiate it. I would have to speak to a member of the media who has, I believe, fully documented this particular incident where the four most powerful men in this country, the Prime Minister, the federal Attorney-General, Treasurer and Minister of Energy I think he was, Mines or something, Mr Connor. He is dead now; the other three are very much alive. There was a problem of $4 billion worth of loan money and certain legal action was taken by Mr Sankey. There are overtures made. I was in Mr Saffron's office when he phoned-you have to correct the terminology; I do not know if he was the Chief Justice of Australia, or one of them-Mr Lionel Murphy.
Mr BOWMAN—He is one of the judges?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Duncan

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to Standing Order 75, which states:

INTERJECT.PARA: No Member may use offensive words against either House of the Parliament or any Member thereof, against any Member of the Judiciary . . .
It seems to me that this is going fairly close to transgressing that standing order.

TALK.START.PARA: -I have asked the honourable member for Bruce to remain relevant to the Bill. The honourable member seems to be saying that this is all relevant to the fact that there is a secrecy provision in the Bill and he is canvassing what he believes may have been said to the Commission of Inquiry. I do not think that that really is relevant to the Bill that is before us. I think the point that is being made by the honourable member for Makin is quite true, that Mr Justice Murphy is a justice of the High Court. The honourable member for Bruce should restrict his remarks to the Bill before the House.

—I will conclude the section I was reading because it puts the matter into perspective. In talking about this Bill it is very difficult not to mention the justice. This was one of the matters that were being investigated by the Commission. Perhaps I can just have your indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker, to complete this sentence. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr BOWMAN: He is one of the judges? ---A. I am not sure if he was the federal Attorney-General then or if he had been shunted -
we are talking about him in his capacity as Attorney-General-

Mr DOWD: He was at that stage federal Attorney-General? ---A. I was present when Mr Saffron approached me and said he had been approached by a Mr Morgan Ryan and Mr Lionel Murphy to try and bring certain criminal actions that were pending and had been causing a great deal of trouble to the federal Government to a speedy conclusion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I do not think that the honourable member can make imputations and continue to make those sorts of imputations.

—I have read in all I intend to read into the record. What I am saying-I come back to my very opening comments-is that this legislation today is not about the health of Mr Justice Murphy. This Bill is about closing down an inquiry that has become enormously damaging to this Government because of the enormity of the material it has uncovered in not only the area of criminal associations but also the area of national security. That is the very reason this Government wishes to bury this inquiry so that things will not proceed further in relation to investigating these matters including, as the shadow Attorney-General has correctly stated in his comments prior to mine, the investigation of matters that may relate to offences committed by other third persons. Whether one is talking about the loans affair, national security or the alleged criminal associations of Mr Justice Murphy, what his real role was and who he really is, I think it is a great tragedy that this Bill is being put through today with such great speed. Notwithstanding this attempt to forestall and close off debate on these important matters here today by closing down the inquiry, the Government will not prevent at some stage the truth on these matters and the truth about Mr Justice Murphy's real role in this country eventually coming out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not detain the House terribly long on this matter, but I would like to make some comments. I must say at the outset that this has been a very sorry matter in terms of handling what has been a unique constitutional situation in regard to the High Court of Australia. It does need to be put into perspective because the High Court is one of the two fundamental institutions which guarantee and protect the rights of individuals, the rights of all Australians. That is its importance; it carries with it the importance which we have as members of this Parliament to ensure the integrity of the High Court.

SPEECH.PARA: We had an unfortunate situation when the Government, with a range of mixed motives-it did not quite know how to deal with the situation-back in May 1986 effectively flick-passed the constitutional problem to the High Court. In the House of Representatives on 6 May at page 3130 the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) said:
I think any government and any parliament would welcome the High Court being in a position to express a view about matters.
At page 3135 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said:
Clearly, they are not going to be issuing a judgment of the High Court but they will be, obviously, coming to some conclusion.

What that did was place the High Court in a most unenviable position. But on that very day, according to documents received under the Freedom of Information Act recently by me, the Attorney-General's Department forwarded to the Chief Justice copies or extracts from Volume 2 of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Alleged Telephone Interceptions, the Stewart report, and also copies of Volume 1. It was only after some considerable debate in this place that the Government realised the error of its ways and moved to the establishment of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry. In introducing the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Bill, the Attorney-General said in the second reading speech:
It is necessary for the standing of the Judge and of the High Court that all allegations be dealt with one way or the other.

I remind honourable members that we on this side of the House in fact supported that move. In a unique constitutional situation it seemed to us to be sensible to move to the establishment of an inquiry so that an objective statement of facts could be collated and then presented to the Parliament so that the Parliament was then in a better position to exercise its constitutional responsibilities under section 72 of the Constitution.

We had a number of objections about the Bill establishing the inquiry. Some of those objections were brought about by the fact that the Government was forced, through indecent haste, to prepare the legislation and there were a number of errors and queries about it. It was also embodied in that legislation that the inquiry would effectively operate in secret. I think it was in the public arena for two or three minutes when the Commission of Inquiry was first established that the counsel assisting advised us that all further hearings would be in camera. It was a sensible course of action for the sake of the integrity of the High Court from the layman's point of view. All he knew was where there is smoke there is fire, that the Federal Parliament had a supervisory responsibility in respect of the administration of justice in this country and it was therefore appropriate that a commission be established. It had the benefit, as often these sorts of commissions have, of taking the matter out of an immediate political context.

The rationale for the establishment of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry rests on a number of issues, facts or matters. The first is that a member of the High Court had had allegations made against him in the public arena. The making of those allegations and the fact of those allegations being made public raise in the public's minds questions as to the suitability of a member of the High Court. The fact is that nothing has changed. No circumstances have arisen since the establishment of the Commission of Inquiry which would in fact detract from the rationale for the establishment of the parliamentary Commission of Inquiry in the first place. The Government has provided no answer to the fact that when it established the parliamentary Commission of Inquiry the circumstances which it considered grave enough for the establishment of that inquiry from a constitutional point of view have not changed.

I have a number of specific objections about this Bill. Some time ago, on 5 August, I lodged an application under the Freedom of Information Act for certain documents. I was able to lodge that application because this Parliament in that Act has decreed that information on a whole range of matters should be available to citizens. I applied under that Act for a copy of the transcript of the proceedings of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry, copies of all submissions presented to the Commission and copies of affidavits, reports or other documents presented to the Commission to assist the Commission with its functions as specified by section 5 of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Act 1986. I have done so, the application has been acknowledged, and this Bill now contains a clause which effectively operates retrospectively so as to bar that application, and in particular clause 7 relating to custody of documents. I might add that, whilst the Freedom of Information Act provided the right to seek access to that information, the Government in its haste omitted to place into the enabling legislation an exemption from applications under the Freedom of Information Act. It was an omission either by the sheer fact that the whole thing was done in a hurry, or for reasons unknown to me.

The House now has before it the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry (Repeal) Bill which effectively will bury all information raised in the proceedings of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry. It seems to me that even given a statement that Mr Justice Murphy would no longer sit on the High Court, it may well be that information has been obtained on the conduct of other persons who have had an association with Mr Justice Murphy. It was only a little while ago that Mr Justice Murphy made an application to the High Court for an interim or interlocutory injunction. We were told in the judgment of the High Court that:

The information which is being considered by counsel for the Commission falls into two categories: (a) allegations relating to the plaintiff's conduct in judicial office and (b) allegations relating to the plaintiff's conduct otherwise than pertaining to judicial office . . .

That, of course, exposes the arguments about the definition of misbehaviour. I think that members of the public are entitled to know what it is that the Government has considered sufficiently of concern to it-political concern, it might be an obvious conclusion to draw-that it should present a Bill today which is an effective stopper to this sort of information ever getting out.

I conclude by saying that the constitutional reasons for the establishment of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry are not in any way affected or detracted from by the illness of Mr Justice Murphy, regrettable though that may be on a personal basis. This has been a difficult matter. It has not been well managed by the Government, and it seems to me now a matter of some very adverse judgment on the Government that it should rush in today with a Bill which will bury for all time some connections with Mr Justice Murphy, and the conduct from a historical point of view of one of the members of the High Court, so as to keep it from public view. In all these matters in the end it is important for the integrity of our institutions that the real circumstances-the perspective and the circumstances in which issues such as these in the public arena have been dealt with, the manner in which they have arisen and the circumstances which gave rise to them-ought in the end to be available for public scrutiny. It is not to the Government's credit that in what appears to all intents as a means of protection or of silencing criticism of Mr Justice Murphy this Bill be introduced today, thereby, using the words of the honourable member for North Sydney, burying for all time the information and evidence collected by the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I wish in reply immediately to rebut the allegations continually made by all Opposition speakers that this is an attempt to prevent evidence that may or may not have been available to the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry from being made available. The statement by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) asked, in effect: `Was there some crime or suggestion of crime committed by a third party?' Let me scotch that suggestion once and for all. The Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Bill, to which nobody opposite really addressed his mind, contained provisions whereby matters or material before the Commission were to be handed back on request. I would be amazed if people felt that something had been given to the Commission which they were not going to ask to have back if it was in the context as submitted here today. Section 18 (2) of the original legislation provides for that. The honourable member for North Sydney is looking a little puzzled. Where a retention is requested, the Commission will be able to deliver it.
—We do not know what has happened.

—I am telling the honourable member that if a request were made the material would be handed back. Can the honourable member imagine somebody suggesting that he would not want it back? I make a further point for the honourable member's benefit. I would be grateful if he did not interrupt because he has had more than a fair uninterrupted opportunity to raise a number of matters, which I will advert to soon. Section 34 of the original legislation says that the Commission may communicate information where in the course of its inquiry there might be a suggestion of the commission of an offence. Does the honourable member think the Commission would not have done that or would not do it even now if that were the position? Again, I make the point that the suggestion has been made that clause 5 in this Bill is something novel when it is virtually a repeat of clause 16 in the original Bill. Further, there is an addendum to clause 5 that defines `document' in that sense as being limited to a document created for the purpose of the Commission and no other document that might be available to the Commission. Having said all that, it completely destroys most of the arguments submitted here today.
—Come on.

—I will come on on the basis that I think it is important to look at what the Opposition has said today. The honourable member for Bruce made no reference to anything on which he has any evidence. He referred to somebody named Anderson giving evidence. I assume that he is still available, and if he is he is the sort of person the honourable member would love to discuss matters with. But, as I understand it, he is a convicted criminal of no repute. That is the sort of allegation the honourable member wants to rely on today. I say no more about that matter. The honourable member went on with a mental aberration as to the involvement with the Central Intelligence Agency, MI5 and every other aspect, which I doubt very much would have been allowed to go unnoticed or even not investigated, since 1973. The honourable member's Government was in power for a fair period after that. Can one imagine relying on the honourable member for Bruce today to come up with something, novel, new, never before investigated, as to what might have been the suspicious movements of people way back in those days? I think the problems of security in 1973 directly related to the fact that the Premier of Yugoslavia was visiting this country and there was some suggesting that his security could not be guaranteed. I say no more than that, but the honourable member might, for his edification, like to look at one of the problems faced by governments in those days.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Bruce went into the Sankey case and everything possible. If he wants to look at the matter from the point of view of what happened there, I remind him that it was found in the course of litigation that there was no evidence to warrant people, members of government being arraigned at that time. The honourable member just has an outrageous, suspicious mind and he has used that mind to introduce into this House today a sense of venom and vindictiveness which has no relationship to what we have been discussing in this Bill. It is outrageous to think of Parliament being used, abused and misused on this basis.

We have here some suggestions as to what has happened in this matter and the position is very clear. There is medical evidence-it is not immediately in front of us, but it was in front of the Commission and its members accepted it; I have no doubt it is accurate-of the terminal illness of Mr Justice Murphy. I am mindful of the fact that in the ordinary work of courts of justice a case does not proceed if a party is not capable of following the case or instructing the legal advisers. The Commission itself said of this:
It would be contrary to established practice under natural justice.
This is the Commission itself saying these words. In this situation it seems inevitable that the Commission, and more importantly Parliament, would be represented as hounding the judge.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why doesn't he step down?
—I do not have to address every aspect in the honourable member's mind. I will tell him later what the position might be.
—You haven't answered the question.
-Order! The honourable member for Bruce will cease interjecting.
—The point that I wish to make is this: On 5 August--
—You still have not answered the question.
—If the honourable member for Bruce interjects again I will deal with him.

—On 5 August the Commission itself came forward with the concept of the matters immediately causing concern in terms of how Commission members saw the problems in front of them at that time. Could the Commission continue in the face of the medical evidence? The Commission members made it very clear that they were not able to continue. They made it very clear that the prognosis was such that it would be impossible and virtually futile for the Commission to continue. They made it very clear that the hearings would be in the judge's absence because he is unable to travel, which is a matter of medical evidence as well, and that this would be contrary to established practice and natural justice. That was their submission to the Presiding Officers to which, of course, the Opposition has been privy. The submission was given to them and therefore it is no surprise. Having said that, I point out that here is a commission which is unable to function for reasons which relate directly to the terminal illness of the person and that is the point that is clear here. I want to emphasise this: If a miracle were to happen and the judge were to be restored to health, I have no doubt that the Opposition would pursue the matter. I want to make this point: If there is evidence out there in the market-place somewhere, whether it be with the Age, the National Times or some convicted criminal, it will not stop there. They will publish it-of course they will. But what does that do for what we are about here if, at that particular stage, there is no judge available to answer those allegations. That is the incredible, dreadful thing that we face now.
—And no inquiry to investigate it.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Bruce.

—These matters are not of recent innovation. The allegations would go back years. Have a look at the Senate Select Committee on the Conduct of a Judge and what it was endeavouring to investigate; have a look at the so-called Age tapes and have a look at what Mr Justice Stewart said about the validity or worth-or worthlessness-of the transcripts.
—That is not what he said.
—Yes it is.
—You haven't read it.

—I have read it and we can debate that at another time. It is very clear that we have had all that material. The outstanding position here is that the Opposition was in government throughout that period of the Age tapes. Opposition members had access to all the information. I would be surprised if they were not able, willing or anxious to pursue it.
—We were not in government; not in 1973.

—They were in 1978, 1979 and 1980 and that is the relevant period of the Age tapes. The Opposition also had the Federal Police getting the information. It had the acknowledgement that the police had that information and it discussed the matter with the Commissioner of Police. I wish to make this point about the Commission of Inquiry: We have had all the debate of years gone by and we have the present position in which surely there is no doubt about the medical evidence and there is no doubt about the fact that the Commission itself says it cannot continue. That is the position that we have here. On that basis I come to the point about what happened in recent times. For some extraordinary reason the honourable member for North Sydney said that the Commission had been established `after months of delay'. Those were his exact words. He said `months of delay'.
—Precisely. Durack said that it should have been established well over a year ago.
—I am talking about the honourable member who said there had been `months of delay'. Let me make this point to the honourable member that--
—I referred to that in my second reading speech--
— Order! The honourable member for North Sydney has had his opportunity to address the House.

—The honourable member cannot take it; that is his problem. Let me talk about his Press statement on 29 April this year. On that date a statement was issued by Senator Fred Chaney, Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, and Mr John Spender, QC, MP, shadow Attorney-General. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: In view of the jury's finding in the trial of Mr Justice Murphy, the Opposition does not propose to take Parliamentary action in terms of section 72 of the Constitution based on the specific issues dealt with in the criminal trial. Claims that the trial was politically motivated are plainly wrong. It should be remembered that the prosecution of Mr Justice Murphy was launched by the Director of Public Prosecutions, Mr Temby, whose office was created by and whose appointment was made by the present Hawke Labor Government.
I do not know what that does for Mr Temby's independence. The statement continued:
The second trial was directed by the Court of Appeal of the Supreme Court of New South Wales.
Once that statement was issued it was very clear that there was to be no pursuit of the matter pursuant to section 72 of the Constitution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hang on. Why don't you read it again? You didn't get it right the first time-you should read it again.

—It is a pity that the honourable member did not make his contribution when he spoke during the debate and that he has to do it now by interjection. That Press release was issued on 29 April. Soon after there was a suggestion that Mr Justice Murphy would meet with his fellow justices. I wish to come right to the point. This suggestion that there would be a reason for the establishment of a commission was never even mentioned in the week of 29 April. It was never mentioned at any stage. Why is the honourable member for North Sydney suggesting that there were months of delay. There was no reason to have a commission. There were no allegations at that stage; they had all been dealt with by the courts. The honourable member says so himself in his reference to section 72. Then came a point of issue that the judges themselves were to have a meeting on the Monday, which was rather unusual. That was the first Monday in May. They issued a statement saying that Mr Justice Murphy would make a submission to the court about matters that may or may not have been in what is called the Stewart inquiry. On that score we were uncertain as to what they were discussing. We were of the view that they must have had some discussions among themselves about the position of Mr Justice Murphy because he agreed to refrain from sitting pending that explanation to his fellow justices. That is the position. In fact, we said that on the Monday evening. We were a bit surprised to find on the Tuesday morning that the justices themselves had issued a Press statement for the first time saying that that was never their intention, they were not dealing with the matter as a court and they were not considering the matter in terms of whether it was right or wrong that Mr Justice Murphy should sit with them; they merely wanted an explanation. That left some confusion certainly in the Parliament and in the public mind about what was to be done about that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: That is where the Commission sprung from. The justices themselves issued a Press statement on the Tuesday morning saying that they were to have a discussion but they were not dealing with the matter as a court and they were not actually finding on the merits. They said there would be no findings. Therefore, we said that we would have to do something about what were deemed to be the allegations. I put it very clearly to honourable members: That is the real reason why the Commission was established. We had to establish the position of Mr Justice Murphy. We could not leave that position uncertain. Would the judges have another meeting a week later? Would there be more discussions? Where was the public interest and public credibility from the point of view of saying what was happening? So we had to establish that Commission. The Opposition entered this debate so pure and anxious to say that there is no animosity and no politics. Opposition members should read the Hansard, following that opening expression. One wonders what they would say if they were to be animus and concerned about the issue from the point of view of Mr Justice Murphy and where he sees his role.

Mr Justice Murphy knows that he has a very difficult illness and knows in his own mind that he stepped down for a temporary period to discuss matters with his fellow judges. He refrained voluntarily, and in the middle of this Commission has come this dreadful prognosis. Is he not entitled, in the eyes of himself, his wife and his family, to say: `Look, I am not going to be left in a position where there is never an explanation of this matter from my point of view'? He made that explanation to me when I saw him on 5 August. He said: `I discussed this matter with my fellow judges and they never objected to my sitting with them'. I make the point that it is not contemptible of me to say that, as the honourable member for North Sydney said. It is not contemptible and never will be. One day the true story may be written. The honourable member for North Sydney says that is the position, so I will make the position very clear to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will do anything to save yourself, won't you-anything at all.

—I do not have to save my position; you have to save yours. The honourable member opened the debate by saying there was no animosity and no politics, but said in the context of the debate that Mr Justice Murphy should resign and should never be allowed to sit. That is the position from the Opposition's point of view, yet there is not one tittle of evidence to suggest that. No other person has suggested it. I make the point that when I discussed the matter with His Honour he made the point that there was no objection from his fellow judges to sitting with him, and on that basis he has gone back to the Court. In Mr Justice Murphy's mind, as well as in the eyes of his family, particularly his sons, that is a redeeming factor.

SPEECH.PARA: Bearing in mind the prognosis is a very dangerous one for life expectancy, is Mr Justice Murphy to die with this over his head? There has been no satisfactory explanation of these allegations, which have been out in the market-place for years. What fairness, honour or integrity is there in any Australian who would say that he should go to his eternal reward with that sort of smear and innuendo over not only his name but also his family? Any man would do the same, bearing in mind that he voluntarily agreed to step down to talk about some matters that were allegedly in a report. That is the real issue here. We all hope that he will recover, but the prognosis is directly the opposite to that.

The Opposition has to bear in mind today that the reason for the Commission arose because of some meetings with the judges; there was no other reason. The statement is very clear that when he was acquitted in April there was no other matter pending, and even the honourable member for North Sydney has to admit that. It was very clear in Mr Justice Murphy's statement that he was going to be on the Court the following Tuesday. All arrangements were made; then there was a meeting of the judges on Monday. There were no other accusations or allegations, nothing outstanding at all, and that is still the position now. There has been no proof of anything, except perhaps some suggestion by newspapers such as the Age and the National Times in particular which feel that they have some allegations to make. On that score, the Commission has taken evidence and has made a recommendation that it is unable to continue because it would be unfair and contrary to natural justice when it has the medical evidence in front of it. The Commission has made it clear that the allegations could not be disposed of rapidly and suggests that the judge should not be hounded by allegations or evidence, either in the Commission or in the Parliament. The Commission has said all that. It is for those reasons that we will terminate the Commission.

I hope also that we can terminate the innuendoes and allegations that have been made here today. They are not new; they were ventilated in the Senate inquiries and have been the subject of litigation in New South Wales, where the judge was acquitted. They have also been the subject of further discussions. I regret the nature of the debate today. I hope it ends on the basis that everybody wishes Mr Justice Murphy a restoration to good health and continued good health. I hope also that those people see no objection to his being able to counter any allegations they might wish to make in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable gentleman claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—If the honourable member claims to have been misrepresented he has the indulgence of the Chair.

—The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) said in his reply to the debate that I had raised something as a quite fresh matter which I had not raised some time ago. Let me quote from what I said to this House on 8 May 1986 to put on record the rebuttal to what he said. I quote from page 3442 of the Hansard which states:

SPEECH.PARA: We are not debating this legislation tonight because of some principled decision by this Government. The Government has been driven here by the Opposition, by the inexorable pressure of events, and by the mounting tide of public opinion. It has abjectly surrendered the position it has taken in the past. It has half-heartedly brought this Bill into the Parliament because it has been forced to do so and not for any other reason. It did not lack warnings. In September 1984 Senator Durack said to the Senate:
If the Government really were willing to resolve the substance of this matter . . . it would co-operate in establishing a form of parliamentary commission.
I said further, referring to the so-called impossibility of the Parliament looking at issues which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) alleged were before the High Court of Australia:

The impossibility has disappeared and the Australian Labor Party, condemned by its own Leader, has been dragged here on a pretence of integrity which demonstrates not only a grievous and cowardly failure of duty over months but also an unprincipled abdication of constitutional responsibility.

I repeated those words `unprincipled abdication of constitutional responsibility' today. The Attorney-General read from a statement which I made on 29 April 1986 and implied very clearly that what I was saying was that there was nothing to look into. I read again the relevant part of that statement:

In view of the jury's finding in the trial of Mr Justice Murphy, the Opposition does not propose to take Parliamentary action in terms of Section 72 of the Constitution based on the specific issues dealt with in the criminal trial.
I repeat these words `based on the specific issues dealt with in the criminal trial'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker I wish to make a personal explanation in reply to the inference made by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender).
—Does the honourable gentleman claim to have been misrepresented?

—I claim to have been misrepresented. The honourable member endeavoured to misrepresent what I said in the sense that he quoted what Senator Durack said in 1984 in an earlier Hansard debate. I have no objection to his saying that but it must be read in context. Subsequent to 1984 there was a trial of Mr Justice Murphy, who, in April this year, was acquitted. That is the difference. I was explaining to the House that the honourable gentleman-
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: This is not a personal explanation. It is not a statement of misrepresentation; it is an argument.
—The Chair is alert to the possibility of a resumption of debate and will take action at the appropriate time.

—I am not anxious to argue but the honourable gentleman has misrepresented me by suggesting that I said the wrong thing when I said to him today that he was talking about months of delay when in fact on 29 April he was not raising any issue at all. It is not much help to the House to be talking about what Senator Durack said in 1984 and I want to make the point-

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: State Mail Centre, 501 Williamstown Road, Port Melbourne.

The Australian Postal Commission requires new accommodation for the State Mail Centre currently located in the existing sub-standard Mail Exchange building, for the processing of mail. The new accommodation will provide loading bays for mail trucks and containers, as well as offices, staff amenities and official and staff car parking. The new centre will be the main Victorian facility for, first, the exchange of mail between Victorian mail centres and other States, and, secondly, customers' lodgement of bulk mails. The new building is a single-storey structure sited to harmonise with its surroundings. All operational facilities, staff amenities, offices and loading bays will be on ground level, including an allowance for on-site car parking of 158 vehicles.

The proposal is the result of a publicly advertised request by Australia Post for offers to supply a building on a fully serviced site with suitable vehicle access and within a defined distance from the central business district. The recommended offer was developed to the satisfaction of Australia Post and local and State authorities and its design is satisfactory to the Public Works Committee. The total estimated cost of the proposed work is $10.8m at April 1986 prices.

I would like to thank the Public Works Committee for its prompt consideration of the proposal. If the House agrees to support this motion, planning can proceed in accordance with the recommendations of the Committee. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) for making the information available to me. SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Minister to ensure that the private sector only is involved in the construction of the State Mail Centre at Port Melbourne.
