PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 May, on motion by Mr Scholes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Amendment Bill has the support of the Opposition. The Bill sets out to amend the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981, which was passed by the Parliament during the period of the Fraser Government. The proposal underlying the amendments is to create a more specific relationship between the legislation and the dumping of radioactive materials in Australian waters as well as meeting Australia's inter- national commitments in relation to the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty, which was recently signed by the Government. It is proposed also that there be a convention for the protection of the natural resources and environment of the South Pacific. Therefore, the purpose of the amendments is threefold: First, to change the original legislation; secondly, to meet the international requirements of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty; and, thirdly, to meet the expected requirements of the protection of the natural resources and environment of the South Pacific.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation is based initially on the 1981 Act, which was passed in this Parliament as a means of bringing into effect the London convention which dealt with high-level waste disposal in the sea, including nuclear wastes. The amendments will prevent the dumping at sea of any radioactive material which has radioactivity in excess of 35 becquerels per gram. I should emphasise that this is an arbitrary figure. It is based on a level of activity slightly above that of naturally occurring potassium, which is not potentially harmful to marine biota.

A substantial amount of research has been carried out in recent years on the likely impact of the dumping in deep seas of high-level nuclear wastes, which has been one of the possible solutions to the growing international problem of what to do with the substantial amount of waste which is currently being created, especially by economies in which the generation of power through nuclear means is a matter of great importance. For example, in France 40 per cent of all power generated is from nuclear sources. In that context it is worth noting that the Opposition naturally supports the decision announced by the Government in the Budget last night that France should be permitted, along with all other countries that use Australian exported uranium for peaceful purposes, to buy our uranium. However, the fact is, as was pointed out by a leading Australian miner, Mr Hugh Morgan, on the AM program this morning, it is highly unlikely, given the fact that the French have been locked out of the market in recent years, that they will be prepared to re-enter in the short term.

This legislation is based principally on the political necessity, as perceived in the South Pacific, of making it very clear to the world as a whole that the nations of the South Pacific, including Australia, are not in any sense happy about the continuation of French nuclear testing in our region. One of the provisions in the Act makes it fairly clear that, while French nuclear testing is not specifically referred to by the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) in his second reading speech, nevertheless, sources of pollution from the carrying out of tests, even if they take place well below the surface of the ground, could be defined as the dumping of materials of a radioactive nature.

Therefore, the essential problem that we shall face in future is the manner by which we solve the problem of the growing amount of radioactive nuclear materials, which is the result of the nuclear industry. The Pacific, as we are well aware, is the largest physiographic feature on the planet. It occupies some 35 per cent of the earth's surface and has an average depth of 4,282 metres and a volume of approximately 708 million cubic kilometres. It is said that the average residence time for water molecules in its deep waters is about 1,000 to 1,300 years. It should be pointed out that sea water, as with all elements of the natural environment, contains radioactivity.

The radioactivity of sea water from all natural radionuclides is about 750 dpms per litre, much of which is derived from potassium. The Pacific Ocean contains some 2.4 x 10 to the 11th power curies of natural radioactivity. In 1970, the total burden of artificial radionuclides in the sea amounted to less than one per cent of this total. It is perfectly clear that there is no perceived threat to the Pacific at this time.

In the northern Pacific in recent years, however, the Japanese have been dumping the residue of their nuclear industry as a matter of course. This has resulted in a considerable amount of political activity by nations throughout the Pacific region. In 1981, the Japanese sent to Australia and elsewhere a high-level delegation to try to explain to nations in the region how it saw the problem and in the hope of receiving our support. The then Minister, the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson), said in a letter tabled in the House on 2 June 1981:
Australia made it clear that it was opposed to the Pacific region becoming a dumping ground for the indiscriminate and uncontrolled disposal of nuclear waste.

The Japanese technical mission which visited South Pacific countries to explain Japan's proposed operation held discussions with officials in Canberra during August 1980. It was during these discussions that Australia's views on the matter were made known to the Japanese. The officials advised the Japanese mission that Australia considered it essential that the disposal of nuclear waste in any environment, and in particular the Pacific Ocean, should be undertaken only in compliance with the strictest safety measures and in full accordance with the relevant international agreements on the subject. Australia has taken a position to this effect at meetings of the South Pacific Forum.

Events have moved further since then. As I said, we are presumably now about to have on the statute books, if the Parliament passes the legislation, the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty, and all the implications of that which will follow. The difficulty, however, rests with our ability to realise that, while it is still apparently economically feasible for major nuclear waste dumps to be contained on the land, the issue may well arise in the future of the extent to which, if at all, low level nuclear waste disposal is possible in certain parts of the oceans where it can be quite clearly proven, in geomorphological terms, that there is no likelihood of a dangerous spreading of the nuclear waste. These are issues which may well have to be considered in the future. I am well aware that there are members of the so-called left wing of the Government party who resent in any context the use of nuclear power. But people need to remember this: When we are talking about the dumping of low level nuclear waste we are in fact not referring to the dumping of radio isotopes and so forth, or major elements of the fuel rod process for the generation of power. Often what we are referring to are such simple things as the dumping of old uniforms, gloves and materials used in hospitals where radiological work is essential for the protection from and the treatment of diseases such as cancer. While this material exists-and it clearly will continue to do so for the foreseeable future-the world must face up to how it will overcome these growing problems of nuclear waste.

The United States of America, for example, has estimated that there are some 2.3 million cubic metres of low level waste, 77.6 million gallons of highly radioactive liquid waste, 331,000 cubic metres of transuranic waste, 175 million tonnes of radioactive uranium mining tailings and 6,700 tonnes of spent nuclear reactor fuel. By the early twenty-first century, the accumulated high level radioactive waste requiring disposal will be an estimated 10 million curies. This is about 25 per cent of the natural radioactivity of the oceans at present. It is worth noting that in France, for example, one million tonnes of wastes of all types are being produced daily. That does not necessarily demonstrate the true situation because, as I said earlier, it does not distinguish between high level wastes and low level wastes. The vast majority of that waste, in fact, would be low level wastes which present no foreseeable threat whatsoever.

I think it is worth noting, in terms of the maximum radioactivity levels covered by the Treaty, which refers specifically to those in excess of 35 bequerels, that even natural substances, such as granite, produce levels very close to that reading. People tend to forget that all of nature is radioactive; it is a question of the degree to which radioactivity can be centralised to damage human beings or the biosphere as a whole. One of the areas which will require significantly greater research in future years will no doubt be the impact, if any, the dumping of nuclear wastes in any part of the ocean can have on the fish population. It has been hypothesised on the basis of scientific models, that one can detect through the food chain a clear link between radioactivity which may contaminate crustaceans, deep in the ocean or on the bottom of the sea, and that found in species ultimately right up to sharks, which in turn gain most of their nutrients from eating other species of fish. These varieties in turn can be captured by fishermen and sold on the open market with the result that human beings can also receive some contamination.

While there is no evidence of which I am aware that such nuclear contamination has yet been identified, it is significant, that in looking at the question of overall polluting of the ocean, there have been some very unsavoury examples of what ocean pollution can mean. For example, there was in the late 1970s the Minamata Bay episode in Japan, when residents ate fish and other marine life that was heavily contaminated with mercury. Many of those people died as a result of acute mercury poisoning. In fact, by April 1977 it was certified that some 1,076 residents were victims of the disease and a further 3,000 were potential victims. Needless to say, mercury, cadmium and various other heavy metals in particular, present a constant environmental poisoning potential which must forever be kept in mind. Even in Australia in the estuaries of our rivers we periodically have problems with contaminated oysters. A case of this in the Derwent estuary in the 1970s caused considerable difficulties when it was discovered that some oysters contained 26,000 parts per million of zinc because up river from that area there was a large zinc plant.

Toxicity, therefore, which can be directly implanted in the ocean as a result of the actions of humanity, is something with which we must continue to be particularly concerned. I do not think it is overstating the fact to say that in the last hundred years or so the land and the seas of the world have probably suffered more pollution directly attributable to human activity than in any of the four billion years of their previous existence. While the Mediterranean under some conditions can be seen as a beautiful blue sea, I have noted the extraordinary amount of pollution that is found there, principally because of the virtual absence of tidal activity and the effect of the winds. Those states which are on the eastern seaboard tend to get the lot. Everything dropped from one end of the sea to the other floats through and finally is deposited on the coastline of either Egypt, Israel, the Lebanon or Syria. These are difficulties which need to be faced by legislation such as this. While it is proposed in this Bill to give protection against the effect of nuclear pollution of the Australian Continental Shelf and our 200-mile continental fishing zone, it is also provided in the legislation that no Australian citizen will be able to pollute and any citizen who does so will be subject to the laws of Australia.

I think it is very significant that very considerable areas will be covered by the Treaty. We are talking about a huge area of water. The big problem we are facing, however, is the extent to which the mini-states of the South Pacific can be expected to police adequately the very real problems that will be facing this area. In recent years the Australian Government has played a useful role in providing coastal patrol boats to a number of these states, such as the Solomon Islands and Vanuatu, to give them some capability of protecting their 200-mile exclusive fishing zones. In this context, of course, we have the difficulty that the United States tuna fishing fleets chose to ignore the 200-mile economic zone because the United States had decided not to sign the Law of the Sea Treaty. Nevertheless, the whole question of pollution and the utilisation of resources in what are now the exclusive economic zones in the South Pacific will be something which Australian governments from here on in will have to take a lot more seriously than they have in the past. There is no likelihood, in my opinion, on the basis of the limited resources and the significant lack of wealth of most of those South Pacific nations, with the possible exception of Papua New Guinea at one extreme and also of Fiji, that these States will alone be able to safeguard the interests of the region.

As I said earlier, there is a tendency in this legislation to point the accusing finger, yet again, at the fact that the French are continuing nuclear testing in the South Pacific below the Muroroa atoll. Some research has been carried out; there have been scientific visits; reports have been tabled to the effect that as yet no certain damage is taking place to the structure of the geomorphological formations in those areas. But nevertheless, there is a constant fear that from that deep nuclear testing in the ocean floor we may well ultimately see a significant increase in the level of nuclear pollution of the South Pacific.

The people of the South Pacific nations in particular are concerned that, in turn, this will affect the basis of their whole economic system and their way of life-namely, access to the sea and the fish in the sea which form the basis of their food supply. Already there have been cases, which have not been proven, in some of the Pacific Islands where major diseases and apparent sicknesses have been caused by polluted fish. But there is no evidence at this stage that that pollution is necessarily directly caused by uranium leakages from nuclear tests in the Pacific. Nevertheless, it is a possibility which makes people very concerned and, as one learns in politics, perceptions of people's expectations of disaster are often worse than the overall result.

For all those reasons, it is significant that this legislation is before the House. It will be supported by the Opposition because we believe that Australia has a continuing role to play in the South Pacific. We have to back up the nations in that region. They are not only our neighbours; they are in a sense our potential allies because the South Pacific represents to Australia, in strategic terms, at least as important an area of ocean as does the Indian Ocean on the other side of the continent. We are in every sense of the term a two-ocean continent and our responsibility as competent allies and friends is to be seen not just in defence terms but in our willingness and ability to play our role by giving support, where appropriate, in legislation that backs agreements of this nature. The Opposition, as will be discovered in due course, has some difficulties with some of the proposals that have been put forward by the Government, but that is not to be seen in any sense as an unwillingness by the Opposition to support at least the principles which are enunciated in the legislation that is before the House. For that reason, on behalf of the Opposition, I support the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Amendment Bill 1986.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with great pleasure to speak on the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Amendment Bill, and I was pleased to hear the Opposition spokesman on the environment speaking in support of this very important Bill. It gives me a great deal of pleasure to stand here and discuss this subject, which is very close to my heart and I trust to everyone else's-that is, the protection of our environment. In particular, I would like to talk about the dumping at sea of radioactive waste and outline why it is so critical that we as a nation support the proposed amendments to the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act.

SPEECH.PARA: For those who are not familiar with that section of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill, I will run through the proposed amendments. The Government believes that each country involved with the South Pacific nuclear-free zone should undertake not to dump radioactive waste and any other radioactive matter within the South Pacific nuclear-free zone; to prevent the dumping of radioactive waste and other radioactive matter by anyone in its territorial sea; not to take any action which will assist or encourage the dumping by anyone of radioactive waste or other radioactive matter at sea anywhere within the South Pacific nuclear-free zone; to support the conclusion as soon as possible of the proposed convention relating to the protection of the natural resources and environment of the South Pacific region and its protocol for the prevention of pollution of the region by dumping. This is with the aim of precluding dumping at sea of radioactive wastes and other radioactive matter by anyone anywhere in this region.

At present, ocean dumping of hazardous waste violates only some international accords. This Government believes that such dumping should not be allowed under any circumstances in the South Pacific nuclear-free zone. The dumping of packaged low and intermediate level waste, usually incorporated in concrete, in steel drums, into the deep ocean, has been practised for several decades. From 1967 to 1982 this practice was carried out annually by a few European countries. Eventually, the dumping was opposed by some 45 European countries. Then several South Pacific nations entered the picture when Japan proposed trial dumping in the South Pacific.

As a consequence of this opposition, no disposal of waste took place in the North Atlantic in 1983, pending reports from several inquiries which have been carried out by governments and responsible authorities. These inquiries included assessments of the wider political, legal, economic and social aspects of radioactive waste dumping at sea, costs and lists of comparative land-based options and whether it could be proved that any dumping of waste and other radioactive matter at sea would harm or not harm life and cause significant damage to the marine environment.

Unfortunately, the convention resolved to ban only high level wastes specified by the International Atomic Energy Agency, in co-operation with other international bodies, as unsuitable for dumping at sea. That sort of legislation does not go nearly far enough. The Australian Government is acting in a farsighted and scrupulous manner to prevent future problems arising from the unknown quantity of radioactive waste dumping in our oceans. It is far better to act now than to regret inaction later.

No other issue affecting society has resulted in as wide a gap between beliefs held by the public and the scientific community. In fact, our esteemed scientists even disagree with one another about the effects of ocean dumping, and recommend that much more research be undertaken. No one-and I mean no one-really knows what the end result of dumping radioactive waste in the oceans of the world will be.

Some will be thinking that, since only low and intermediate level wastes will be dumped at sea, what is the fuss about? Why should it not go ahead? But the danger in letting countries dump their radioactive waste into our oceans lies in some unscrupulous countries dumping any type of waste, whether it be low, intermediate or high radioactivity, simply because of their wish to save money and because of the extreme cost of storing nuclear waste in other ways. Some countries and some people have no scruples where money is concerned.

If honourable members opposite do not understand this point, let me explain. The aim of radioactive waste management is to contain or dilute the radioactive material to such a degree that disposal will not present a significant biological hazard. Radiation doses to individuals are maintained as low as is reasonably achievable within limits recommended by the International Commission for Radiological Protection. Glass is used for the solidification of high level nuclear waste, which is said to be very stable because it has good resistance to heat, chemical action, radioactions and mechanical stresses. The vitrified waste is stored in stainless steel containers chosen to resist corrosion. This waste is then kept for 30 to 50 years in water ponds or air cooling chambers or the reprocessing plant. Hopefully, after this time, the heat output would have declined sufficiently to allow the containers to be transferred to boreholes in rocks where natural cooling is adequate. In the Swedish nuclear waste management proposals, the drums that I have mentioned would have a 10-centimetre cladding of lead and an outer case of 6 millimetres of titanium.

The process is extremely expensive. A great deal of time is involved and it is certainly not just a matter of throwing a few burnt rocks of uranium on a pile and forgetting about it. I am sure that countries with a nuclear industry agree that the option of dumping the lot into the ocean sounds a great deal better and a great deal cheaper. We are all aware that modern society creates waste materials that are supposed to be disposed of in nature without unduly disturbing the ecological equilibrium. But effective disposal techniques have not been found for some of this waste. Most plastics do not degrade. Poisonous mercury does not degrade or decay; nor do many other man-made materials. We live and breathe amidst discharges of noxious gases, aerosols, exhaust emissions of motor vehicles and increasing radioactivity. Yet we continue to produce these articles that are not easily disposed of.

We now face a more serious threat from the careless disposal of nuclear waste-in particular, as I have already said, from the dumping of radioactive waste into our very lifeline, the sea. The oceans of the world make up the largest percentage of the surface of the earth. They are an essential component in our food chain-essential for the survival of humanity. Yet some of us maliciously and wantonly disregard the delicate balance of this our most precious resource. We continue to dump rubbish, sewage, detergents, oil, radioactive waste and other materials into our oceans.

If the basic objective in the disposal of radioactive waste is the protection of man and his environments from unacceptable harm, how can sea dumping be justified when so little is known of the effects of this procedure and of the harm that it will continue to cause on the ecological equilibrium? Did the rules prevent the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics from trying to cut costly safety measures at Chernobyl? Have these regulations and postulations of various governments and scientists around the world prevented France from atmospheric nuclear testing at Mururoa Atoll? According to a report from a scientific mission to Mururoa, the pattern of past testing beneath the atoll rim has produced in the sub-surface a repository of nuclear waste products whose depth probably varies from 500 metres to 1,200 metres.

The French claim that any leakage from the volcanics and limestones will be stopped by the impermeable transition zone. The transition zone which occurs between the volcanics is highly variable in thickness and rock type. This casts grave doubt on its ability to act as a barrier to radioactive leakage. The potential exists for leakage of water from detonation cavities into the biosphere. Even though this process takes a good many years, that is not an excuse to ignore the possible future ramifications. This risk should not have been taken by them. We have to show those countries that we mean what we say. We have to educate people to the dangers of a casual attitude towards any sort of nuclear waste management.

At this time I will refer to the Government's decision to sell a stockpile of $66m worth of uranium to the French. I can sell the Budget in my electorate, and I can sell some of the hard decisions. But I cannot and will not sell this decision. I believe it is wrong and I will do all within my power to get it changed. I was elected in 1983 and my maiden speech was devoted solely to peace and disarmament and to what I thought were the principles and philosophies of the Australian Labor Party in not selling uranium to people who do not care about this area of the world. I have said previously that I will work as hard as I can to make certain that this decision does not go ahead; my lobbying has started already.

To return to the Bill, there are many examples of radioactive matter leaking or spilling or contaminating plant. I will give a few examples. In 1958 in Canada at the Chalk River plant an irradiated fuel element broke and the plant caught fire. There were two months of intense contamination. An area of 400,000 square metres around the building was contaminated. In 1970 at the Hanford reactor in the United States of America a loss of coolant automatically started the primary scram system. Scram is the rapid reinsertion of control rods. The system failed due to a short circuit. The back-up scram system worked. General Electric stated before the accident happened that the probability of a failure of the scram unit was one in 10 billion; the actual rate so far has been one in 10,000. Past accidents at Hanford occurred in 1954, in 1955 and in 1966.

In 1971 at Waterford, Connecticut, United States of America, the Mills Cone reactor suffered a malfunction of the system valve which caused the radioactivity and hence the power lever to rise beyond the fuel or rated power level. The scram system or reactor safety system went into action. But, had it failed, there would have been a rapid core meltdown or nuclear runaway explosion and finally a major public disaster. Defective equipment allowed plutonium oxide to escape into the atmosphere at Oklahoma City in the United States of America. Twenty-two workers were contaminated.

There are more recent accidents, of course. Most honourable members will remember the Three Mile Island accident in the United States of America in March 1979. The authorities are still cleaning that up. At that time that was considered the worst incident in the history of commercial nuclear power stations. The reactor was almost new, having been in operation for only three months. Investigations which have since been carried out have found that both the manufacturer and the operator hurried through the start-up period. The accident was caused by a stoppage of the main feedwater pumps, that is, a failure of the secondary cooling circuit; by the failure of the emergency pumps to operate because of the line being closed, which represented a breach of procedure; by the failure of a pressure valve to close, leading to the loss of the primary cooling fluid; and by the failure of operators to recognise the above fault, leading to the manual shutdown of the automatic emergency core cooling system.

How long will we ignore these so-called accidents when it is obvious that they are usually the fault of greed or of a casual attitude towards the most destructive force in mankind's history, or of a total lack of regard for the safety precautions that must be followed. We do not have to go back as far as 1979 or Chernobyl. Just in the last month John Lysaght (Australia) Ltd at Hastings in Victoria lost a radioactive americium 241 cylinder which has since been traced to Australian Portland Cement Ltd in Geelong. I am pleased to see the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) here. John Lysaght is one of the largest employers in his electorate and he is very well aware of this matter. That cylinder was found in a cement grinding mill in Geelong. Let us just imagine what would have happened if that piece of radioactive material had gone through the grinding mill and been mixed up in the cement. The radioactive cylinder fell out of its casing into an iron scale pit at Lysaght's. The cylinder was transported to Geelong where the scale was used as raw material to make cement. The cylinder could have been dispersed with over 30,000 tonnes of cement.
A report in the Age of 15 August, in a small paragraph, I think on about page 5, stated:
``Finding the cylinder was like finding a needle in a haystack,'' the spokesman said. Health Department officials have taken the cylinder to Melbourne laboratories for analysis.

Even though radiation levels in the material were analysed by the Health Department and the Australian Radiation Laboratory and classified as safe, the question remains of what might have happened had the cylinder contained high levels of radioactivity. Let us follow the cylinder from the accident point through to Geelong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The remarks of the honourable member for Dunkley are of more than ordinary interest but he is rather stretching their relevance to the Bill before the House.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. However, let us imagine what might have happened if that cement had been put into buildings. The radioactive emissions would have affected generations of Australians. I could go on but honourable members all get the picture. The hackneyed expression `prevention is better than cure' has come back to haunt us in a most terrible way. We have to stop pretending that these sorts of accidents will not happen; they do, they have and they will continue to happen. Surely it is time to stop the ostrich-like syndrome and take as many positive steps as possible to eliminate such grave dangers from our environment. The Government's anti-sea dumping proposal is one such step. There are already 30 years or more of experience in storing nuclear waste, but we continue to be careless. Is it worth the risks? Is it worth ignoring? This Government thinks not.

SPEECH.PARA: Close to home again, recently I was at Kakadu National Park with my colleagues on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation. The Government has had a request from the ranger uranium mine to allow it to release periodically contaminated water into the Magella Creek apparently during appropriate periods of high natural flow during the wet season. A large framework of Federal and Territory legislation exists for water management in the Alligator River region. Yet our friendly scientists seldom have enough information to make statements regarding the changes which could occur due to excess exposure to radiation. What point is there in conducting environmental studies if they are unable to tell us what will happen and why?

The Magella flows finally into the sea. If Ranger dumps waste water, can we prosecute it under this Act? Under these circumstances, to consider seriously anything other than the banning of ocean dumping of radioactive wastes would be criminally negligent. In pointing out the anomalies in what has been said and what is proposed for future nuclear power plants waste disposal and what generally happens now I am alerting all honourable members to the fact that talking about it is cheap; sensitive disposal of nuclear waste is expensive. I know which course some countries take when faced with expensive decisions.

When will mankind have the maturity and the intelligence to prevent such horrendous damage to our world and allow future generations to inhabit a world which has not been poisoned by radioactive waste? It can be done and it will be done if the Government continues to lead the way and implement such legislation. I support this Bill and I urge the House and all those in Australia who are listening to support it also.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Amendment Bill which seeks to oppose the dumping at sea of radioactive waste and other radioactive matter by Australian citizens in Australian waters. For too long we have viewed our seas as dumping grounds for our waste products with no thought whatsoever of the ramifications on the marine life and ecological balance. However, now in our more enlightened frame of mind, we are beginning to understand how the sea is affected by our actions and the ecologically sensitive nature of this vast resource.

SPEECH.PARA: This piece of amending legislation is a recognition of this growing awareness of the waters covering three quarters of the earth's surface. Yet to my mind, this Bill does not address the real problem of radioactive waste disposal. I pose the question: If we elect not to dump these wastes into the sea, what do we do with them, how do we dispose of them? I contend the dumping at sea of radioactive wastes was never a serious alternative in Australia because of the limited amount of radioactive material generated throughout our country. Nevertheless, this Bill as presented does not preview alternative methods of disposal under consideration, nor does it address the inconsistencies existing between the Commonwealth and State governments in dealing with this problem. This situation was brought to the Commonwealth's attention following the release of recommendations by a joint Commonwealth-State committee on the management of radioactive wastes arising from medical, industrial and research use of radionuclides.

In November 1983 the Committee made several suggestions which were accepted by the Federal Government, Northern Territory, and all States except Victoria. Cabinet endorsed the following recommendations in February 1984: A uniform code of practice for user disposal of very low level radioactive waste to air, water and landfill areas be adopted nationally; a national program be commenced to identify sites potentially suitable for the disposal by way of shallow ground burial of radioactive wastes, with site identification to be based on internationally accepted criteria; the Commonwealth investigate the development of facilities for interim and long term storage of radioactive wastes; and, finally, the States agree to actively assist in the establishment of national storage and disposal facilities, and in the operation of appropriate administrative arrangements to permit access to such facilities by all participating governments.

Victoria has refused to accept radioactive waste burial in shallow trenches in its State on environmental and health grounds, but it acknowledges other parts of Australia may be suitable. It was not until a year and a half later in mid-1985 that the Government, through the Department of Resources and Energy, initiated a program to act on one of these recommendations. Senator Gareth Evans, the Minister for Resources and Energy, announced the Department would begin investigating sites for shallow ground burial, and should report back within six to nine months. However, at the same time, the Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council sounded a warning about shallow ground disposal, cautioning adequate site selection could take many years involving several Commonwealth and State authorities. Since then, we have heard nothing regarding these investigations, leaving Australia with no cohesive national plan for the disposal of low and intermediate level radioactive wastes. As a result, we continue to have these wastes scattered throughout Australia, stored in Commonwealth and State facilities. Because of this lack of adequate, centralised control, we have had our own minor nuclear shocks, mistakes and coverups over the years. While not on the same scale of Chernobyl or Winscale, these revelations make it necessary to take some more positive action to develop a comprehensive approach to nuclear waste disposal. Basic uniform procedures must be legislated for in several areas such as packaging, labelling and transport of radioactive substances throughout all States and Territories.

Whilst all of these areas are of equal importance, I will concentrate my attention on the issue of transporting radioactive waste across State lines. As it stands now, we have no national code of practice for the safe transport of low and interim level wastes. The original intention of the Environmental Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act, 1978, was to develop various codes of practice in consultation with the States. Where State laws did not follow the codes, the Commonwealth was able to make regulations enforcing the codes within a State or Territory. The Commonwealth, since that time, has prepared several codes, including one for safe transport of radioactive substances based on the International Atomic Energy Agency regulations. Yet, the States, with the exception of South Australia and the Northern Territory, have not incorporated them into State law. This is not a problem overseas because of the International Atomic Energy Agency, but it has caused situations here where accidents have occurred and no one was willing to take responsibility for them.

In 1984 there was a serious incident in New South Wales involving a leaking isotope container dispatched to the Lucas Heights nuclear establishment from a consignor in Brisbane. The State of New South Wales felt it could not act and requested the Queensland Government to prosecute, but without result. Many constitutional specialists state the Commonwealth has ample external affairs powers to apply its Environmental Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act directly within the States. This could be with or without the consent of the State governments.

There are other serious considerations which need to be addressed when approaching a legislative framework within the transport area. Some of these are: The safety of the driver and assistants, as well as the public, the consignor and consignee in respect of radiation from intact, closed containers; the likelihood of and protection against terrorism and/or robbery; adequate policing of regulations and deterring penalities; adequate, standard and easily recognisable warning signs; and, traffic and other special arrangements for major transport of highly dangerous radioactive materials.

I am quite astounded these very basic considerations are not being reviewed or enforced by the Federal Government. As I stated earlier, the dumping at sea of nuclear wastes was never a serious alternative generally because of the amount of wastes generated within Australia. What the Minister for Resources and Energy should be addressing is the issue of the introduction of adequate International Atomic Energy Agency codes which are uniform throughout Australia. There are currently sufficient existing transport requirements to justify the formal use of IAEA regulations. The States and the Commonwealth should be more interested in updating their radiation protection legislation. Radioactive wastes will not go away because of neglect of adequate law enforcement. Consideration of this problem has been going on since 1979. Is it not about time we seriously confront the issue and make some positive moves in the right direction? I call upon the Minister to stop nibbling around the edges and come to some hard conclusions about this very real, pressing problem.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! It being close to 12.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with Sessional Order 101a. The debate may be resumed at a later hour.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that we have present in the Gallery Senator the Hon. Guy Charbonneau, Speaker of the Senate, and the Hon. John Bosley, Speaker of the House of Commons, in the Parliament of Canada. With the concurrence of honourable members, I propose to provide the two Presiding Officers with seats on the floor of the House.

INTERJECT.PARA: Speakers Charbonneau and Bosley were thereupon seated accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that Senator Charbonneau and Mr Bosley are leading a parliamentary delegation from Canada. Other members of the delegation are present in the Speaker's Gallery. On behalf of honourable members, I extend to the delegation a warm welcome.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. In view of the fact that the Australian dollar has dropped today to a level below its pre-Budget close of US63.30c-we will see whether the Treasurer laughs as the dollar goes down-and the fact that last night the growth figures for the United States economy were revised downwards, is the Treasurer still confident about his growth projection of 2 1/4 per cent for 1986-87, and does he still expect a significant reduction in interest rates during the course of the year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The historic changes the Government made to Australia's fiscal policy last evening will of course make a difference to the underlying fundamentals of the Australian economy in both the medium and long term, and the judgments in foreign exchange markets no doubt will be gauged to the medium and long term outcomes in the economy. While one always sees movements in the foreign exchange rate and money market rates whenever there are substantial public announcements, I do not regard the movements up or down over the last 24 hours as being of any significance in making a judgment about the foreign exchange market's view of the Government's changes. I say with all respect that, if the honourable member for Mackellar thinks that, he has a lot to learn about the way in which the foreign exchange market will make a judgment about this country.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member asked me a question about the growth assumptions in the Budget. The growth assumptions in the Budget are both hard and reasonable ones. We have forecast gross domestic product growth at the level of 2 1/4 per cent and for the non-farm economy 2 1/2 per cent, and the contribution to growth coming this year-1 3/4 percentage points of the 2 1/4 per cent of GDP or the 2 1/2 per cent of non farm product-comes from a stronger net export performance being driven by the devaluation of the exchange rate.

I remind honourable members that in last year's Budget we forecast a contribution to growth from net exports of 1 1/4 percentage points, which was driven by the 20 per cent depreciation of the dollar at that time. Since that time we have had a further 20 per cent depreciation of the dollar. Now, as it is some time since February 1985 when the exchange rate first fell, the impetus to growth, to a better net export performance, coming after depreciation of the exchange rate, I think would lead anyone to believe that the assumption of 1 3/4 percentage points, given the fact that we achieved 1 1/4 percentage points in the national accounts last year, is entirely reasonable.

In terms of the other elements of the growth forecast, we have 0.5 per cent for gross national expenditure, for demand-and 0.5 per cent is almost the lowest figure since 1956-57. It is a most modest assumption. It is important in terms of cutting down demand for imports, and between the 1 3/4 percentage points coming off net exports and the 0.5 per cent off GNE, it makes the assumptions entirely reasonable. The external assumptions have been based on International Monetary Fund and Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development assumptions, including judgments about the weakening of the United States economy, but so much of the contribution to growth in this year will come from the replacement of imports within Australia. We will not be sucking in imports at the rate we were, and a lot of our exporters will also be finding markets for their exports, as indeed Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd did over the last year by lifting manufactured exports of steel products by 25 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Trade explain the aims and objectives of the Agricultural Marketing Innovation Fund established in the 1986-87 Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Agricultural Marketing Innovation Fund was announced as part of the statement by the Minister for Primary Industry on economic and rural policy. The Budget provides for the first instalment of $5m to be provided through the Australian Trade Commission for this important new initiative. With the depressed state of agricultural markets around the world, Australia has to find new ways to support agricultural marketing around the world, not only of raw agricultural products but also of processed agricultural products, food and so on. This program is designed to provide the necessary research and back-up to develop new products and to take advantage of new opportunities as they emerge.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Trade Commission, along with the Department of Primary Industry, assisted by expert advice from statutory marketing authorities and so on, will be seeking proposals from the industry under this program. This will mark a new beginning in terms of a revived thrust for agricultural marketing of Australian products around the world.

This initiative is in sharp contrast to the statements of that rather bizarre Liberal member in Western Australia. Of course we are used to the Western Australian Liberal Party producing some fairly bizarre individuals, but there have been no remarks quite as extraordinary as those made by Mr Lightfoot in a letter to the Secretary of State in the United States of America. This reveals that what Opposition members want, at least if they do not dissociate themselves from Mr Lightfoot, is to see an aggravation of the problems being confronted by Australian farmers, which would see a further reduction in farmers' living standards, and as well an undermining of the Australian currency and a reduction in the standard of living of all Australians.

The important thing is that it is bad enough for Mr Lightfoot to be making those remarks, but it is infinitely worse that the Leader of the Opposition has not dissociated himself from those remarks, even when he was given the opportunity to do so not only in the House yesterday but also through the media this morning.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for O'Connor may well wish to dissociate himself from those remarks, recognising that the National Party in Western Australia is breathing heavily down the back of his neck in relation to his Federal seat.
—It is you blokes who are wanting to run wild.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor would do well to consider his position.
—In more ways than one.
—I rise on a point of order, Madam Speaker. We are back to personal attack and if you are going to tolerate it, what am I entitled to do?
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat.

—Madam Speaker, I think it ill becomes the Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the National Party in this place to retain their silence on this matter. It is a very important issue which would have very severe consequences for the Australian agricultural industry. It is quite clear that the Leader of the Opposition is prepared to do whatever is necessary in order to sabotage the recovery within Australia. Of course, he seeks to ride to power on the back of a broken economy which he himself has attempted to sabotage. We do not intend to stand idly by while these kinds of ridiculous proposals are made. We are doing everything we can, both on a bilateral basis and a multilateral basis and indeed with special marketing efforts, to ensure that the agricultural trade of this country enjoys better prospects in the future.

—My question is again addressed to the Treasurer. How does the Treasurer expect to get the import replacement needed to redress our ailing balance of payments problem, given that he has forecast a one per cent decline in business investment this financial year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The forecast in the Budget Papers of a decline in business investment of one per cent is translated literally from the Statistician's forecasts or intention surveys taken about investment at the height of uncertainty about the course of public policy over the last few months. We are not of a view to inject any discretion into that judgment, but I think that the change in sentiment which will arise both within Australia and about Australia will markedly improve that investment outcome over the course of the year.
—Oh! So it is going to be higher.

—No, the Budget forecast stands. Personally I think it will be higher because the huge stimulus available from the depreciation, the profitability now of the traded goods sector of the economy and the capacity for business to import replacements on an accelerated scale obviously mean that that potential is there. Also, it needs to be understood that we have had quite a deal of excess capacity left over from the Howard recession of 1982-83. While we have been using that extra capacity utilisation--
—You think it is going to be higher.

—The fact is that 1982-83 was the first year of negative growth in 30 years and factories were lying idle right across the economy. We are now using that capacity up to capacity utilisation. Obviously, as we have indicated in the case of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, we have seen a 25 per cent increase in steel exports coming off a given level of capacity. No doubt we will see full capacity utilisation and investment where necessary. Also, within that investment forecast, there will be a topping off and a decline in the non-building construction sector over the year and that will be replaced by other investment synonymous with the investment forecasts in the Budget. No doubt some of that investment will be in other sectors of the economy as well as in the non-residential construction area.

ANSWER.PARA: The essential and fundamental restructuring of the economy which is now taking place, the rebuilding of our import competing structure, a better net export performance and the winning of export markets by the supercompetitiveness of the Australian economy at this time will produce obviously a great incentive to invest here. In his question, the honourable member mentioned the obvious impact upon financial markets of this massive decline in the public sector borrowing requirement. The fact that for the first time in memory the Commonwealth Government will have no new treasury bond raisings this year, that the whole program will essentially be a roll-over of the maturities program and the decline of $2.2 billion in absolute terms in the public sector borrowing requirement will reduce public demands upon Australian financial markets and savings, leaving those savings to be taken up by the Australian investment community. I have no doubt, because of rational decisions it will take looking at its best interests and the opportunities available in the economy, that that investment will be taken up and, as I say, I think exceeded in the terms of the outcome over the course of the year.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer to the criticism of some commentators that the Government's approach to wages policy presented in last night's Budget is too soft for current economic circumstances. Is this criticism of the Government's centralised wage fixing system a valid one?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. The quick and short answer is no, but I will add to that. In the pathetic situation in which the Opposition-and particularly its leader-finds itself, in the aftermath of a Budget which has been almost universally acknowledged as responsible and effective--
—Order!

—I will not take up the three-quarters of an hour available to me by going through all the quotes; instead I will content myself with a couple. The pithiest, most accurate and most concise was in an editorial in the Australian Financial Review which gave this five word summary:

ANSWER.PARA: That is absolutely spot on. I do not think the pathetic crew opposite would suggest that the next quote has come from a really radical organisation. It is from the Australian Bankers Association, which said:
A strong response to the current economic conditions. This firm action in the fiscal area will ease pressure on monetary policy and work towards a reduction in interest rates.

Again, that is absolutely accurate. In this situation where the Opposition finds itself deserted, bereft and alone one looks to see where it is at its most pathetic and, of course, one finds it in what Opposition members have to say about wages.

When I appeared in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation studio this morning I was followed by the Leader of the Opposition. I did not prompt the comment of the person there, but as I left and the Leader of the Opposition came in that person said quite gratuitously, but quite accurately, to the Leader of the Opposition: `That is the only seat of the Prime Minister that you will ever be occupying.' I may say to the very effective and very honourable Minister for Communications that, after seeing what intelligent and perceptive people are employed by the ABC, we might have to have another look at the Corporation's funding. In his pathetic peregrination around the studio this morning the Leader of the Opposition had the temerity to talk about the fact that the comparison in wages outcome under this Government with the international sector was `pathetic'. Let us look at page 40 of Budget Statement No. 1 on which there is a very interesting table. On that page there are international comparisons of average earnings. This is what we saw in the last year of the stewardship and irresponsibility of the then Treasurer. What was the comparison? Let me give it to honourable members. In 1982 the movement in earnings for the major Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development trading partners was 6.5 per cent, while in Australia it was 16.5 per cent-154 per cent higher. Last year for the OECD countries it was 4.6 per cent and in Australia it was 6.2 per cent. In other words the differential has been brought down from that massive 154 per cent under Mr Howard to 35 per cent under us.

Let us look at what has happened in terms of real earnings in this country in the past three years, compared with what has happened with three of our major competitors. In Australia there has been a 5 per cent decline in real earnings. As the Treasurer quite properly put it in his brilliant Budget Speech last night, one of the basic reasons why we have been able to get massive economic growth and high employment growth is the general responsibility of the trade union movement in this country under the prices and incomes accord. In a situation where we have had an average annual rate of growth of between 4 and 5 per cent in non-farm gross domestic product, because of the responsibility of the trade union movement we have had a 5 per cent decline in earnings.

While we had a 5 per cent decline in earnings, the United States of America has a one per cent decline in earnings. What has happened in the United Kingdom? The United Kingdom was held up last night by one United States commentator as the role model. He said that we should look at that golden land of the United Kingdom to see what sort of wages policy we should have. In terms of real wages in the past three years, the United Kingdom had 13 per cent unemployment and a 10 per cent increase in real earnings, while Japan had a 5 per cent increase in real earnings. That is the relative outcome.
In relation to real unit labour costs, I read to the House from page 59 of the Budget Papers:
Real unit labour costs in the non-farm sector fell by 1 per cent in 1985-86, bringing the cumulative fall since 1982-83 to over 7 per cent; a further 1 per cent fall is forecast for 1986-87.

The tragedy is not simply that the Opposition will not learn from its culpable negligence in 1982 but-shame heaped upon shame-it promises more of the same. The Opposition will get rid of the accord which has produced a 5 per cent decline in real earnings. What will it bring back? Exactly the same system it had in 1982 which gave a 16.5 per cent increase in earnings while the rest of the world was trailing with a 6.5 per cent increase. The Opposition was an abysmal failure when it was in government and, because it has not learnt, it is even worse, unimaginably so, in opposition than it was in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to his Government's former ban on uranium exports to France and the Treasurer's admission that this ban `failed to serve a useful purpose'. Given the parlous condition of our balance of payments and our export sector, will the Government remove other bans on uranium exports which are also serving no useful purpose? Will the Prime Minister give the House an unequivocal assurance that, whatever the Caucus might decide, the Government will keep the Budget promise to scrap the ban on uranium exports to France?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will answer fully the question put to me by the Leader of the Opposition, but let me say at the outset that no one is more conscious that I am--

—Honourable members opposite may well laugh at the concerns of the young people of this country, but they will laugh to their great detriment at the very legitimate concerns that the young people of this country have about the dangers of nuclear war. This Government understands those concerns. We made a decision in 1983, which we gave effect to in 1984, because we hoped that the suspension of the sale of uranium to France may play some part in persuading France to cease its nuclear testing in the Pacific. That was a legitimate hope and we took that decision in the understanding of the very real and legitimate concerns felt by many people, particularly the young people in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: We have found in fact that, although we have made the most persistent representations to the Government of France, that has made no difference, and in light of the circumstances confronting us in this Budget we decided that it was no longer appropriate to continue that process. The effect on France of the ban was that we inflicted a penalty on it of forcing it to buy uranium cheaper on the spot market than it could have under the contractual arrangements. It seemed no longer sensible for us to continue that policy. Let me say that I will ensure that every relevant Minister-myself, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Minister for Trade and every other Minister who has contact with France after the resumption of sales-will take every opportunity to continue to put to the Government of France the opposition of this Government to nuclear testing.

Having said that, let me say this as to the budgetary impact of the decision we have taken: Because of the fact that sales will be resumed, the net positive result in terms of the Budget will be $66.4m. If one looks at what the position will be in terms of our balance of payments in the years ahead, it is reasonable to assume that Australia may get up to something like $200m per year in current terms through the 1990s.

Let me make the position quite clear in regard to safeguards. While France is not a party to the Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, in terms of safeguards it has a commitment to behave exactly as those states which have signed the Treaty, and has done so. The safeguards agreements which are in place have established a framework for assurance that, in accordance with Australia's nuclear safeguards policy requirements, Australian origin nuclear material exported to France remains in peaceful use.

Madam Speaker, as you know, as Australia knows and as the International Atomic Energy Agency knows, Australia has the most stringent safeguard requirements in the world and on safeguard grounds there is confidence about selling uranium to France. Nuclear safeguards on Australian origin nuclear material in France are applied under the Australia-France and the Australia-European Atomic Energy Community nuclear safeguards agreements.

I notice that in some quarters it has been alleged that Australian nuclear material has been used in the French weapons program, either in the Super Phoenix fast breeder reactor program or indirectly after the reprocessing of spent fuel. Those allegations are incorrect, as the Super Phoenix reactor is operated for peaceful purposes as part of a European program of co-operation in breeder development for peaceful purposes. No Australian uranium has been used in Super Phoenix; no Australian uranium has been reprocessed by France. If it had been, it could only be used for peaceful purposes under the safeguards agreement.

I repeat that the decision of this Government was taken in good faith in the first place. It served no purpose in terms of producing the result that we still want to achieve; that is, the cessation of French nuclear testing in the South Pacific. I repeat that I, the Foreign Minister and all relevant Ministers at every opportunity will continue to put to the people of France that they should desist from nuclear testing in the South Pacific.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Would the Prime Minister table the document from which he read?
—No, the Prime Minister will not.
—Was the Prime Minister reading from a public or confidential document?
—A confidential document.

—Has the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs noted media reports about the case of a 13-year-old Vietnamese boy, Nguyen Phi, with a terminal malignant illness who is seeking the urgent entry of his parents from Vietnam? Have there been any developments with this case?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do know of this case. It has drawn a great deal of sympathy in the community. I cannot altogether get away from the good news of the Budget because I can report to the House that it was brought to my attention by my friend, the Chairman of the Special Broadcasting Service, Sir Nicholas Shehadie. Like Sir Nicholas and the Government, I have a great commitment not only to ethnic radio and television but also to the greater security and the good fortune of the SBS, so much so that when Sir Nicholas drew this to my attention I immediately followed through in spite of the fact that he learned about it from the Mike Willesee show.

ANSWER.PARA: Having learned about it myself in that way I want now to tell the House that the sad story relates to this young 13-year-old boy who arrived in Australia in the care of an aunt as long ago as September 1981. He has a malignant tumour and a life expectancy of only up to one year. I understand that his parents have been sponsored for some time to come to this country but, hitherto, were not able to receive an exit permit from Vietnam. The night before last I was able to see the Vietnamese Charge d'Affaires, and I pay tribute to the prompt action of the Vietnamese Embassy. It has now secured an exit permit for the boy's mother and father, and I am hopeful that he will be reunited with his parents within the next few months.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to the detailed answer he gave to my previous question on uranium exports. I again ask the Prime Minister: Given the parlous condition of our balance of payments in the export sector, will the Government undertake to remove other bans on Australian uranium exports which are also, like the French ban, serving no useful purpose?

—If the Leader of the Opposition knew anything about the subject he would know that there were particular circumstances regarding the export to France concerning Queensland Mines Ltd and that what was involved there was an outlay of Commonwealth funds to Queensland Mines because of an existing contract with France. There is no comparison between that and any other area of the existing or potential uranium industry in Australia.

—Will the Minister for Science inform the House of the Budget implications for the Commission for the Future in restructuring our economy? Will he tell the House of the implications of a policy advocated by the Leader of the Opposition-the man who is so far behind that he thinks he is coming first-of scrapping this important initiative?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Budget allocation for the Commission for the Future for its second establishment year will be increased from $623,000 to $936,000-a rise of 50.5 per cent-taking the organisation to a plateau with a staff allocation of 10. I should add that the Victorian Government has provided a senior officer at no cost to the Commonwealth. The Western Australian Government is proposing to do the same.
—A positive step.

—It is regarded as good value by the States, and I hope that other States will follow suit. Expenditure for 1986-87 will comprise 0.16 per cent, less than one-sixth of one per cent, of the allocation for my Department-so let us not get it out of proportion. The Commission is already filling a major gap in community understanding by providing information and education about changes in science and technology which have profound, rapid and wide-ranging social and economic implications. The Commission is hoping to establish an innovative and productive culture for Australia by working with a variety of community and business organisations. It has been used by instrumentalities from every State-
—Tasmania?

—Including Tasmania, Queensland and the Northern Territory, and it is producing publications for unions, parliamentary committees and business organisations. Substantial publishing, seminar and media programs will be completed in 1986-87. A Clearing House in Future Issues has been established. The Commission will be carrying out a major program entitled `Futures and Education' for the Bicentennial Authority over the next three years.

ANSWER.PARA: It would be difficult to point to another place where $900,000 of government money is being better invested in helping re-orient Australia's business management, education systems and employee organisations towards re-thinking national positions about the future. The Commission was set up to encourage Australians to accept the challenge provided by computer technology and the advent of the `information society', and it is now in its first full year of establishment. We cannot afford not to raise debate in the work force, in our schools, in our Parliament and in our board rooms about the need to develop that new Australian culture, to pull ourselves by the bootstraps out of what is clearly an economic and social crisis.

The Commission for the Future is more than paying its way. The Leader of the Opposition is a political amnesiac. He cannot remember anything about the past. For example, he cannot remember the projected $9.6 billion blowout of his last Budget. He cannot remember anything about that. He has no historical sense and he has absolutely no sense of or interest in a commitment to the future. His value systems are totally materialistic. He measures value only in dollar terms and he is interested only in financial year to financial year. He is capable of thinking only weeks ahead. We cannot just be thinking months ahead. We need to raise community awareness of how Australia will change between now, the year 2000 and beyond.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Treasurer a question about the more immediate future and, in doing so, I remind him of his now infamous banana republic interview on 14 May in which he said that a growth outcome of less than 3 per cent would result in an increase in unemployment. I ask the Treasurer: Now that we know the Budget predicts a total growth of only 2 1/4 per cent in this financial year what now, according to the Government, will unemployment rise to during this financial year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Budget assumptions make clear that the employment forecasts, off the gross domestic product forecasts, are for a 1.75 per cent employment growth over the course of the year. Honourable members will know that, in the last three or four years, work force growth has slowed considerably to be now well under 2 per cent. The judgment, therefore, about the unemployment rate turns upon the participation rate which, over the last year, has been at an all-time high, as high as it has ever been since the Australian Statistician has been collecting the data. That high is coming particularly from women rejoining the work force in the buoyancy of the labour market of the last couple of years and particularly last year where we saw employment growth of nearly 4 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: As the economy slows and conditions in the labour market deteriorate somewhat it is reasonable to assume that the participation rate will probably stabilise or fall and, in that context, the judgment about the movement in the participation rate is the essential judgment about where the unemployment rate will finally lay in year average terms for 1986-87. One has to understand the level at which we will key off will be the last figure for June 1986, which was 7.6 per cent. So it is a matter for judgment. The number of unemployment benefit recipients is the question in relation to Commonwealth Budget outlays. We have an increase of 36,000 there, which is effectively 46,000 as we believe that by a tightening of the procedures for unemployment benefit recipients we can reduce the figure by 10,000 to a net 36,000. In the circumstances, it will mean that the gains against unemployment-the very rapid gains, the 11 per cent employment growth over the past three years-will be somewhat eroded. But, considering the massive magnitude of the growth in employment over the past 12 months, nearly 4 per cent-and 11 per cent over the course of the past three years of the consolidation in the economy this year is entirely appropriate to the current account conditions that Australia faces. Hence the Government's satisfaction with the forecast--

TALK.START.PARA: —But what is the unemployment rate going to be?
—I gave the honourable gentleman an answer--
—Order! The honourable gentleman has asked the question and he has got the answer.
—He is thick, Madam Speaker. I told him about-
—I may be thick, but what is the unemployment rate going to be?
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.
—I am not getting an answer.
—We do not make an unemployment forecast in the Budget Papers and, from memory, there was not one made in the time of the Leader of the Opposition.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENTS OF ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, who is the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Has his attention been drawn to a recent study undertaken by Mr Brian Buckley, a former Liberal Party staffer for the Australian Institute of Public Policy, an organisation established with the efforts of a former Liberal member of Parliament, John Hyde? Does the study purport to recommend ways to save public sector expenditure in line with coalition policy? Does the study recommend the abolition of the Departments of Aboriginal Affairs and Veterans' Affairs? What would be the result of the implementation of the coalition's hidden agenda on Aboriginal and veteran Australians if this study were to be implemented?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I have seen the report. I think that all those who know Mr Hyde know that he is a man of great courage and great endeavour. He would have to be to try to provide any kind of intellectual stimulus to this pathetic group that calls itself an Opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: Nevertheless, the importance of the study lies in the fact that the Opposition continually demeans on every possible occasion all those employees in the public sector. It never stops saying that the simple way of solving our economic problems is to dismiss large areas of the public sector and abolish departments. That is its position. It is like its position on privatisation. Opposition members all support privatisation until such time as we ask them: `What are you going to privatise?' If the Opposition is saying that it is a simple exercise in abolishing departments in the Public Service, that is a position, but it is about time the Leader of the Opposition and his relevant shadow Ministers told us just what departments they want to abolish. Does the shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs, who I think people say has some real commitment to veterans in this society, support the view that the Department of Veterans' Affairs ought to be abolished? Is he prepared to stand up in this chamber and adopt the hidden agenda which links into the Opposition's generalised approach? Is the shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs prepared--

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not certain whether it is the honourable member for the Northern Territory or the gentleman who--
—Wilson Tuckey?
—Well, it is not Wilson Tuckey. The position is this: Veterans and Aboriginal people in Australia are entitled to know that when this Government talks about abolishing--
—The Government?

—The Government. These documents are out. They are public; they are circulated and they cause considerable anguish in various levels of the community. They are not repudiated by the Leader of the Opposition, nor are they repudiated by shadow spokesmen. The people of Australia are entitled to know what the Opposition's alternative criteria are.
—Oh, come on.

—The honourable gentleman had better not wave his hand at me, otherwise the shadow Attorney-General will have a go at him. I believe it is time that the Opposition had the integrity either to say `Yes, that is our policy' or publicly to repudiate it through its purported shadow spokesman.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Prime Minister that the market is somewhat sceptical about the $3.5 billion deficit figure in the light of the Prime Minister's commitment in his 1984 policy speech, part of which read:

QUESTION.PARA: The trilogy will be met in the first year, 1985-86. The tax commitment is certainly for each year.

If the trilogy had not been ditched this year and last year, would tax collections have been $400m lower in 1985-86 and $1,400m lower in 1986-87? As the Prime Minister's credibility is about as dramatically devalued as the dollar, will he advise the House of the status of this current undertaking?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I made it clear at the time that this Government imposed upon itself the historic discipline of the trilogy that should drastic changes in economic circumstances occur which required an appropriate stance of policy, that stance would be taken. Let me make it clear in regard to the trilogy that the two legs of it concerning reductions in outlays and proportion of gross domestic product and the deficit as a proportion of GDP have been more than met. They have been very substantially met. Aggregate taxation receipts in 1985-86 were slightly less than the budgeted levels. Had the nominal GDP anticipated at the time of the Budget formulation in 1985 met that expectation, the expectations in regard to the trilogy limit would have been satisfied not only on Budget night but also as an outcome. In the event, as is made quite clear in the Budget Papers, the planned limit has been exceeded.

ANSWER.PARA: I make it quite clear that it remains our objective to reduce tax receipts to 25 per cent of GDP. That is the trilogy limit. However, we made the deliberate decision in the circumstances of this Budget formulation that the more important priority in the interests of the whole community was to reduce the Budget deficit to the level of $3.5 billion. I just make the point that, even with the decisions that we have taken, and making the adjustment for change in the method of financing health care, tax receipts are a lower share of the GDP in the Budget than the peak that was reached under the Treasurership of Mr Howard. If we turn to page 358 of Budget Paper No. 1, we see that tax as a proportion of GDP in 1981-82 was 24.7 per cent. If we adjust the 25.5 per cent for 1986-87 for the financing of Medicare, it comes out at 24.6 per cent. It is the indisputable fact that the peak of tax as a proportion of GDP was achieved under the Treasurership of Mr Howard. Finally, on the question of the tax outcome, I remind the House again of what I pointed out to it at the end of the previous session when the question of tax achievement under Mr Howard was admitted by him. I will read what he said on 8 November 1983, and honourable members should remember that the former Government had seven and a half years to do something about reducing tax as a proportion of GDP. In November 1983, speaking of his own former Government, he said this:
left office, taxation as a proportion of the gross domestic product was higher than it was as a proportion of GDP in 1975.

That is a correct statement, it is there for all to see and I cannot dispute it. In other words, they had seven and a half years to reduce taxation as a proportion of GDP and when they went out of office after seven and a half years it was higher than when they came in. That is what they did in 7 1/2 years of office. Fortunately, they will not be given another chance to devastate the Australian economy.

—I wish to make a personal explanation.
— Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do, indeed-twice.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—I was first of all misrepresented by the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins). During the course of answering a question from his own side, the Minister for Trade said that I had not in any way commented upon or dis- sociated myself from remarks apparently made in a letter by the West Australian Liberal member, Mr Lightfoot. The reality is that I received only one inquiry about my position regarding Mr Lightfoot from the Press and I indicated that I certainly did not share Mr Lightfoot's views. I can only say in the House that his views on this issue would be repudiated by every member of the Liberal and National parties who sits in this Parliament. It raises a fascinating new concept of political responsibility to suggest that the national leader of a political party is responsible for each and every act. I would like to know whether the Prime Minister dissociates himself from every remark made by Joan Coxsedge, George Crawford or Frank Walker or, indeed, from the comments made on uranium by people in his own party. As far as I am concerned, this is a new concept from the Minister for Trade: If some character makes a remark, we have to run around dissociating ourselves from it. I make it perfectly plain to the Minister for Trade where I stand.
