The House ought to remember that the joint all-party delegation went to Washington as a result of an initiative by the Deputy Leader of the National Party (Mr Hunt). If it had not been for him, that initiative would not have got off the ground.
—Order! The honourable gentleman will stick to where he claims to be misrepresented. If the Deputy Leader of the National Party wishes to say something, that is a matter for him.
—I am prepared to take responsibility for him.
—I do not think the honourable gentleman has to do that.
—He is a very honourable man.
—What about Malcolm? Will you take responsibility for him?

—On many issues, I will. The even more grievous misrepresentation came from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). A new version of creative accounting was unveiled this afternoon. Whenever an historical Budget figure does not suit the Prime Minister, he goes back over it and he says--
—Order! Will the honourable gentleman get to where he claims to be misrepresented?

—I have to, because otherwise honourable members might not be certain which of the misrepresentations I am referring to. It relates to the comparative taxation records of the former Government and the present Government. To the eternal embarrassment of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) last night, and of the Prime Minister today, page 358 of this year's Budget Papers reveals the fact that the highest level of taxation receipts recorded under any government in peacetime was recorded in the Budget brought down by the Treasurer last night. All the creative accounting and all the Prime Minister's attempts to say that if we leave out one or two departments we look better, do not wash with this Parliament or with the Australian public. Whatever he says, he and the Treasurer are the biggest taxing Prime Minister and Treasurer that this country has ever seen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker, twice.
—The honourable gentleman may proceed.

—I have been seriously misrepresented twice. The first misrepresentaton-published in today's Mercury-is attributed to Senator Tate, Labor, who, I am told, is from Tasmania. Senator Tate is quoted as accusing me of engaging in `puerile political posturing' when I forewarned at the weekend of massive cuts in the freight equalisation scheme to the detriment of all Tasmanians. The figures speak for themselves.
—This is not a personal explanation.

—Yes, it is. In the past two years the Hawke socialist Government has cut the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme by a total of over 12 per cent, putting in jeopardy the jobs of up to 2,000 Tasmanians.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, and again in today's Mercury, Senator Grimes seriously misrepresented me by claiming that my statement that 2,000 Tasmanian jobs would be lost was `absolute nonsense'. Senator Grimes's remarks relate to my prediction at the weekend that Commonwealth spending in Tasmania would be cut by at least $40m in `Tuesday's Budget'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman knows that he can indicate only where he was misrepresented.
—That is right. I was about to. I have only one sentence to go.
—Will the honourable gentleman tell the House where he was misrepresented?

—I am telling you. I have tried to go quickly to save time and I had only one sentence to go. I said that Senator Grimes's remarks related to my prediction at the weekend that Commonwealth spending in Tasmania would be cut by at least $40m in `Tuesday's Budget', I was wrong. Commonwealth spending in Tasmania was cut by a massive $61m in last night's hate Tasmania, Keating Budget.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.PRESENTERS: ADERMANN; BRUMBY; BURR; COLEMAN; CONQUEST; DOBIE; DOWNER; FIFE; FISCHER; HALL; HALVERSON; HAWKER; HICKS; HOLLIS; HUMPHREYS; LLOYD; MCGAURAN; MARTIN; MILDREN; MILLAR; MILTON; REITH; ROBINSON; SAUNDERSON; SHACK et al.
PETITION.TITLE: Post Offices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that many post office agencies are to be closed. They provide a network of offices with postal and agency services to residential areas and small communities.

They serve a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced if forced to travel further to purchase postal items or collect parcels. It would be an unnecessary expense particularly for pensioners without their own transport.

We maintain that the purpose of Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer. They are a community centre particularly in country areas and if necessary they should be subsidised to retain them.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of post office agencies and that the network should be extended, with the Agency services they offer expanded.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Adermann,Mr Brumby,Mr Burr,Mr Coleman,Mr Conquest,Mr Dobie,Mr Downer,Mr Fife,Mr Tim Fischer,Mr Steele Hall,Mr Halverson,Mr Hawker,Mr Hicks,Mr Hollis,Mr Humphreys,Mr Lloyd,Mr McGauran,Mr Martin,Mr Mildren,Mr Millar,Mr Milton,Mr Reith,Mr Ian Robinson,Mr Saunderson,Mr Shack,Mr Shipton,Mr Snow and Mr Wilson.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BEALE; BRUMBY; FISCHER; HALVERSON; HAWKER; MILTON; SAUNDERSON; WILLIS
PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Graduated family allowances are of important assistance to families with more than one child.
All family allowances, whether for one, two, three, or more children, have not kept pace with inflation.
There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.
There are also suggestions that the dependent spouse rebate be reduced or removed. This would represent another blow to the family unit.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should:
ask the Federal Government to increase the value of existing family allowance payments, and
reject any moves to change the payments to a flat rate or to tamper with the spouse rebate;
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Brumby,Mr Tim Fischer,Mr Halverson,Mr Hawker,Mr Milton,Mr Saunderson and Mr Willis.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That families have been gravely disadvantaged by a serious decline in the level of their net disposable income through:
Failure to index family allowances-resulting in a 50% loss in their real value since 1976
Abolition of family allowances for dependants who have turned 18-even those still at school
Failure to increase the spouse rebate since 1982
Discriminatory taxation system-which penalizes single income families.
Recognising the cost benefit to taxpayers when the intact family unit itself delivers essential care to the extended family.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Government take immediate action to:
Restore the lost value of family allowances and to index them to cover future price rises
Introduce optional income-splitting for taxation purposes
Retain the spouse rebate.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr John Brown and Mr Coleman.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation Measures: Effects on Families
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That taxpayers with dependent children have been gravely disadvantaged by a serious decline in the level of recognition provided in the taxation system for the costs of maintaining a family, in particular:
the failure to index family allowances which has resulted in an erosion of more than 50% in their real value since May 1976;
the abolition of family allowances for dependents who have turned 18, even those still at school;
the abolition of concessional tax rebates for education and other expenses.

That this erosion in horizontal tax equity has placed an intolerable financial burden on many larger families, particularly those on middle incomes who fail to qualify for means-tested benefits such as TEAS but whose living standards are now well below average due to heavy expenses on necessities such as education, housing, food and clothing.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:
family allowances be restored to the 1976 value (in real terms), and indexed according to the CPI;
the dependent spouse rebate be retained;
the Federal Government take urgent measures to restore equitable provisions in the taxation system through the introduction of family income splitting.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Halverson and Mr McGauran.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Tasmania respectfully showeth:
1. We are concerned by media statements that the Government intends to restructure the family allowance payment in a form that will reduce its assistance to families.
2. Remind the Government that the family allowance payment is not a Social Security payment as such but a replacement payment for a tax rebate once enjoyed by families for their responsibilities.
3. Whereas the tax rebate would be indexed to the CPI the present family allowance has lost real monetary value since 1976. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that:
(i) The family allowance payment be indexed to the CPI.
(ii) That there be no adverse adjustments to family allowance payments in the 1986/87 Budget.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned plead that the Parliament implement pro-family policies. In particular we appeal for:
1. the retention of the present graduated assessment system for payment of the Family Allowance;
2. indexation of the Family Allowance in order to keep pace with inflation;

3. an increase of 3.7% in the Family Allowance benefit to return it to 11.5% of the Average Award Wage (making it similar in value to the 11.5% of the Basic Wage when Child Endowment was first introduced by the Chifley Government in 1941).
4. retention of the Dependent Spouse Rebate and the amount of the Dependent Spouse Rebate adjusted so that it is equal in value to the tax-free threshold allowed when calculating taxable income.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BLANCHARD; HOLLIS; KENT; MCHUGH; MILTON; SAUNDERSON; SCOTT; TICKNER
PETITION.NAMEIDS: UE4; DH4; PH4; ZH4; DI4; 2J4; 7J4; RJ4
PETITION.TITLE: Radioactive Substances and Irradiation of Food
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth we most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blanchard,Mr Hollis,Mr Kent,Ms McHugh,Mr Milton,Mr Saunderson,Mr Scott and Mr Tickner.

PETITION.TITLE: Prescription Drugs for Pensioners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
1. We the undersigned are totally opposed to the introduction of a $2.00 fee on prescription drugs for pensioners;
2. The impact of such a fee will be particularly felt by the chronically ill elderly who will be faced with a $2.00 burden with the purchase of each Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme drug;
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Ensure that prescription drugs continue to be provided to the pensioner population without the $2.00 fee on each prescription.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt,Mr Conquest,Mr Halverson and Mr Shack.

PETITION.TITLE: Prescription Drugs for Pensioners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That we the undersigned are totally opposed to the introduction of any fees for prescription drugs for pensioners;
(2) That the recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) to introduce ``concessional user status'' for pensioners would lead to confusion.

Your petitioners therefore urge the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to ensure that prescription drugs continue to be provided to the pensioner population free of charge.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: First International Earth Repair Year
PETITION.PARA: For 1988 to be proclaimed the ``First International Earth Repair Year'' (FIERY) as a vital action to ignite global co-operation for Worldpeace and as an international aspect of the Australian Bicentenary.
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That deterioration of the total global environment is continuing at an increasing rate; that important environmental resources vital to human livelihood such as trees, soil and water are decreasing at an alarming rate; that there is a need for educating all people to assume a greater responsibility for the conservation, sustainable use and maintenance of vital resources; that dynamic and active initiatives are needed to conserve and renew the total environment; and that protecting, conserving and repairing the Earth can unite all people and nations in co-operative action for survival.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government will propose to the United Nations General Assembly at its 41st Session in September 1986 that 1988 be proclaimed the ``First International Earth Repair Year''.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt,Mr Humphreys,Mr Nehl and Mr Tickner.

PETITION.TITLE: Film Censorship Board
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

We, the undersigned, plead that Parliament will legislate, or act in accordance with the present legislation to replace the current members of the Film Censorship Board who have admitted to Senator Harradine on 12th December 1984 as reported in the Senate Select Committee on Video Material, (see attached extracts), that they are not applying either the blasphemy or obscenity tests as required under the provisions of the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations, and that these persons be replaced by persons who will apply these and the other related test in accordance with the said Regulations. Your petitioners humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest consideration.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blanchard,Mr Downer,Mr Steele Hall and Mr Shack.

PETITION.TITLE: Changes to Veterans' Entitlements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that persistent rumours suggest that the Hawke Government intends to reduce Government expenditure by contracting or eliminating programs for war veterans and war widows.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment and that of previous Governments to ex-servicemen and women by:
Ensuring no additional cut-backs will be made to the portfolio of Veterans' Affairs.
Review the previous cut-backs in such areas as the travel allowances, dental scheme and repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme.
Proceed with abolishing more stringent conditions applying to the granting of the TPI pension.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt,Mr Halverson and Mr Hicks.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce divisions in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will propose and pass a motion that `the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Harry Edwards,Mr Hawker and Mr Reith.

PETITION.TITLE: Second Language Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:
We the undersigned residents of Australia totally reject any move to cut funding to Australia-wide English as a second language program in schools.
We request that the Australian Government restore funding to the 1985 level in the 1986-87 Budget.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Baldwin and Ms McHugh.

PETITION.TITLE: Housing-related Poverty
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of citizens of Australia shows that-
Approximately 100,000 Australians live on the verge of homelessness, dependent on Government resources to survive, or sleep out of doors or in refuges.
Over 700,000 households, or in excess of 2 million Australians are living below the poverty line after paying their rent or mortgage costs.
In addition, there are thousands of households with special needs, such as the disabled, who are not well catered for in the private sector but who nevertheless require suitable housing.
Waiting lists for public housing have almost doubled in the past five years to 146,000 by June 1985. The list is expected to grow to some 250,000 by 1990.
We therefore ask that the Australian Government, as a highest priority-
Undertake a campaign to bring the issue of poverty and, in particular, housing-related poverty, to the attention of the Australian public.
Increase expenditure on public housing through the Commonwealth State Housing Agreement, by at least 15% annually in real terms.
Increase rent relief payments for those on low incomes in the private rental market.
Use its influence with State and Territory governments to encourage them to increase their expenditures on public housing.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blanchard and Mr Tickner.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the failure of the Government to honour its election promises to pensioners.
In particular those promises relate to the following commitments:
1. That within three years of its election to office, a Hawke Labor Government would raise the level of the standard pension to 25% of average weekly earnings.
2. That the lag time between the announcement of the Consumer Price Index figures and the subsequent adjustment of pensions would be reduced to one month, and
3. That the disproportionate tax burden borne by low income earners would be lifted.
None of these promises has been honoured to date.

Your petitioners are extremely angry at the failure of the Government to live up to its commitments and as in duty bound will ever pray that these serious omissions will be given the attention they deserve.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Duncan and Dr Harry Edwards.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows that the Hawke Government should:
1. Pass on the full benefit of lower international oil prices
2. Not increase or extend fuel taxes; and
3. Maintain its tax cut commitments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment to the Import Parity Pricing policy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hawker and Mr Tuckey.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag;
2. We are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
The Union Jack-itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses-represents the nation's historical origin, and the source of its language and law.
The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. We know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. We recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. We are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that `the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: South African Embassy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the failure of the Government to address itself to the injustices perpetrated by the South African Government.

To bring further international pressure and condemnation on the vicious regime of the Botha Government, the petitioners urgently ask that immediate action be taken to close the South African Embassy in Canberra until such time as apartheid in South Africa is fully dismantled.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the Bill of Rights is not supported by the people of Australia, and calls on the Government to:
Delay proclamation of the Bill until all matters of contention are settled by national referenda, and that:
(1) Matters of States rights, property rights, rights of the newborn, the right not to belong to unions, among other issues, have not been submitted to the people of Australia to decide, and that;
(2) No Australian Bill of Rights should depend on any foreign convention for its basis in Australian law.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That, for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initiative needs to be established to work towards mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being for all and full employment. This Initiative will help to ensure a sustainable society conserving natural resources, and revitalising soils essential for growing a plentiful and healthy food supply and tree cover for the needs of present and future generations. By working for these objectives, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will:
1. Propose to the United Nations General Assembly that 1989 be declared International Year for Repairing the Earth.
2. Implement action programs leading up to 1989 which will include:
(a) Actively supporting the International Year of Peace in 1986 by reallocating at least 10% of our military expenditure to fund environmental repair programs.

(b) Implementing National Recycling Programs to reuse water, and to compost into hygienic humus all presently wasted organic garbage and sewage-sludge mixed with fine ground powder from mineral-rich gravels and rocks, to use as a natural fertiliser in revitalising impoverished soils;

(c) Developing National Employment Programs giving priority to the planting and growing of healthy forests, food-producing trees and other crops and vegetation including environmentally sound use and reuse of water to assist the greening of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Prescription Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia calls on the Commonwealth Government to recognise that the imposition of a charge on the prescription of Epileptic drugs
1. is a discrimination against sufferers because of their condition
2. causes hardship to epileptics, particularly pensioners
3. is likely to cause increased hospitalisation of sufferers who cannot afford the charge and thus impose an increased cost on the hospital system
4. is contrary to the spirit of the U.N. declaration on the Rights of the Disabled and Mentally Retarded Person
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Commonwealth Government do revoke charges on the prescription of Epileptic drugs as a matter of some urgency.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That Labor's capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax, tax on lump sum superannuation and assets test are an unwarranted burden on the people of Australia, have contributed to the national economic crisis and the anomalies in the legislation are causing confusion and anger amongst all sections of the Australian community.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of Labor's Assets Test, Labor's Capital Gains Tax, Labor's Fringe Benefit tax and Labor's tax on lump sum superannuation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament House.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Bill of Rights is a dangerous piece of legislation which gives us no new legally enforceable rights;
That the Bill of Rights leaves out vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property, the right to a private education;
That the Bill of Rights gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission to investigate in private, without legal representation and with criminal penalties for refusing to co-operate;
That the Bill of Rights deals with our rights; therefore we, the people, should say whether we want it by a referendum.

Your petitioners humbly pray that you repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Page electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government's Bill of Rights seeks to make changes in the constitutional balance in Australia by intruding into the affairs of individuals and of State and Local Governments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:

Repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Bill of Rights is a dangerous piece of legislation which gives us no new legally enforceable rights;
That the Bill of Rights leaves out vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property, the right to a private education;
That the Bill of Rights gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission to investigate in private, without legal representation and with criminal penalties for refusing to co-operate;
That the Bill of Rights deals with our rights; therefore we, the people, should say whether we want it by a referendum.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will oppose the Bill of Rights, support Liberal amendments to improve it in case it is passed, and pledge to repeal it should it become law.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the many anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions brought to its notice, the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identification Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
This petition of Riverina residents shows that we vigorously oppose the introduction of the `Australia Card' or any form of compulsory identity cards.
We believe that the introduction of identity cards will erode civil liberties; will create an increased risk of invasion of privacy.
We believe that the above Bill seeks to alter the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act which can only be altered by a properly conducted Referendum.
We call on the Parliament to immediately reject any proposals for the introduction of compulsory identity cards.

PETITION.TITLE: Identification Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the proposed introduction of compulsory identification (ID) cards should be reconsidered and rejected because the system:
(a) is not a cost-effective method of reducing tax evasion and social security fraud and, to the contrary, in the form proposed will facilitate such evasion and fraud;
(b) will constitute an unwarranted infringement of individual privacy by the aggregation of a wide variety of personal information of a private nature;
(c) will cause a further large and costly growth in the bureaucracy and burden on the taxpayer; and
(d) cannot be guaranteed against misuse for purposes other than for which their introduction is stated to be intended and in fact provide the opportunity for blackmail and other forms of misuse.
And your petitioners humbly pray that the problems which identification cards are intended to reduce should be attacked by other, more effective and less obnoxious methods.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia shows:

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Medicare Office, Wyong, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the fact that the lack of a Medicare Office in Wyong is seriously inconveniencing the residents of Wyong Shire.
Your petitioners therefore request that a Medicare Office is established in Wyong as soon as possible.

PETITION.TITLE: Cost of Ski Lift Tickets: Snowy Mountains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the high cost of ski lift tickets imposed during winter by the operators of resorts within the Snowy Mountains of Australia. Your petitioners below believe the Snowy Mountains are an asset for all Australians to enjoy and should be within the financial reach of all and not just the wealthy few. Your petitioners therefore request that the Parliament take action to reduce the cost of ski lift tickets imposed by the operators of resorts within the Snowy Mountains.

PETITION.TITLE: Illawarra Planetarium Project
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously urge, for the sake of economic development of the Illawarra region, the Federal Ministers Mr Brown and Mr Willis to recommend funding of the Illawarra Planetarium Project, as recommended to them by the Government of the state of New South Wales.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to ensure that the Illawarra Planetarium project receives sufficient funding to proceed as planned.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia pray that:

1. That the Commonwealth Government increase the monies allocated to the Victorian State Government for road funding, so as to allow adequate funding for the construction and maintenance of roads within the Shire of Cranbourne.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pony Club Incomes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we the undersigned are totally opposed to the Government's policy to tax pony club income.
Your petitioners urge the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to allow tax exempt status for pony clubs.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Gold Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in parliament assembled.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia, electors of the Division of Calare shows-
The proposed gold tax will severely affect the livelihood of numerous people involved in the exploration, mining and service divisions of the gold mining industry in this district.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the proposed gold tax not be introduced.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That whereas the Federal Government has imposed the Fringe Benefits Tax, such a tax will increase inflationary pressures, lead to a net loss in employment, will add significant cost and time burdens to business in this country and is in every sense an inequitable taxation measure.
The following people in the State of Tasmania therefore urge the Federal Parliament to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Additional Nuclear Reactor at Lucas Heights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That they oppose the construction of any additional nuclear reactor at the Australian Atomic Energy Establishment at Lucas Heights in N.S.W.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government of Australia will not construct an additional nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Lucas Heights Nuclear Reactor
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That in the wake of the Chernobyl reactor disaster, no nuclear reactor can be considered entirely safe.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government close down the Lucas Heights reactors immediately and permanently, and that no new nuclear reactors be built within Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Weapons in Australian Ports
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, believing
that Australia should not host nuclear weapons in its territory or in Australian waters; and
that the presence of nuclear-armed warships makes a priority nuclear target of ports being visited; and
that the safety precautions for handling and deployment of nuclear weapons are inadequate to guarantee safety from accidents; and

that the following warships, all capable of launching nuclear weapons deployed in the British or United States navies, will be visiting Sydney between 29 September to 13 October-HMS Illustrious, HMS Beaver, HMS Fort Grange, HMS Manchester, HMS Amazon, HMS Olmeda, USS Missouri, USS Paul F. Foster, USS Oldendorf; and
that these warships capable of carrying nuclear weapons will be participating in the 75th Anniversary of the Royal Australian Navy
We therefore call upon the Australian Government to:
prohibit the entry of nuclear weapons to Australia; and to
deny access to Australian ports of foreign warships unless an assurance is received that they are not carrying nuclear weapons; and to
require that foreign warships participating in the anniversary of the Royal Australian Navy not be carrying nuclear weapons in Australian territorial waters.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Republic
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
Take the action necessary to create an Australian Republic on or before 1st January, 1988.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Weapons Tests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
And, to the Australian Government.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that a comprehensive ban on all nuclear weapon tests in all environments for all time would be a vital first step towards:
Inhibiting the addition of more and more sophisticated and destabilizing nuclear weapons to the world's arsenals;
Arresting the extension of the arms race to outer space;
Upholding the provisions of existing treaties and agreements.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:

1. The Australian Government (a) take new initiatives to encourage all member states of the United Nations-especially the governments of nuclear weapon states-to conclude at an early stage a treaty banning all nuclear weapon tests in all environments for all time; (b) call on all nuclear weapon states to declare an immediate moratorium on all nuclear weapon tests pending conclusion of a CTB.
2. All federal members of parliament and senators make strong representation to the Australian Government to act towards these goals.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Western Sydney State University
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth:

That they strongly support the establishment of the Western Sydney State University as recommended in the Parry Report and call upon the House to establish the Western Sydney State University in conjunction with the New South Wales Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr John Brown,Mr Cadman and Mr Hicks.

PETITION.TITLE: Northern Rivers College of Advanced Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
There is an urgent need to upgrade and extend the facilities at the Northern Rivers College of Advanced Education.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:

Provide the necessary capital funding for the Northern Rivers CAE to ensure North Coast students have access to a tertiary institution capable of providing them with the skills they will need to meet the challenges of the future.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully request that:
The world's resources be redirected to the relief of human suffering, starvation, poverty and disease.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:

Stop spending taxpayers' money on self promotion through high cost, high profile but superficial policy on nuclear disarmament and make a genuine bi-partisan commitment to positive and practical policies designed to achieve progressive world-wide nuclear disarmament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government's Bill of Rights seeks to make changes in the constitutional balance in Australia by intruding into the affairs of individuals and of State and local governments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:

Repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt and Mr Ian Cameron.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's productivity- superannuation accord with the ACTU and its support of the superannuation claims of the trade union movement will create an imbalance in industrial power and distort the future development of the Australian economy.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject the superannuation claim of the trade union movement, and allow superannuation to develop without trade union domination.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt and Mr Ian Robinson.

PETITION.TITLE: Stud Breeding Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned stud breeders of Australia showeth:
1. Stud breeders are deeply concerned over the Federal Government's decision to create a new tax which will be most harmful to the industry.
2. If passed, the proposed tax law would cause chaos in an industry that caters for the domestic and export markets.
3. Could cause the loss of pedigreed animals in all spheres of the industry for years to come.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will:
(a) Reconsider the stud stock tax and so remove an added burden on stud breeders.
(b) Formulate policies that will de-regulate the industry and achieve an environment which caters for the depressed economy resulting from the devalued dollar.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Tasmania respectfully showeth:
1. That in its present form the Australian Bill of Rights 1985 does not represent the reasoned opinions of public opinion.
2. The Bill denies more rights than it upholds.
3. That one day's debate in the House of Representatives was insufficient time for our elected representatives to debate legislation which will control our lives indefinitely.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
(a) That the Bill lay before the House to allow reasoned debate by the electors of Australia.
(b) That our elected representatives be allowed to consider the Bill without haste.
(c) That any divisions on the Bill be recorded by a conscience vote by Members and not on Party lines.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth:
That all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable taxation deductions;
That the Hawke Government's Fringe Benefits Tax is an unwarranted burden on the small business and rural sectors, which will severely affect their long term viability.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government withdraws the Fringe Benefits Tax legislation without delay.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth:
That all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable deductions.
That the proposed Capital Gains Tax is an unwarranted burden on the rural sector, which will severely affect its long-term viability.
That the delay by the Government in introducing the legislation into Parliament is causing confusion and hindering farmers in the organisation of their affairs.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government introduces the Capital Gains Tax legislation without delay and that the Australian Democrats join with the Opposition to defeat the proposed legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Television Services to Rural Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth:
(1) That in the past, because of their remoteness, citizens in rural areas have not been able to receive SBS (Multicultural) television through conventional means.
(2) That recently those citizens have been able to receive the SBS television service from the AUSSAT satellite by means of receive-only earth stations.
(3) Now express concern that by Government decision this service is to be terminated.
Your petitioners therefore urge that SBS television continue to be made available to citizens in rural areas of Australia by means of the AUSSAT 1 satellite and receive-only earth stations.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Financial Support to Homemakers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain concerned citizens of Nathalia and district draws to the attention of the House that we demand recognition and financial support in Government policies for the millions of Australian women who choose to stay at home accepting the responsibility to strengthen the sanctity of family life which is the basic and God-given unit of society.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the above action be taken.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N.A. Brown) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to take adequate action to ensure employment growth.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We raise this matter of public importance because it gives the Opposition an opportunity to make three significant points about employment and unemployment in Australia. We do that because we believe very firmly, and we suggest that it is clear beyond any doubt, that the big sleeper in this Budget that we received last night is unemployment. If we go several months down the track, the biggest single failure of this Budget will be in exactly that field-the failure to expand employment and the inevitable increase in unemployment in this country. If we had any doubt about that, that doubt was certainly dispelled by the performance of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in Question Time today. When we gave him an opportunity to set the record straight and to make a clear and unequivocal statement on the Government's predictions for unemployment, he ran away from the question and was not prepared to put his flag to the mast on what the Government expects the rate of unemployment to be.

SPEECH.PARA: We venture to say that, when we look at all the economic tests and if one applies common sense and logic to them, the biggest single failure-there will be many of them in this Budget several months down the track-as a result of the Budget and of the economic policies now being pursued by the Government will be a higher rate of unemployment and a failure to generate the number of jobs that are needed in this country.

We will make these three points to the House today to amplify this point with respect to unemployment and the great danger that lies ahead of this country in the failure to generate jobs. But, before we put those three basic points, we can put in a nutshell the whole issue of employment and unemployment as it is faced today. The Government at the moment is telling us two things which are the basis of this whole complaint and the basis of the employment and unemployment situation.

The Government is telling us in the Budget and in all of its statements two things: The first is that our inflation rate will be 8 per cent in the course of the coming financial year and that in that financial year that rate of 8 per cent, which we know is 800 per cent greater than that of some of our trading partners and 600 per cent greater than that of other trading partners, is the rate that will exist in this country. But not only will there be an inflation rate of 8 per cent in this country in the course of this financial year; that rate of inflation will also be in the context of an economy of falling growth and shrinking trade.

That is the first thing that the Government is telling us. Having told us that, it has given us its response as to what its wages policy will be in the light of that inflation rate. So we will have an inflation rate of 8 per cent, shrinking trade and a decaying economy. What is the Government's response when asked what wages policy it will adopt in the course of this financial year? The Government's response is: `Well, add wage costs that are greater than those of our trading competitors. Do not try to erode the disadvantage that we have but look at what the wage increases are in comparable countries overseas, increase those, add some more for the claims for superannuation, do not do anything about the extravagant holiday loading and penalty rates and then let us have that awarded in the course of this financial year as our rate of wage increase in this country'. We say that, when one puts the 8 per cent inflation rate, that we know we will have, together with the Government's response that it will take the wage increases that exist in comparable trading partner countries and increase the wage expectations that will be awarded in this country, that is a formula for nothing but employment disaster in this country. That is the employment and unemployment situation in this country at this time.

But in this matter of public importance we will make three points that cover the whole field of employment and unemployment. The first is that the Government has deceived the people about the prospects for employment growth in this country. The second point is that the Government has embarked on policies that it is now pursuing and that can only reduce employment and increase unemployment in this country. The third point is that the Government's response in the programs that it is now financing to the tune of hundreds of millions of dollars is nothing more than a hotchpotch of incompetence.

So that the matter of public importance can be presented in a structured way, which we like to do, my colleague the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) will devote his remarks to demolishing the pathetic performance of the Government's training, employment and job creation programs. But, without wishing to trespass on his field, I cannot resist the temptation to inform members of the House of the Government's response in one of those programs. The Government keeps putting out handy publications to explain to people, particularly young people, how to get a job. One chart is appropriately called `The Job Hunting Game', which is what it is under the policies of this Government. In this brochure, proposition 4 in the advice to young people looking for a job is: `You slacken off and go to the beach for a few days'. I suppose that is the advice that can be given to many people under the policies of the present Government until we get a better and more responsible government in this country.

We see that the first thing that is now very clear about the employment policies of this Government is that it has deceived the people about the prospects for employment growth in Australia. To establish that deception we do not need to go back any further than four weeks ago. Four weeks ago the employment and unemployment figures for June were released. Those figures were greeted with considerable enthusiasm by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis). He looked at the unemployment rate of 7.6 per cent and he said: `Well, isn't that marvellous? What does this unemployment rate of 7.6 per cent tell us?' He leapt into print and he said: `It clearly explodes the myth perpetuated by the Federal Opposition that we are stuck at an unemployment rate of 8 per cent'. He was presented in June with an unemployment figure of 7.6 per cent and he said: `Well, that is the end of the Opposition's argument when it has tried to perpetuate this myth that the unemployment rate in Australia is stuck at around 8 per cent'.

It is true that we had given a persistent warning month after month that, if we continued with high taxes on business which stifled investment, if we continued to impose new taxes on business, if we continued to adopt high interest rate policies, if we continued to do nothing about holiday loadings and penalty rates in this country, if we maintained union power at its present extent in this country and if we did not argue in the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for full wage indexation, we would have increased unemployment. What happened? Only a matter of a few weeks later the next month's figures came out. What did they tell us about this so-called myth that the Opposition was perpetuating? They showed us that the unemployment rate had already gone up to 8.3 per cent, which is where it rests now. Of course, the Government had said: `Don't worry about this, we can hold the line'. It might have gone up to 8.3 per cent, but there is going to be unemployment growth, according to the Minister, which will hold the line. We are a bit concerned about it, but there will be employment growth, to use his own words, which would be sufficient `to hold the line on unemployment'. That line was held not a day into the present financial year until the situation that we are now presented with came about. It became very apparent to us not only that there was an increase in unemployment to 8.3 per cent, but also that the only reasonable conclusion one could reach about the future would be that there would be further increases in unemployment.

One does not have to go any further than that to show, particularly over the last month, that there has been a continued fabrication of deception by the Government as to the real underlying depth of unemployment in this country under the policies which are calculated not to generate employment in this country but to reduce it. The proof is now before us in the last unemployment figures and the proof will be seen month after month as the unemployment figures continue to be released.

Secondly, we say that the Government is now embarking upon policies which can only reduce employment and increase unemployment. Who can forget as a starting point those memorable remarks of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) only a few days ago, last weekend, when he said: `Wait for the Budget and we will have a look at employment policy. When the Budget is delivered the Treasurer will come in and he will give an unequivocal statement; he will give unequivocal information and unequivocal detail as to what the Government's wages policies will be over the course of this year'. We have now had the unequivocal detail; we got that in the Budget Speech made by the Treasurer last night and we got some more unequivocal detail from the Treasurer in Question Time today. The only thing that emerges from it is, first of all, that the Government does not know what the unemployment rate will be for the rest of this financial year and, secondly, that the Government is embarking and continuing on policies which can only have the result of increasing unemployment in this country.

We have got the unequivocal detail that the Government believes it to be, so let us have a look at what it is. The first thing the Government is going to do is to try to discount wages by 2 per cent in the next national wage case. We say that if there is any sense, because there clearly is, behind discounting of wages because of the effect of the devaluation, the Government must discount for the full effects of the devaluation. It is pointless doing anything else. Secondly, the Government says: `There is another national wage case coming up next April'. What is the unequivocal detail it gives us about that? The Government says: `When the April national wage case comes up next year we will have a look at it and if circumstances warrant it we will have a look at the possibility of arguing for some discounting on that occasion too'. We say it is clear as burning daylight that if the Government wants to get any confidence back into this economy it must, first of all, recognise the overwhelming significance of wage costs and the part that that is playing in holding this economy back and, secondly, that if it wants to restore any confidence with overseas markets it must now declare that it will argue for full discounting in the April national wage case.

The third part of the unequivocal detail that the Government condescends to give us is that wage increases looked at on an award basis over the coming financial year will be 4 3/4 per cent or thereabouts and they will be broadly comparable, we are told, with those of our major trading partners. That must surely be the greatest deception of all. It is absolute nonsense and can be shown to be so. In the first place the Treasurer is talking about award wages-he seems to be like other members in the Labor Party because they do not know anything about employing people-and the fact that employers have to pay actual wages across the counter.

If we look at actual wages in this country-it is buried there in the detail of the Treasury statements-we come to the conclusion that there will be an increase in wages of something over 6 per cent in the course of this financial year. If one adds the full potential costs of superannuation, which the Government does nothing to discourage but everything to encourage the unions to pursue, our wage expectation could indeed be higher over the coming year. But when we look at the reality which is buried in the Treasury papers we see that there is an expected increase in wages of over 6 per cent. What does that tell us about how we will compare with the countries with which we have to trade and with which we have to compete? It tells us that we are well ahead. Let us look at the comparable countries and their figures. In the United States of America, on the last figures, there was an increase in wages in the last year of 3.5 per cent; in Japan, 3.7 per cent; in Germany, 3 per cent; in the major Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development trading countries, 4.6 per cent; and Australia, as we are told in the Budget Papers themselves, over 6 per cent. It is clear-this is in the Budget Papers and it is in there for anyone to read-that it is above the average for Australia's major trading partners.

As I said at the outset, the whole thing can be expressed very concisely because what the Government is presenting to this country is simply a situation where our inflation rate will be 8 per cent. Comparing this with at least one of our trading partners it will be 800 per cent higher than the inflation rate in that country and many times the inflation rate in virtually all of the others. This is the situation that has faced the Government, and it is now presenting us with an inflation rate of 8 per cent because of its policies. It says: `In reality, let us look at what is paid in other countries and we will pay Australian workers more'. We say that that is a formula for disaster and it is to the Government's advantage, if it has its wits about it, to wake up to itself and abandon that course.

What should the Government do if it wants to get this thing back on the track before unemployment goes through the roof? Firstly, there must be a wages freeze if we are to stick with the present centralised system. Secondly, and most importantly, it must abandon its taxes on business, both those that it implemented before the Budget and those that it implemented last night, the new taxes which can only act as a disincentive to employment and can only act as a powerful force to prevent the generation of more employment in this country. The Labor Party seems to forget that if it imposes taxes of $1.4 billion it cannot help get any result other than an increase in unemployment in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very interesting to receive a lecture from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honour- able member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), about employment policy. When he was a Minister in this country, the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, he showed he knew all about employment policy by prevailing over a period of minimal employment growth and a strong increase in unemployment. It was a period in which the economy was going downhill rapidly, a period in which the number of unemployed teenagers increased by 45,000, and a period in which wages blew out by 17 per cent in the 13 months that he was the Minister for Employment.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, you can see what kind of credentials the Deputy Leader of the Opposition brings to these sorts of debates. He has been there and he certainly has not done it. He has shown that he was an absolute and abject failure when he had the opportunity as Minister for Employment to show what he could produce. He produced 16,000 jobs in 13 months, an increase in unemployment of 75,000 and an increase in wages of 17 per cent. That was his contribution to the welfare of the Australian nation. So we start off with an appreciation of what credentials the Deputy Leader of the Opposition brings to his shadow portfolio and to debates of this nature when he seeks to lecture the Government about employment policy.

This Government does not have to hang its head in shame to anyone in this country or anywhere else about employment policy. We have shown quite clearly that we have what it takes to create strong employment growth in this country. For three years we have demonstrated enormous success in that area. There has been an increase in employment of 640,000 in 3 1/4 years in this country, and for the last couple of years we have had the strongest employment growth of any country in the Western world. Those are credentials which indeed stand us in good stead when we say that we know what it takes to produce jobs in this country and to bring the unemployment rate down, particularly if honourable members appreciate that we did all that after inheriting an economy which had gone through the floor and in which there had been a massive recession; indeed, the worst recession for 50 years.

It is from that basis that one must now look at the situation that the nation is in. We are in a situation where clearly we have to make an adjustment to our economy. This adjustment is not caused by the failure of government economic policies and it is not caused by a failure of the trade union movement to adhere to a rigid prices and incomes accord. It is not due to the failure of business to perform. It is due solely to the fact that we as a nation have been afflicted by a tremendous burden, by the deterioration in our terms of trade and by a catastrophic decline in our export prices, which forces us as a government to make a very substantial adjustment. If anyone is to blame for this situation, one would have to blame those people who were in government over most of the post-war period-the people who shaped the Australian economy. They produced an economy which was industrialised on an inefficient basis, which was not able to produce manufactured exports, and which had a narrow export base-an industrialised country with Third World exports which, despite the minerals boom, was still 80 per cent reliant on agricultural and mineral products and a small proportion of manufactured exports as a proportion of total exports.

We see an economy that needs a strong structural adjustment. This problem if anyone is to blame, flows from the fact that the previous Government allowed the economy to develop in this way. Other nations which are blessed with considerable resources, and nations of comparable size such as Canada, for instance, in the post-war period industrialised in a way that gave them strength and a capacity to withstand the imposts from falling commodity prices that weigh so heavily on us at present. They built up manufactured and other exports as a proportion of total exports from 20 per cent in the early stages of the post-war period to about 50 per cent. We did not do that. We relied on our agricultural exports and said that we were the lucky country. Then we had the mineral boom and said that that made it even clearer that we were the lucky country.

The fact is that we have the present problem in greater magnitude than any other country because the fall in commodity prices devastates our exports much more than in countries which have a much more diverse array of exports, which have competitive manufacturing industries and which are able therefore, to withstand the fall in commodity prices much better than we are. The fall in commodity prices and the change in the terms of trade are catastrophic for us. We have no alternative but now to take a much quieter role in terms of economic growth in the next year or so while we as a nation adjust to the balance of payments problem which has been foisted upon us.

In a situation where the nation is absolutely compelled to have a slower rate of growth, we shall of course have a slower rate of growth of employment. That does not mean that employment growth has ended or that we will have soaring unemployment. It means that for a time we shall have a lower rate of growth in employment than we have been blessed with in the last couple of years. We are looking at employment growth this year of approximately 1.75 per cent compared to 3.9 per cent in 1985-86-a considerable reduction but still growth. In those circumstances it is not a disaster and does not mean a tremendous rise in unemployment.

It is clear in the Budget Papers and from what I have said publicly and recently when the July figures for employment and unemployment came out, that we as a nation have to face the likelihood of some increase in unemployment. That increase will not be large, in our view. It is quite clear in the Budget Papers that we expect some increase in unemployment, but not a large increase. That increase is virtually unavoidable in the present circumstances, given that we have to make such an enormous adjustment to the balance of payments. That is indeed to be regretted, but when we get through that period with a lower rate of growth of employment and some slight increase in unemployment, we will then, if we have got the other factors right-which I am sure we will-be able to move into a stronger growth path with higher growth of employment and some further reductions in unemployment in future years.

That is the scenario that faces us. It does not give us great pleasure to say to the Australian people that we are most likely looking at some increase in unemployment in the current financial year, but the situation could be a hell of a lot worse if we did not do what we are doing in this Budget and in other areas of economic policy. As we have said in the Budget and in other statements made by various Government economic spokesmen, if we do not make the adjustments we need to make, if we do not make a considerable reduction in the deficit, if we do not discount wages, inevitably we will be forced to make a further reduction in the exchange rate and/or by increased interest rates. There is no alternative. Either we make the adjustment ourselves with some pain, with some reduction in living standards and some slight increase in unemployment, or it will be foisted upon us. If it is foisted upon us it will be a hell of a lot worse. The fall in living standards will be very much higher and the increase in unemployment will be much greater.

In those circumstances we believe that the most sensible thing is to make those adjustments deliberately ourselves rather than have them foisted upon us by the international economy. The Government has been prepared to stand up and take that course. It will not make us magnificently popular for a time, but we believe that the Australian people, as there is already evidence in the response to the Budget, have already appreciated the fact that this nation needs to make an adjustment and to remain in control of its own economy. If we do not make these adjustments now, if we do not do what needs to be done in the present circumstances and have them foisted upon us, we will lose all control of our own affairs. That would be a disaster for the nation because it would certainly mean much greater pain than would otherwise be inflicted. That is the situation that faces us, and all this Opposition talk of deception and so on is a load of nonsense. There has been no attempt to deceive the Australian people. The situation and what it involves has been spelt out clearly and specifically.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition wanted to say something about wages policy. I do not think he actually said very much but he got on to the subject. It was made clear in the speech of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that at the next national wage case the Government will seek a further two per cent discount. That is essential if we are not to have the inflation impost from the further devaluation which has occurred since September last year-a devaluation of around 20 per cent. If we are not to have that increase in import prices feeding through the consumer price index into wages and back into the CPI and perpetuating the wages-prices inflation horror, we will have to have a discount so that that will not happen.

That is a responsible attitude for the Government to take. Obviously it is not easy for us in the context of the accord to say that we are to have that adjustment, but we believe that it has to be done. We believe that it is economically responsible that it be done and that therefore we have to do it. We are not seeking to hide anything in this respect. We are saying quite blatantly and openly to all concerned that we have to have that discount in order to have a lesser rate of wage increase and to avoid an inflationary spiral.

We are looking at what we need in terms of competitiveness. We agree with the Opposition that that is important. Devaluation has made us massively competitive. We are now enormously competitive with the 40 per cent devaluation in the trade-weighted index that we have had since early 1985. It gives us magnificent opportunities. Indeed, it is that devaluation which is now becoming the engine for growth in this financial year. It will provide most of the growth in domestic product this year, with net exports contributing most of that growth. The devaluation gives us the basis for that. It means that we can get structural adjustment going in this country and develop a wide array of exports in order to make our export industries much stronger than they were previously. This is essential if we are to get out of the balance of payments problem. The wages adjustment is necessary to ensure that the devaluation which gives us all these opportunities does not get fed into inflation and therefore start to destroy that competitiveness.

The Opposition sought to make comparisons with overseas wage rates and growth. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) pointed out in Question Time that if comparisons are to be made about comparative increases in wage rates between Australia and overseas countries, we should compare the position when the previous Government was in office with the situation since this Government came to office. In the last year of the previous Government there was a 6 1/2 per cent wage increase for our major Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development trading partners and a 16 1/2 per cent increase for us. Our increase was 10 per cent more-an extraordinary differential. In 1983 the increase for our OECD trading partners was 4 1/2 per cent compared with 5 1/2 per cent for us, so they were slightly ahead; in 1984 it was 4 1/2 per cent for overseas countries and 7.7 per cent for us, which meant they were a bit further ahead; and in 1985 it was 4.6 per cent overseas and 6.2 per cent here. In this year and in 1987 we are looking at something like a further 6 per cent increase if one takes account of the discounting and also allows for some drift.
