Therefore, we expect again to be slightly ahead of overseas countries, but very much in the same ball park. Certainly the differential will be nothing like that which would destroy the massive competitiveness which we as a nation have and which gives us enormous opportunities to expand our export industries and make the very important structural adjustments.

Quite clearly we as a nation have magnificent opportunities at present. Every cloud has a silver lining, so to speak, and in present circumstances we can certainly make use of the devaluation in a way which would not be possible had it not occurred. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition also mentioned that the Treasurer when making his comparisons of wages here and overseas, was using award rates of pay. That is absolutely untrue. He was not doing that. He was referring to earnings, so was the Prime Minister and so was I in the figures that I gave the House just now.

I understand that there is to be some assault launched on the employment and training programs conducted by my Department. Those programs are very effective and although the job creation program-the community employment program-has been scaled back, it has been extremely important for the long term unemployed. It is a program which has done much to assist the long term unemployed to get jobs. The traineeship program, which is coming into force now, will provide much training in 1986-87. It will introduce a system of training which will be of enormous benefit to young people in this country in the future. Already 4,500 traineeships positions have been created and over 2,000 trainees are in place.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must make some remarks about the comments of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis). It is rather interesting to analyse his remarks because he seems to be pulling back a little from some of the rhetoric we have heard from him in the past. Certainly, to just stand up and blame the problems that we have now solely on the terms of trade is a little bit rich. We must remember that at some time in the 12 previous years a Labor government was in power so it cannot all be our fault. The unions have priced us out of jobs. The figures show that new business starts have dropped during the time that Labor has been in government. As to the question of wages and the 2 per cent discount, businesses and responsible commentators want much more than 2 per cent discounting at the next wage case. The Minister should go in and argue for no increase at all.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget deficit referred to last night of $3.5 billion is to be financed solely by increases in taxes and is the bottom line result of last night's efforts. These increased taxes will have, in combination with previously announced taxes, a cumulative effect on employment growth prospects and these prospects are now clearly in jeopardy. The `great communicator', the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), has made much of jobs, jobs, jobs-we have heard that so many times over the past couple of years-but the delivery over the next 12 months now looks awfully doubtful. This Budget's soft underbelly-the rubbery figures-is clearly in the employment prospects. The Budget Speech states:
Unemployment could rise a little.

A little! The Minister knows as well as I do that he is worried and that the community should be worried. Six months from now we will see what `a little' really is. The response to the employment issue has been inadequate to say the least.

One could say-and I think honourable members on both sides of the House would agree-that the youth of this nation are the key to the future. If we look at the last census we see that 50.4 per cent of the people in this country are under 30. The Australian Nationwide Opinion Polls youth survey which was conducted by the Special Minister of State (Mr Young), the Minister for keeping Labor in office, indicated that Labor must do something and do something it did. We had the Priority One public relations exercise, we had appearances on Countdown, we had rock concerts, we had the Australian traineeships scheme launched-and we know what a debacle that has been initially-and we have had the Prime Minister appearing endlessly on talkback shows. It seems that he can talk the best. We have also had examples of glossy publications which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N.A. Brown) showed honourable members during his speech. I sometimes wonder whether the Minister actually looks at some of these pamphlets before they are sent out. One of them says: `Before you do anything, don't do anything without going through everything in here'. It then says: `Get ready, get set, go-no worries'. No worries! That is what the Minister would have us believe now after last night's effort. But it is clearly not sufficient.

Rhetoric does not reveal the full picture. In June 1986 there was an 8.3 per cent unemployment rate. In June 1985 the rate was 8.4 per cent, so clearly there has been no marked change over a 12-month period. Youth unemployment is appallingly high. In June 1986 it was 22.7 per cent, the highest monthly rate since March 1985. The average length of unemployment had increased from 33 weeks in March 1983 to 51.9 weeks in March 1986. Once again young people have suffered. In March 1983 the youth unemployment rate was three times the adult rate. In March 1986 it was 3.5 times that rate. Now we have this Budget.

The community employment program has been cut by $90m and one hopes that the more bizarre schemes will be cut out. When the legislation last came forward in this House the Opposition supported the Government but pointed out that CEP was full of examples of how not to help unemployed people and how to waste money. If CEP funding is aimed at the right projects, a $90m cut should have no adverse impact on employment creation for those most needing assistance. We urged the Government then to focus more on traineeship funding for youth. This has at least now been realised by the Government. However, traineeships have been slow to start and the reason has been plain for everyone to see. The Minister's former union colleagues are interested in maintaining existing jobs, not in providing the flexibility of approach to facilitate a greater opportunity for traineeships. The Australian traineeship scheme has so far failed to deliver the promised goods. The reasons are many, but two perhaps warrant special mention. Priority One was an ill-conceived program launched with an overload of hype and a paucity of substance. Secondly, the unions actively worked to ensure its initial failure. Unions can play a vitally important role in the Australian traineeship scheme if they recognise two very basic truths. The first is that the high level of youth wages relative to adult wages is a significant barrier to increased youth employment. Secondly, expanding and educating the work force is in everybody's interests and the big beneficiaries, of course, are those who gain employment.

What about the national task force into traineeships which was set up by the Government in February this year? Initially it was appointed for 12 months. Will the Government make public the recommendations that that body has made to it? Perhaps it should tell us how the task force is going-we have not heard anything about it. Perhaps it should tell us what the members of that task force are saying. Also, we note that the new community volunteer program, which is simply a new name for an existing program, is to have a new national advisory group. I ask the Minister: How does he justify that and is it really necessary? When will the Government come clean on the `work for benefit' proposals of the Prime Minister. We remember his address to the nation-the one that did not get the rave reviews in the newspapers, the one that failed. No one quite knew what the Prime Minister meant when he referred to community work for youth. Most people thought he meant work for benefit was necessary and he got some credit for that. But the Budget tells the Prime Minister that that is not on, that we will have a voluntary scheme. The Prime Minister changed his mind, just as he did on uranium.

Where is the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) or the `Black Irishman' as he is called? Where is that man of principle today? I did not see him get up and walk out last night How did it feel for him to see himself written up in Time magazine recently as the `defender of the unemployed'. Certainly we will watch him over the next six months because it is quite clear that the unemployment situation is the soft underbelly of this Budget and that will be very plain for the whole community to see. People like the honourable member for Melbourne often think that they are the only ones in this place who have compassion. They certainly are not. Many of us, on both sides of the Parliament, are concerned. It is significant to see that this Party on the first opportunity after the Budget to raise a matter of public importance, has raised the question of the future of employment growth. We certainly need and hope for a better investment climate to permit greater growth. We hope for a stronger approach to traineeship schemes rather than just more rhetoric and confusion. We hoped for the compulsory work scheme but got a wishy-washy pale compromise. We hoped for honesty in employment estimates but got fudged responses and the ever earnest Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations wringing his hands yet again. There has been an inadequate response to one of Australia's greatest social problems. The Government will be judged harshly for its deceit, for the false hopes it has generated and for its sheer inability to bring into line all its union friends to ensure that jobs, jobs, jobs are a reality.

To address this human tragedy of unemployment, new attitudes are required in key areas. The labour market must be made more flexible. Training programs must be just that and not short term measures. Our antiquated apprenticeship system must be overhauled and there must be closer links with educational institutions. Increasing participation rates in education are vital for our future. Unions must become more compassionate towards those without jobs. The preoccupation should be with improving employment, not the perverse situation of gaining improved benefits at the expense of improved employment. No one wants to see unemployment used as a means of exploitation. That is not in the nature of a civilised nation, which we like to think our nation is, or at least can be.

Employment prospects are dependent on many factors and the Budget Papers are very illuminating in this regard. We find in them an admission that employment growth will shrink to 1.75 per cent this year and a decline in employment growth will cause an increase in unemployment. On page 59 of the Budget Papers there is an admission that an average unemployment rate of at least 8 per cent will remain for 1986-87. In fact, it is likely to be far higher. The consumer price index is forecast to be 8 per cent, which will certainly hurt our competitiveness, which in turn will disadvantage the employment prospects for which we are looking.

It is our view there needs to be an examination of the apprenticeship system as it operates in Australia. The Budget allocates $122.6m for trade training. Trade-based training is union controlled and is not producing the greatest assistance for employers and employees. There clearly needs to be an examination of the apprenticeship system. Money spent on schemes which are unproductive must be reviewed and could be reallocated. There must be a re-examination of all unemployment schemes. The Kirby report, the report of the Committee of Inquiry into Labour Market Programs, is not a final document; it is but a start. Those schemes which clearly are not performing the functions for which they were designed will have to be looked at far more closely.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) and his much maligned, but accurately maligned, Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party of Australia, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), went through the same routine as they have done in this place on many occasions. But it is worth reflecting on the history of this discredited Opposition when it was in government. My colleague the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) did that very well and I do not intend to canvass that ground again. It is worth making a couple of general points, because if one were to rely upon the contributions of Opposition members one would almost necessarily embrace the view that wages policy-and wages policy alone-is the only part of a very complex economic equation. Opposition members have run through a few statistics, but even on the ones they ran through they ought to hang their heads in shame. For example, it is worth looking briefly at the employment record of the Opposition. The Hawke Government has created 640,000 jobs in its term of office of just over three years. That is not statistics, that is 640,000 people in jobs who otherwise would not have had jobs. Under the previous Government 337,000 jobs were created in 7 1/2 years, which is less than half the jobs in twice the amount of time. That record speaks eloquently for itself and there is no need for me to address that particular issue in my contribution to this matter of public importance.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition will not be allowed to forget the economic vandalism it visited upon this country and in particular the hypocrisy of the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party will not be allowed to go unchallenged. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations addressed with some eloquence and even more accuracy the economic vandalism that the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party visited upon Australia, in particular the young Australians about whom the honourable member for Bass was waxing so philosophical. In the term of office of the Liberal Party, it was the young people particularly who suffered. Some people in Tasmania, as recently as a few weeks ago, were not prepared to allow him to forget it; nor should they. While I do not embrace their methodology, the message is one that should not be forgotten.

One of the most important economic variables-and it was not addressed by anyone opposite-is our international competitiveness. We all know that there are a number of ways in which we can go about defining Australia's international competitiveness, but unit labour costs adjusted for exchange rates relative to a basket of our major trading nations is certainly a most important variable, and those on the other side of the House with any economic training would not dispute that. Let us use that measure. During the life of the Fraser-Howard Government, there was an improvement of not much more than a lousy 2 per cent in that variable. This is one of the fundamental equations that this country needs to address. The record was an increase of marginally in excess of 2 per cent. Over the period of the Hawke Government that index of international competitiveness has improved by in excess of 20 per cent. Of course, one can always use statistics and come out with a whole range of interpretations of them. We all know that there are lies, damned lies and statistics. The reality is-the honourable member for Bass is agreeing-that that index is important.

Those figures-they are not the Government's, they are in the Budget material handed out last night-give a major indication of the movement in this country's economy. The movement in real gross domestic product under the Hawke Government has been 4.6 per cent and under the Fraser-Howard Government it was 2.9 per cent. The movement in real non-farm GDP under the Hawke Government has been 4.2 per cent and under the mob of vandals opposite it was 2.4 per cent. Under the Hawke Government inflation has averaged 6.5 per cent and under the former Government it was 10.7 per cent. Another figure which might be of interest to the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party is the average number of working days lost per annum through industrial disputes under the vandals opposite, of whom the Deputy Leader was one of the main bovver boys. Under the former Government three million working days were lost per annum, compared with 1.3 million days lost under this Government; almost one-third of the former Government's rate. The Hawke Government has created about 640,000 jobs in three years, compared with 337,000 jobs created by the former Government in over seven years; an absolutely disgraceful record.

I go back to the main issue before us today, the issue of wages. Wages policy has been one of this Government's great success stories. It is all right for those on the other side of the House to attack any particular policy initiative of this Government-perhaps that is their duty-but I can tell them that the people of Australia will become sick and tired of a whingeing Opposition which is not prepared to put any alternative policy settings before this Parliament or the people. Opposition members come in here and knock. They have interest groups such as Bob Ansett on the fringe benefits tax. They can go to Bob Ansett and say: `We will abolish the fringe benefits tax'. Hooray! They can go to others and talk about the assets test or the capital gains tax. They can go to all those interest groups and say `If you want to blame someone, blame the Hawke Government', but what is it going to put in place?

There has not been one speech in this House from the Opposition on where it would derive the alternative revenue that is fundamentally necessary to run this country; nor have Opposition members been prepared to indicate in any substantive way, in terms of reductions in government expenditure, precisely where they would impact any proposed reductions. Honourable members opposite simply will not do it. They will not do it because it is a fundamental tenet of opposition life that one goes out and attacks. One does not leave oneself open to criticism by saying: `We might chop this area of government expenditure', or `We might have to increase revenue from this source'. Honourable members opposite will not do it. But at the end of the day, before the next election, they will have to put up some alternatives not only in these areas but also in terms of wages policy. Really, they do not have a wages policy. The previous Government never had a wages policy. It ebbed and flowed between full indexation, partial indexation, a wage freeze and so on. It did not know where it was going. People will recall that vividly. In particular, people will recall the involvement of this discredited Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party in that process.

Our record ought to be stood in stark contrast to the fiasco of the wages policy that the previous Government had before we came into office. Let me refer to its crowning achievement of which I have had some experience. I had to go round in those years and try to negotiate redundancy packages for workers, for example, in the metal trades industries, who were being laid off in their thousands as a result of the 1982 metal trades case. That was a very sad and sorry experience and one that I will never forget. In any event, honourable members opposite ought to accept the responsibility for it because it was a fundamental and inevitable result of having no wages policy at all.

I could go on and talk about a whole range of the Opposition's other indictments but I will simply say this: I get sick in the gut sitting in this House and seeing honourable members opposite, who have more cheek than the rear end of an elephant, coming into this place and putting up these stupid criticisms without having the intellectual honesty and the political courage to put forward any viable proposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 249th report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts entitled `Proposed computer acquisition for Repatriation General Hospitals by the Department of Veterans' Affairs'.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This report contains the findings of the Public Accounts Committee's inquiry into the proposed computer acquisition for repatriation general hospitals by the Department of Veterans' Affairs. This proposal was the first received by the Committee under its standing reference to examine and report on major computer acquisition proposals before they proceed to Cabinet for approval of funds. The Committee accepted this standing reference in May 1985 in response to the Government's concern that major computer acquisition proposals are often of such complexity and raise such important related issues that they cannot be dealt with adequately under the severe pressures imposed by the Budget timetable. It is intended that the Committee's scrutiny of automatic data processing acquisition proposals will occur outside the annual Budget process and will precede any Cabinet approval for the commencement of tendering and acquisition action.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has circulated to all departments its guidelines on information to be submitted to support major automatic data processing proposals and invited comments from departments. Should the information requirements be too onerous, the Committee stands ready to review or amend them. The Committee recognises that there is always the danger that the planning process receives excessive attention and is in effect elevated above the operational tasks itself. In the absence of any approach by the Public Service Board or individual departments, the Committee can only assume that its guidelines are fulfilling their objectives.

Some of the major matters which the Committee was requested to examine in its review of these proposals include their justification and cost effectiveness, employment and industrial relations issues, technical and other risks and provisions for Australian industry participation. The Committee is refining its approach to computer acquisition proposals and is conscious that it should not delay proposals. Accordingly, not all proposals may be subject to a full public inquiry. The Committee has found benefit in supplementing the public inquiry process by on-site inspections and informal discussions. In this proposal the inspection of Concord Repatriation Hospital and Royal Adelaide Hospital convinced the Committee of the urgent need to achieve significant improvements to the service provided to our veterans.

The Committee has been concerned at the lip service being paid by departments to Australian industry participation. The Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce has appeared as an expert witness in a recent hearing, together with the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services. The Committee considers that Australian industry participation is of vital concern. It therefore sees the need for departments to give full attention to this issue. The Committee has been disappointed with some departments' attitudes and considers that their proposals do not comply with the spirit of the Government's Australian industry participation policy. The Committee will be devoting particular attention to this issue and some proposals may need to be rejected.

Having made some quite general observations about the ADP inquiry process, let me turn to matters relating to the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The Department's proposed computer acquisition for repatriation general hospitals was approved by Cabinet and funds of $2.6m were included in the 1985-86 Budget, subject to advice from the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh). The Minister for Finance subsequently advised the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) on 1 August 1985 that no expenditure should occur until a satisfactory report on the proposal had been received from the Public Accounts Committee.

The Committee is concerned that this proposal was not referred to it directly as a result of a Cabinet decision as envisaged under the arrangements agreed between the Committee and the Minister for Finance. It also notes that the intention of the reference was, as the then Minister for Finance, now the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins), stated in his speech, to ensure proposals are reviewed outside the Budget cycle, and well in advance of any decision to commit funds. This clearly has not been the case for this proposal where funds had already been approved for the current 1985-86 Budget subject to a satisfactory report from this Committee. The Committee is unequivocally of the view that all proposals should be referred to the Committee by Cabinet itself and well in advance of any request for, or approval of, funds.

The proposal from the Department of Veterans' Affairs is to upgrade the computing capacity and facilities available in repatriation general hospitals-RGHs-to provide an integrated hospital information system to improve patient care and treatment, including admissions, scheduling of patient services and discharges. The Department proposes to acquire an IBM computer for Concord RGH and IBM compatible computers for the four other mainland capital RGHs at an equipment cost of $10m over the four years 1985-86 to 1988-89. The Department proposes to acquire the IBM computer for Concord without going to public tender, but to request tenders for the computers for the other RGHs. The Committee did have some initial reservations about the relationship between IBM and the Department of Veterans' Affairs. However, the Committee has been assured that this relationship is not inappropriate given the history of the repatriation general hospital computing project.

The Committee has identified opportunities for the Australian software industry and will be interested to see the outcome. The Committee's major conclusions about this proposal are that: The Department of Veterans' Affairs has not to date conducted the development of an integrated information system for the repatriation hospitals in a manner consistent with existing planning guidelines and sound project management practices; the computing systems at repatriation general hospitals generally lag well behind those available in other public hospitals; and some form of integrated hospital information system is the most effective way to satisfy repatriation general hospital information requirements and that the patient care system proposed offers the only appropriate vehicle to achieve this in an IBM compatible environment.

The Committee recommends that the Department of Veterans' Affairs proceed with its negotiations with the Department of Finance and the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services with a view to purchasing computers for the repatriation general hospitals; that the Department of Veterans' Affairs supply the Committee, accompanied by comments from the Department of Finance, with information on computer capacity requirements before placing an order for a computer at Repatriation General Hospital Concord; that the Department of Veterans' Affairs respond to the other Committee recommendations through the Minister for Finance minute mechanism prior to proceeding beyond the purchase of the Concord computer; and that, should the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services accept the arguments put to it by the Department of Veterans' Affairs for a certificate of exemption for an IBM computer for Repatriation General Hospital Concord, a supply and development contract be concurrently negotiated with IBM which ties further development and support for the patient care system related software to the initial IBM computer acquisition.

The Committee also makes several general recommendations for future computer projects. Some related recommendations are also contained in the Committee's report on the Australian Audit Office computer acquisition, which was tabled previously. From its experience with the Department of Veterans' Affairs proposal, the Committee recommends that departments include in their strategic plans a clear statement where the proposed acquisition of computer software is subsequently likely to involve or influence computer hardware expenditures; and that this information be explicitly drawn to the attention of the Department of Finance, the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services and this Committee. I recommend the report to honourable members.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AMENDMENT (RECIPROCITY WITH ITALY) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howe, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The main purpose of this Bill is to provide for the implementation of the reciprocal agreement on social security signed with Italy on 23 April this year. The Bill will also effect minor amendments to the Social Security Act 1947 to ensure that the agreement meshes with the Act. The reciprocal agreement which has been concluded with Italy is the first in a network of new cost-sharing agreements which the Government is seeking to conclude with each of Australia's migrant source countries. The background to this initiative was outlined in my statement to the House on reciprocal social security agreements on 8 May 1985. A copy of that statement has been distributed to honourable members with this speech.

Reciprocal social security agreements are formal arrangements which countries enter into to ensure that people who move between them receive social security pensions and benefits on a fair and equitable basis. They are treaties binding countries under international law and are put into effect under the domestic law of the countries concerned. Like the agreement with Italy, Australia's future agreements will be based on principles which are in line with international practice. Those principles are:
Shared responsibility: Each party to the agreement will contribute to a person's total social security coverage.
Equality of treatment: The residents and citizens of both countries will be given equal access to each other's social security laws.

Totalisation: Periods of residence and/or contributions in both countries will be added together to give people the minimum period of residence or contributions required to qualify for a pension from either or both countries.

Pro-rata basis: The total amount of pensions to be paid by each country to people residing in the other will be based either on the length of a person's residence or contributions. The Social Security Proportional Portability of Pensions Act 1986 enabled this principle to be adopted for Australia.
The reciprocal agreement between Australia and Italy specifically addresses the social security rights of the following groups of people:
Those who have resided in Australia and cannot claim Australian pension entitlement because they now reside in Italy;
those who ceased contributions to the Italian social security scheme when they migrated to Australia and who now cannot claim Italian pension entitlement; and
those from Italy who are now in Australia and do not have access to Australian pensions because they have not resided here long enough.

The Government will be pressing to get the agreement with Italy ratified as soon as possible in order that the benefits it gives can flow to the intended beneficiaries. In developing this agreement with Italy, the Government has formulated a four-stage process to be followed for future agreements. This process involves:
Detailed exchanges of information, including written material and face to face meetings to enable both country's officials to understand each other's social security systems;
consultations with communities in Australia likely to be affected by an agreement;
negotiation of the terms of an agreement, taking into account community views; and
ratification, legislation and implementation.

In keeping with my undertaking to the ethnic communities in Australia, relevant communities will be consulted before the commencement of formal negotiations. Exchanges of information between Australia and the country in question need to take place before consultations can be conducted with the community concerned so that the implications and the viability of an agreement can be explored with the community and its concerns taken into account prior to the commencement of formal negotiations. As with my community consultations in 1985, the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia will be invited to assist with further consultations. I commend the Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN LAND TRANSPORT (FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris.
(Quorum formed)
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Act 1985 to give effect to the announcements made by the Government on 12 June 1986. It adjusts the rate of duty and excise on petrol and diesel which is hypothecated to the Australian Land Transport Program Trust Fund. This measure, and the decision to hold payments in 1986-87 under the Australian bicentennial road development program and ALTP to $1,250m, forms an integral part of the Government's overall economic strategy.

The Bill will reduce the rate of duty hypothecated to the Trust fund by 0.235c per litre from 1 July 1986. It also authorises the repayment from the ALTP Trust Fund to the Consolidated Revenue Fund of the revenue generated in the period from 1 July 1986 by the 0.235c per litre adjustment, taking into account subsequent indexation adjustments and any interest earned by these funds while they are retained in the Trust fund. These amendments do not alter the Government's fundamental commitment to developing a better road system for Australia.

This Government, more than any of its pre- decessors, has highlighted the need for a road system which serves the interests of the Australian community, including our industries. We have recognised that roads facilitate the interaction of commerce between our major cities, between communities and within communities. We are, in effect, bringing all Australians closer together.

Road transport is a fundamental part of the Australian way of life. Well designed and constructed roads make significant contributions to Australia. They reduce costs; they save lives; they encourage all forms of industry. They repay to Australia far more than their cost. However, in the current economic circumstances, where Australia is under pressure from external factors, it is essential that each sector of the economy and the community makes a contribution towards the overall well-being of the country. The downwards adjustment and the excise rate proposed will reduce payments to the Trust Fund by about $50m a year from that originally projected for 1986-87.
Turning to details of the Bill, clauses 1 and 2 contain the usual citation and commencement provisions.

Clause 3 of the Bill provides for the rate of excise payable to the ALTP Trust Fund to be 3.610c per litre from 1 July 1986 by the insertion of section 14a into the principal Act. This varies by 0.235c per litre the rate which would otherwise have applied from 1 July. Clause 4 of the Bill makes a minor adjustment to the wording of section 15 sub-section (7) of the principal Act. Clause 5 of the Bill provides for the revenue generated by the 0.235c per litre adjustment to be paid out of the ALTP Trust Fund to the Consolidated Revenue Fund. In accordance with the established indexing procedure for the rate of duty of excise on motor spirit and diesel fuel under ALTP, this variation of 0.235c will also be indexed with the associated revenue to be paid into the Consolidated Revenue Fund in due course. Clause 5 also provides for any investment income which may accrue to these moneys whilst they are held in the ALTP Trust Fund to likewise be paid to Consolidated Revenue. I commend the Bill to honourable members. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Amendment Bill is a Bill which every member of the community would applaud. It seeks to repeal existing legislation and replace it with stronger legislation to stop the dumping into the sea of any material containing radioactivity of any significance. I am sure that everyone in the House and every thinking person will be very keen to see that we do not add nuclear material to the environment of the seas, because there is no way of knowing where it is going to end and no way of containing it once it has been so deposited.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill carries with it a very strong responsibility for Australia, and I am afraid that it is a responsibility which Australia does not fully recognise. It is inevitable that there will be an accumulation of nuclear waste in the world. That is happening now. Many tonnes of nuclear waste which are stored throughout the world must ultimately be disposed of. Although we have seen the wisdom of not consigning it to the sea, we have to find a repository for it, and in this area Australia must address its responsibilities to the nations of the world. In Australia, we have geologically stable and geographically remote areas where we could safely contain uranium nuclear waste, and we also have the best technology in the world in the Ringwood Synroc technology. In times to come, responsible people in the environmental movement will recognise that Australia must take the step of offering to the world facilities for the storage of high level nuclear waste.

I would like to mention the Synroc system. It has enormous potential to do good for the world and bring some stability to the world, because it locks up nuclear waste in the atomic matrix of the synthetic titanium rock. This is much more leak resistant than the present proposed method of borosilicate glass. While I would not denigrate borosilicate glass in any way, for I believe that that, too, is a safe method, there is no doubt that the Synroc method is at least 10 times safer. For that reason, we have to give it great consideration.

I shall take a few minutes to explain the system. Holes are drilled into the earth. Areas with a very stable formation, for instance, the Yilgarn shield in my electorate, or the very large gabbro deposits west of Broken Hill, are found and the holes are drilled. The nuclear waste, which has been contained in this matrix, is then encased in a stainless steel cylinder and lowered into the holes. The holes are proposed to be about 4 kilometres deep. The containers are placed at 100-metre intervals, the intervening space being filled with a high yield bentonite clay which expands when it comes into contact with water, thereby making the holes quite impervious. To my knowledge, no water is found at depths greater than 1,000 metres in Australia. If a hole were 4,000 metres deep, without any water, it is unlikely that there would ever be an ingression of water. But if water penetrated these holes, it would swell the bentonite clay and seal off the hole. If water happened to penetrate, it would simply stay in the hole because it would have nowhere to go. It is a very safe method of containing nuclear waste.

Australia has a great responsibility to the world. I would be very concerned if Japan, which is geologically very unstable, were to start consigning nuclear waste to the ground in its territory. It would be far more appropriate if Australia said to the Japanese: `In the interests of the environment, we would feel much happier if you sent your waste to us and we will store it for you'. Of course, there would be a price for this. Just in passing-a fact that I am sure no one is really concerned with-I should say that this vital industry is probably worth about $2 billion a year. This is Australian technology in which we are pre-eminent in the world.

The Bill is also important because there is a lot of concern in the community about radioactivity. It is a very emotional subject and there is an enormous amount of misinformation. I listened to the debate in this House on the subject. I have spent some time looking at the nuclear industries in France and Great Britain. I am very impressed by the safety standards in the industries in those countries. I read with some alarm about the leaks that occurred at Sellafield. I went to Sellafield to have a look at the situation. It is true that a leak occurred there. A beaker containing water was pumped from the control zone and the alarms were sounded, but in getting it back some was spilt and some went into the Irish Sea. As a result of that spill, the United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority cleaned up 90 miles of beach, took away 400 tonnes of debris from the beach, including many old refrigerators, and restored the beaches to a level which they had not enjoyed for many years.

I then saw some scaremongering by the anti-nuclear lobby, saying that there had been an alarming upturn in bowel cancer in this area. It is true that bowel cancer is unusually prevalent in that part of the United Kingdom. It is also prevalent in some other parts of the United Kingdom where there is no nuclear industry. That alone would cast doubts on the assertion. What is common to most of those areas is the presence of raw sewage. There is a suggestion that cancer is caused by a virus, and it may be that the raw sewage, not radiation, is the cause of the cancer. Unfortunately, in the Thames estuary, where there is also a lot of raw sewage, they do not get any bowel cancer; they just get larger fish. There is clearly a lot of misinformation about this.

The fear that is generated by radiation may inhibit the development of positive industries in Australia. The mineral sands industry-mineral sand being a radioactive material-would do much more for Australia's terms of trade if it were value added in this country. As it is, we send it overseas and the rare earth materials are extracted overseas. That is where the great value added component comes in.

I would like to draw particular attention to neodymium, which is one of the minerals of the future. It is a slightly radioactive material. In fact it has a half-life of some million years. Some people say: `Ooh, ah, a million years. This will be dangerous'. The reason that it has a half-life of a million years is, of course, that the radiation level is very low. I point out that that is also the case with plutonium which, despite all of the shock horror, is a relatively low radiator. That is why it takes so long to revert to a half-life.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your radiation level?

—Neodymium is a very interesting material. It is one of the rarest constituents found mainly in monazite. As honourable members will know, particularly the learned honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), Australia has 80 per cent of the world's monazite deposits; in fact it has 80 per cent of the world's mineral sands resources. Western Australia has 80 per cent of Australia's resources, most of them in my electorate of Kalgoorlie.
—Most of everything is in your electorate.
—That is right; it is the centre of the world and so that is very appropriate. I am sure that, if God had a chance, that is where he would make heaven.

SPEECH.PARA: Neodymium is very interesting material because it has the property of enhancing magnetism. It is a very magnetic material. Alloys made from neodymium will in fact reduce the size of electric motors in the future. They will make electronic components much smaller. It will be a mineral much in demand. It would be a criminal shame if Australia were to continue to export monazite principally to France and Japan and to have the neodymium extracted there. We should do that in Australia and have an industry from a major resource and a major value added component. I mention that because one of the things that may inhibit the develop of such an industry is the fact that there are ignorant people who talk about radiation but who do not really understand it.

The world has had the effects of Chernobyl brought very closely to its attention lately. Of course, Chernobyl was the disaster that the anti-nuclear lobby had been waiting for. It was to be the big one. Unfortunately for that lobby, it really has not turned out that way. When we look at the Russian industry, we must realise that it is probably the most inefficient and probably the most dangerous nuclear industry in the world. It is certainly by a very large margin more dangerous even than that of the United States of America's nuclear industry which, in terms of safety, cannot hold a candle to the industries in Britain, France, Germany and the Scandinavian countries where standards are much higher.

But even in Chernobyl, where no attempt was made at containment and where large amounts of nuclear material were released, it appears that the long term effects will not be as horrendous as we have been told. I have seen some figures recently in which Sweden states that it expects that it will have eight additional cancer deaths from the release of this energy. That is regrettable. But I am sure that in the equivalent period far more people will be killed as a result of coal mining than as a result of the Chernobyl disaster. I also believe that vast steps will be made in a cure for cancer. So, while we may lose some people, others will be saved. Chernobyl was not the great disaster that the anti-nuclear lobby had been waiting for. I guess those same people will now be out praying that an accident will happen in Europe or America. In fact, I talked about this to the anti-nuclear senator from Western Australia, Jo Vallentine. She confided to me that an accident in Russia was not really much good to the anti-nuclear lobby because it needed one in America or Europe to make a bigger impression. I often wonder about that mentality.

This Bill also deals with the South Pacific nuclear free zone. That needs to be applauded. Like so much legislation that we have seen, it is one of those Bills that do not really do any harm even though they do not do much good. For that reason, I believe one can applaud the legislation. I must also say that one has to be a little cynical about it because one of the things that one notices about large nations and superpowers is that they can always be relied upon to do what they think is in their best interests at the time. So, no matter what treaty obligations they enter into, we can always be assured that, when it suits them, they will not honour their obligations. I guess that is one of the very few certainties in this world. In saying that, while it sounds somewhat cynical, I believe the action of the United States in relation to trade as it affects this country illustrates that only too clearly, to the detriment of our farmers.

I believe the nuclear industry has a very good safety record. The fact that this sort of legislation is supported and applauded by the industry is an indication of that. It is unfortunate that there is so much nonsense talked about this industry by what are basically the very conservative forces in the world. I refer to the sorts of people who opposed the invention of the steam engine, who required people to walk in front of cars with red flags because things had not been done a certain way in the past.

It is unfortunate that my Party, the Australian Labor Party, for the very reason that it has a very democratic structure is vulnerable to attack from single issue zealots. It is a source of great regret to me that a number of such people have infiltrated the Party. I might just say in passing that one of the great tests of the anti-nuclear lobby is to say to its supporters: `What is alpha radiation? What is beta radiation? What is gamma radiation?' I will bet London to a brick on that very few of them know the answer. But these are the people who talk with great authority and who are interviewed incessantly by the Press as authorities on the subject. But, when one asks them the basic questions, they simply do not know. It is a pity that we have a Press that has such abysmal ignorance on this subject that it is not capable or competent to question such people usefully in this regard. I was called to speak at short notice. I think I have done an enormously good job filling in 15 minutes; and I am afraid that that is all I have to say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a man of the sea. The electorate of Denison is bounded from Claremont to Taroona by Australia's most beautiful river, the River Derwent, into which waters flow from as far away as the Tasman Sea and from the Southern and Antarctic oceans. I have lived by the sea all my life. I have been involved with the sea all of my life as a yachtsman, as a member of the Royal Australian Naval Reserve and as one who genuinely loves the sea. I therefore have pleasure in supporting the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Amendment Bill 1986, although I want to make it quite clear that my vote in favour of it does not imply support for the next piece of legislation that we will deal with, namely, the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill upon which it is constitutionally based.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to note that this legislation came into being in 1981 during the term of the Fraser Government. It was clearly based on the foreign affairs powers in that it related at that stage to arrangements for dumping of radioactivity in Australian waters, which is now subject to change because of decisions that have been taken on that practice; this legislation bans such a practice completely. This Bill will prevent the dumping of all radioactive materials in Australian waters. I say `hear, hear' to that. The Government's reasons for this tightening up measure are to fulfil our obligations under the recently signed South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty and the proposed convention for the protection of natural resources and the environment of the South Pacific. I mention in passing that that convention is somewhat similar to the International Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources, the headquarters of which are based in Hobart in the Federal electorate of Denison-a decision very properly taken by the Fraser Government, the then Prime Minister and the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock).

The 1981 Act's provision for dumping radioactive waste is to be totally repealed as this section is based on the London Convention which deals with high level wastes. I think it is fair to say that this Amendment Bill will prevent the dumping at sea of any radioactive material which has radioactivity in excess of 35 becquerels per gram. This level is an arbitrary one based on the level of activity slightly above that of naturally occurring potassium but which is not potentially harmful to marine biota. The Government maintains that the only international standard which measures potentially harmful levels of radio- activity is in fact the International Atomic Energy Agency formula. This is so complex that it is considered unworkable in decision-making for dumping. Even though the levels of radioactivity allowed are extremely low, the Government's advisers maintain that in the time since the 1981 Act was implemented there has been no dumping application which would have failed the proposed new limits. That is good news.

Whilst this Bill does break new ground and totally bans the dumping of radioactive materials in Australian waters it is, as I said, based on the Treaty obligations and the Treaty provisions in a piece of legislation which I will be voting against for reasons which I will explain when we get to that debate. Nevertheless, I support this Bill.

I am told that the majority of the earth's surface is covered by water and that 97 per cent of the human body is water. A lot of people say that they are aquarians, and I suppose without putting it too simply water is really the fundamental basis of life on this planet. Therefore I think it is fundamental that we are very careful not to do anything to the waters that surround our continent which might-I emphasise the word `might'-endanger future generations. I have said before and I will continue to say that the people who live here today do not own Australia; we are trustees for an asset which we have to pass on to our children and to our children's children, hopefully in a better condition than when it came into our hands.

Many people will have heard of Mr Gordon Barton, the founder of that great corporation, IPEC. Mr Barton, who I have known for many years, developed a practice which, if it were done universally throughout Australia, would make this nation a much more beautiful place. Wherever he and his family went for a picnic he would not leave that picnic area until he had filled the boot of his car with the rubbish that had been left by previous persons visiting that scene. I saw Mr Barton on one occasion actually filling the boot of a Rolls Royce which he was driving on that day. He kept driving along the highway until the boot was absolutely filled. He, his wife and children all participated. I note with pleasure the presence of the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) in the chamber because this falls within his area. Mr Barton said that that was a practical application of a dictum to him by his parents when he was very young to leave any place he went into more beautiful at the time of his departure than it was when he arrived.

TALK.START.PARA: —You always do that when you depart from an area.

—I do not know whether I am being complimented or insulted. We are not on air, so the mass populace will not have the opportunity of judging the Minister's remarks. Those who read Hansard will have to form their own opinion. That was Mr Barton's theory. I now note the presence in the chamber of the honourable member for Kooyong.
—Your leader.

—Indeed. I was speaking a moment ago of the decision that the honourable member and the former Prime Minister took to base in Hobart the International Commission for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources.
—You lobbied me very hard on that issue.

—I did indeed. I must say I will look forward to lobbying the honourable member hard in the future on other issues. I therefore find myself in the position of supporting the principle of the legislation. I repeat the caveat that I added at the beginning; namely, that that does not imply support for the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill which in fact I will be opposing and voting against along with the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: It is wise perhaps when one is dealing with the environment, not in all cases but certainly in the case of a moving material, and water is a moving material, to err on the side of caution, and therefore the total ban has my support. I noted with some interest the speech of the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), who is the shadow Minister and spokesman on the environment in this House, when he said, I thought with some considerable effect, that it was a presumption for us today to believe that all uses of the ocean and the ocean floor are at this moment known to mankind. I will quote what he said because I think it is a very profound statement. He stated:
Consider the possibility that the ocean floor, even at great depths, may some day have enormous value to man.
It would be arrogant in the extreme for us to believe that all possible uses of the sea are known.

What interests me is that that is almost exactly the position in relation to krill. Some 30 years ago nobody had heard of krill except a handful of scientists. Nobody had any idea of the enormous natural resource and the enormous wealth which we have in krill. It is a small organism found in the Southern Ocean, in the Antarctic Ocean as it is more commonly known, which, properly harvested, could feed mankind. It is not an exaggeration to say that krill, properly harvested-there are many tests going on at the moment; indeed, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics is testing somewhat excessively by taking a considerable amount out under the provisions of the Treaty-with its protein high value component added to roughage has a capacity to feed mankind. I say it is something which nobody knew about 30 years ago. I note the presence in the chamber now of the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). That is why I thought the point he made was very valid. It would be quite arrogant for us to presume or assume that we know everything about the sea, the ocean and what it can be for mankind and for the destiny of this planet earth.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is all very fascinating, but what has it to do with the Bill?

—I am sorry the Minister did not realise that it was very related to the Bill because I am indicating my reasons for supporting a total ban of all radioactive material. I thank the Minister for his help. My remarks are not only relevant but also I thought I was delivering them in a very rational, reasonable and persuasive manner.
—As always.

—I thank the honourable member for Bradfield for his comment. Having said the nice things, I just want to say one or two words on the other side of the coin. It is all very well for us to pontificate about our views of protecting the oceans in our region from nuclear or radioactive contamination. I am sick and tired of sections of the Australian Labor Party pontificating to the Australian people about the dangers of the presence in Australian waters of ships belonging to our allies which may be nuclear-powered or nuclear-armed. The thing that staggers me is the deafening silence of the Hawke socialist Government and those who aid and abet it in clinging to office on the involvement of nuclear activity by the Soviet Union in our region. The Minister more than anybody else should realise that the matters I am about to mention just simply cannot be fobbed off. The increased Soviet presence in the South Pacific poses the greatest threat there is to the national security of Australia, and the greatest threat our nation probably will ever have to face. When are we going to hear those champions--

-Order! I point out to the honourable member for Denison that this is not a cognate debate. We are actually debating the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Amendment Bill. I believe that the comments that he is making are pre-empting the next debate which is on the Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill. Would the honourable member please confine his comments to the Bill he is debating?
—Yes, certainly, Madam Deputy Speaker. In fact I had nearly completed my remarks. I shall be speaking on the other Bill. I was conscious of that. I have one minute to go.
—I ask the honourable member to retain those comments until that occasion.

—Yes, I will. I am complaining about the dumping of radioactive material by the Soviet Union in waters some of which come to Australia. I want to refer to two matters which have never been raised in this House before and about which I feel strongly. I wonder why the Hawke socialist Government says nothing about them. The first relates to the recent action of the Soviet Union in test firing SS18 Mark 4 missiles with a range of 1600 kilometres and with 10 warheads, each 50 times more destructive than the Nagasaki weapon, into the vicinity of the Cook Islands, which is not very far from Australia and New Zealand. That matter has been commented upon in national magazines and newspapers. The Bulletin in particular has run a series of articles on the subject. I am still to hear a squeak from the Hawke socialist Government as to what it feels about protecting the environment, namely, the waters adjacent to the Cook Islands, Australia and New Zealand from the deliberate dumping, which is the only way in which one can describe it, of Soviet nuclear missiles. That was the point I wanted to make, because I have nearly concluded my remarks. Here we are pontificating about any radioactive material being dumped in Australian waters. I pointed out in my opening remarks that the level which we had previously set, 35 becquerels per gram, was based on a level of activity slightly above that of naturally occurring potassium-that is salt in ordinary language-but which is not potentially harmful to marine biota.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the more worrying for the future of mankind-that sort of level, or Soviet SS18 Mark 4 missiles with a range of 1600 kilometres and with 10 warheads each 50 times more destructive than the Nagasaki weapon? If one is to have a go at radioactive materials getting into our area, I think something should be done about that aspect. Finally, I would point out that those who complain about nuclear-propelled vessels which are part of the forces of our ally the United States of America coming into our waters say not a word about Soviet nuclear-propelled vessels in the Southern Ocean, the Antarctic Ocean and the fishing waters of Kiribati. There has been too much double-speak and I will reserve my further comments, which will be even stronger, for the debate that follows in which I shall be honoured to follow the honourable member of Kooyong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALKER.NAME: Mr COHEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the support from both sides of the House for the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Amendment Bill. Clearly it is not a Bill on which there is a lot of controversy, and it has general support. I wish to respond briefly to a number of points that have been raised in the debate. Not all the points referred to the dumping of waste at sea, which is strictly defined in the context of the conventions, treaties and agreements concerned. The Bill relates to the discharge of waste or other matter from a vessel, aircraft or platforms into the sea for the purpose for disposal.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh) referred to the code of practice for the safe transport of radioactive substances in 1982. This code was formulated under the provisions of the Environment Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act 1978 which was enacted under the Fraser Government and makes no provision for mandatory enforcement in the States, as the honourable member suggested. Since it is a matter within the responsibility of my portfolio, I am able to say that the transport code is being revised in the light of new regulations for the safe transport of radioactive material published by the International Atomic Energy Agency in 1985. When revised, I anticipate its satisfactory implementation by all States and the Northern Territory. Meanwhile my Department is continuing to co-ordinate with State and Territory authorities in the implementation of the code.

The honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) made a number of references to the Soviet Union and its dumping practices in the high seas. He also mentioned the whole nuclear involvement of the Soviet Union in a number of respects. This matter should really be raised in the debate on the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill. Australia has no jurisdiction to control activities of foreign countries on the high seas. The honourable member mentioned the actions of the Soviet Union in the vicinity of the Cook Islands; by virtue of ratifying the Treaty Australia, with other nations, will achieve those objectives. The honourable member will be able to raise those matters in the next debate.

This is not a complex Bill. It seeks to amend the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act. I think that all matters have been carefully canvassed. The legislation will prohibit the dumping of nuclear waste at levels over 35 becquerels per gram in Australian waters and by Australian ships. That is all it sets out to achieve and is what it will do. I thank honourable members for their support.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Cohen) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOUTH PACIFIC NUCLEAR FREE ZONE TREATY BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 June, on motion by Mr Hayden:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is not prepared to support the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill, which gives legislative sanction to the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. We have determined not to support this Bill notwithstanding our concern with the questions of waste and dumping in the South Pacific, both of which we have strenuously opposed and sought to prohibit during our period in government and on which we have given the Government support. We have chosen to vote against this legislation because of the constraints that this Bill will have on Australia's security and its impact on our allies, for reasons that I shall enunciate.

SPEECH.PARA: I stress, however, that the measures relating to the prohibition of nuclear weapons testing and nuclear waste dumping in the South Pacific have always been strongly maintained by the Opposition. I believe that a stronger and more viable alternative exists other than inclusion in this Treaty. Prohibition of nuclear testing and nuclear waste dumping in the region ought to be removed from this Treaty, predicated as it is and enshrined in domestic legislation and in a separate international covenant. I have read for some time how this Treaty was brought about by the activities of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at the South Pacific Forum. We are rather used to latter-day commentators and historians ignoring the genesis of most of these matters. In fact, the genesis of this Treaty occurred in the late 1970s when the former Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, and I attended a South Pacific Forum meeting. Mr Anthony, strongly opposed also to the dumping of waste and the testing of nuclear explosive devices in the South Pacific, suggested that we should consider the possibility of having a treaty to prohibit those two matters. That was the genesis. It was subsequent to that and after the election of a Labor government that this devious group opposite saw in this proposal the opportunity to coddle their consciences with a treaty proposal that would allegedly declare a nuclear free zone. From that developed the concept that causes us concern for reasons that strike at our security.

In his second reading speech the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) said that the Treaty was `the authentic and collective voice of the South Pacific region'. Well, it is not. It is a treaty that is not wanted at all by some and there are others who want even more than is covered by the Treaty. The Minister told the House that the Treaty had been `welcomed by the international community'. Well, it has not. It has not even been welcomed by our friends. I have not read one congratulatory message from any of our Western allies. I have read a strong message of support from the Soviet Union. It may be that in the minds of some this represents the international community, but it does not to members on this side of the House.

At this stage the United States has reversed its position as to whether it will sign the protocols. My feeling is that, experiencing the difficulties that it is in a diplomatic and trade sense in negotiating fisheries agreements with island states of the South Pacific, the United States by the end of the year may well feel that it should sign these protocols. It is capable of withdrawing from the provisions at any stage and I feel that down the line it may well sign them. Nothing that the Opposition has determined in terms of opposition to the Bill will be qualified by the United States not being a member state here, but nevertheless signing a protocol. It has not got to that point and it may decide not to. My own inkling is to assume that the United States may sign it. That does not qualify one whit the concerns that I will put today in relation to the Treaty.

I have said that this Treaty could weaken, not strengthen, our security. The Treaty and this implementing legislation are, in my view, inconsistent with our national security interests. The prohibitions of the Treaty on Australia's freedom of action will apply irrespective of any future shifts in the balance of military and strategic forces in our region, or indeed in the world. Regardless of how critical it may be to our own survival that at some future time we may wish to provide facilities such as home porting to our allies, such an arrangement will be forbidden by the Treaty. We would not be able to do this even if we were at war and our national survival was at stake because the Treaty is to remain in force indefinitely.

There are some who believe-and I gave some consideration to this as a recommendation of the Opposition because of my strong views in favour of prohibiting dumping of nuclear waste and nuclear weapons testing in the South Pacific-that perhaps in this chamber we should indicate our concerns but then vote for the Bill. But the more I considered it the more I recognised that we could prohibit those two factors that I have mentioned both domestically and by international treaty and that that would be the proper course of action rather than allowing measures prohibiting them to go through at such enormous cost to our security. The reality is that when this treaty Bill has legislative effect, it may in circumstances override ANZUS. Is there anyone who would then, on balance, say that our desire to prohibit the dumping of waste and our opposition to nuclear testing should be embraced notwithstanding that consequence? Peter Henderson, who was formerly Secretary of the Department of Foreign Affairs, stated recently in words that I thought were rather apt:

We would have done better to have said openly to the island governments that for overriding defence reasons, involving the maintenance of their own security as well as Australia's that a real nuclear free zone simply cannot be reconciled with our mutually shared interests.

In foreign policy the duty of governments is significant, is it not? It is to plan against long term contingencies and to do nothing which might compromise our national security. The Treaty in this Bill denies the likelihood of a deteriorating regional environment and the consequences that would have for us. The legislation before us would fetter our ability to respond to what could be a radically altered strategic environment.

For so long the South Pacific has been a quiescent region with tiny micro states, now states in their own right. Hitherto, in the main, they were colonial territories which in recent times achieved their own independence. That does not apply to all of them, particularly New Caledonia which is still a French colonial territory. But in the main those British interests and others have moved towards a path of self-government and independence. It has been a quiescent region. However, there are now emerging trouble spots and some political turbulence which may pose a threat in the long term to vital Australian and broader Western interests. Complacency is the last thing that we need. Taking the wider Pacific region itself, the same concerns apply. I might add that for over 30 years regional order and stability, consistent with the interests of the free world and the successful denial of Soviet access, have been achieved through an effective management role performed by Australia and New Zealand and ultimately depending on United States underwriting of the area's security. Recent developments have injected a new volatility into the region, placing greater strains-indeed very significant strains-on existing alliance security arrangements. From Australia's viewpoint these developments could result in further deterioration of our political and strategic environment.

The New Zealand Government's refusal to allow port access to any United States nuclear armed or powered vessels has unquestionably greatly encouraged the Soviet Union and its proxies to upgrade their interests and involvement in this area. I have recited in this House before statements made by Mr Dibb, who has given advice to this Government on defence planning and defence matters, in which he has drawn attention to the long term desire of the Soviets to break up ANZUS. That is not just our view, it is the view of a significant adviser to the Labor Government. As he has put in different words, the Soviets have been interested in the unravelling of ANZUS to the extent that that would assist their own longer term interests. Thus, fundamental Soviet objectives have been the unravelling of ANZUS, the decoupling of Australia, New Zealand and South Pacific countries from the Western alliance and the erosion of the deep seated positive sentiments towards Australia and the United States.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whose side is the Prime Minister on?

—Oh well, on this issue of ANZUS you will recall that the only action that the Prime Minister took was to write a letter to Prime Minister Lange early last year and when it was leaked to the newspapers he ran away from it. Honourable members will recall that I described that letter in this House in great detail. As I said on that occasion, it was a letter to Lange from Shorty. The New Zealand Government's action, which Soviet radio asserted might act as `a chain reaction leading to the collapse of the ANZUS bloc', must be seen in the context of other regional tensions. In this increasingly unsettled environment within that broader region, Soviet power and activity continue to increase in the Indian Ocean, South East Asia and the North Pacific. The Soviet push for on-shore and port facilities in the South West Pacific increases with even greater success and Soviet naval power continues to grow dramatically in the Pacific region. In fact, the Soviet Pacific fleet represents 35 per cent of its naval assets and is the largest of its four fleets.
—The most modern, too.

—Indeed. It possesses more than 800 modern surface ships and submarines. Cam Ranh Bay is the Soviet Union's largest base outside the Warsaw Pact. What little over a decade ago was a major American base is now the nerve centre for the Soviet Union's largest naval fleet. Its capacity to project that power to the region about which we are talking-this so-called nuclear free zone of the South West Pacific-is undeniable. It is just no good drawing a map and saying that henceforth this is a nuclear free zone, when the super-power has a capacity to project the sort of power about which I am talking into that region. The capacity is there, it is undenied. Honourable members opposite may like to wish that away, but it is just that-wishful thinking.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no wonder that the Soviets have so embraced this Government's South Pacific nuclear free zone. It restricts the United States-the only weapons state to deploy in the defined zone-yet the Soviet Union's power base at Cam Ranh Bay will be unaffected. It is not correct, therefore, to say that the United States can project power into this part of the world from Subic Bay and Clark, so that gives it a balance. It is the consistent approach of people on the other side to produce this form of moral equation or power equation in terms of saying: `Well, if the Soviets are there, it is balanced by the Americans'. We are not in the business of equating the Soviet Union with the United States; that is the harsh, underlying reality of our approach to international relations. We affirm our place as an ally of the United States and in the broader Western alliance and have no truck with this moral or other equivalence argument which seeks to put them on the same pedestal.

Until recently the Soviet Union accepted that the effectiveness of the Western alliance system, embodying ANZUS, constituted an effective deterrence system inimical to the intrusion of its strategic interest in the area. Now it has perceived that, the ANZUS lake is no more. A major Soviet goal to undermine the pro-Western alliance system in the region is undoubtedly succeeding. It is in this context that the Soviets have welcomed the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty and it is in this context that we have to look at the legislation we are being asked to ratify today. We ought to have no illusions about that. While Soviet penetration and actual gains are still restricted in the South West Pacific region, it is important that we appreciate the opportunity that increased regional destabilisation has given the Soviets. It is also crucial that we focus attention on the fundamental issues at stake. The South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty and this Bill fail to do that. I refer the House to clauses 11 and 15 of the Bill, which are of particular concern. Clause 11 states:
A person who stations, or does any act or thing to facilitate the stationing of, a nuclear explosive device in Australia is guilty of an offence . . .

The Treaty defines stationing as including `transportation on land or inland waters, stockpiling, storage, installation and deployment'. This is an extraordinarily wide definition that in effect could strait-jacket successive Australian governments from offering home porting facilities to the United States Navy or base facilities to the United States nuclear-capable aircraft or nuclear-capable ground units. It is not the argument of the Opposition that we want to stockpile nuclear weapons in this country, but we will not abide a clause which says that in time of peril to this country, need, war or a threat to our security, if our allies want to enter our ports-home port, if one likes-or deploy troops, they will be forbidden to do so by this Bill because of the definition clause defining stationing as including transportation on land or inland waters and deployment. If we were in the perilous situation of asking the United States to come to our aid, is it to be thought that this legislation is to override ANZUS?

I will not mention the very significant figure opposite to whom I went and discussed this matter on one occasion. I said to him: `I am deeply concerned that in a time of crisis for this country, this legislation will override ANZUS'. He said to me: `Yes, that may be so, but of course we would ignore it.' What a great safeguard, a great fallback. I said to him: `You may not be around at the time. I have to proffer viewpoints, programs and policies for my Party and in government on foreign policy terms for the security of my nation. I am not going to have some Mickey Mouse proposal overriding my country's most basic defence treaty, nor is my conscience eased because you tell me you will ignore the legislation'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that Old Silver?

—I am not prepared to indicate who it was. He accepted my argument, but he was not prepared to go on with it because of the internecine fighting. To keep the Left happy we have this.
