This is an extraordinarily wide definition which could strait-jacket successive Australian governments from offering home porting facilities to the United States Navy or base facilities to the United States nuclear-capable aircraft or nuclear-capable ground units. It applies to all our allies. The same applies to nuclear-capable or nuclear-powered British vessels as well. Indeed, the United Kingdom is part of the five-power arrangements with us and is a direct ally, quite apart from its membership of the Western alliance. In the event of war this treaty would continue to apply and would, in law at least, prevent us from offering such facilities to the United States or other allies. The legislation could also be interpreted as being at odds with the United States Government's policy to neither confirm nor deny whether its vessels or aircraft are carrying nuclear weapons.

SPEECH.PARA: Similarly, clause 15 of this Bill allows the presence of nuclear explosive devices on foreign ships visiting or navigating in or through Australian waters or on visiting aircraft, but restricts this to apply only to transiting movements. As such, it specifically denies the deterioriating regional stability to which I referred and would severely limit our future options. Whilst the United States would lose its options, which under certain circumstances might be absolutely vital for our defences, the Soviet Union, interestingly enough, would have no restrictions on its nuclear stationing in places such as Cam Ranh Bay because its nuclear threat to the whole South Pacific remains totally unconstrained by the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty.

There is a further problem with the Treaty; that is, once the Treaty exists and implementing legislation is enacted, it can be extended. Time and again we have heard demands that this Bill does not go far enough. In fact, one island state of the Pacific thinks the Bill does not go far enough. Beyond a smaller island state are our friends, the New Zealand people-regrettably governed by others who could not be described in quite such friendly terms, the current New Zealand Government--

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you suggesting that that Government is not supported by the majority of New Zealanders?

—I will answer the Minister's question. The Government was supported at the last election by the majority, but I do not assess what is in the interests of my country on the basis of some vote in another nation. My duty is not to respond to what some left wing government in New Zealand wants. My duty is to do what is right in Australia. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs can sit in the chamber with his pack appealing all he likes to his lefties who walked out last night. This Government's duty ought to be to the security of this country and it should not be bowing and scraping to a left wing government across the Tasman. The sooner it gets that right the sooner we might have a more effective ANZUS. If I reply in fulsome terms it is because I am sick to death of hearing from the Government that ANZUS problems revolve around us being kind and gentle to New Zealand. They do not. We could have fixed that problem if we told the New Zealand people that they could not have it both ways. But this Government was too gutless to do that. It thought it could ride along with their nonsense, that they could stay within ANZUS but not allow our allies to enter into their ports. I am sorry to sidetrack on that. I am not here to abide by the vote of the New Zealand people. I am an Australian and my duty is to this country and to our own defence.
—You are not answering my question.
—Order! I suggest that the honourable member for Kooyong ignore the interjections.
—Ignore the Kiwi lovers.

—I love the New Zealand people, the Government that they have will not last beyond the next election, but far be it from me to interfere in the domestic affairs of another nation. I have already talked of what transpires when we put something down. There is always some bunny who suggests that it has not gone far enough. The Government's left wing here has said that already and Prime Minister Lange is now saying that. He has already declared that frequent Australian port visits by United States warships could be interpreted as `stationing' and that is disallowed by the Treaty. Interestingly enough, others have suggested that our export of uranium could be in violation of the Treaty. This schizophrenic Government has done the right thing in regard to the export of uranium to France but it will duck and weave on this question. I can see this Bill being debated for the next week or two. I will lay any money that honourable members opposite would like it to be dealt with by tomorrow.
—The honourable member for Hughes says that it is against the treaty.

—That is right. Prime Minister Lange said that the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty was an important first step towards prohibiting nuclear maritime passage or deployment of submarines. As the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) has indicated, it does not take much imagination to see how the left wing of the Australian Labor Party, over time, will insist that the Treaty is further radicalised. The underlying assumptions of the report of the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities, the Government's about-face over assisting with the MX missile tests, its rejection of the United States invitation to participate in strategic defence initiative research, its opposition to the United States strategic modernisation and now the steerage of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty are fundamentally weakening our own participation in the Western alliance and providing an opportunity for others to exploit and decrease our own security in this region. We are profoundly worried about the direction that is being taken by this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me just go back to those aspects of the Bill that relate to the dumping of nuclear waste and nuclear testing in the region. As I began, let me reiterate that the Opposition supports the aspirations of the region to ban nuclear testing and the dumping of nuclear waste in the region but we are of the firm view that these aspects, currently incorporated in the treaty Bill, can be legislatively and internationally enshrined without undermining our security environment. We recommend strongly that a separate international convention relating to the dumping of nuclear waste be negotiated. I suggest that such a protocol would be better pursued separately since it would be easier to persuade the nuclear powers to accept restrictions on their high seas freedoms in relation to dumping rather than as a subsidiary part of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty to which they clearly have reservations on other grounds. Indeed, I also maintain that the verification and control procedures, as presently described in the Treaty, are actually inadequate for detecting covert dumping of radioactive waste within the region and it leaves open the question of land-based waste disposal. A separate protocol, a stronger one relating to nuclear waste disposal, would be both emvironmentally and strategically better. Similarly, our opposition to nuclear testing in the region is well known. In place of those clauses in the Treaty, consideration could also be given to a further, separate convention.

So there is some clarity as to where the Opposition stands. We reject the Bill because it compromises our security. It compromises it by severely restricting our future options. We believe that nuclear testing and nuclear waste dumping should be addressed as separate protocols. We are quite prepared to argue that in any forum. I am sure that we would get almost unanimous support for that-let us exclude one well known continental nation-and be able to police both matters far more effectively if major powers did not feel that they were so constrained with the other elements of this Treaty. If the Government follows the Opposition's lead it would have a more vigilant approach on dumping and on testing, which we oppose. As I have said, we would have separate international conventions dealing with those matters and we would be able to have verification and control procedures which would be stronger than those that are currently in this treaty.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with you on dumping.
—We should have done that on dumping.
—I agree with that.

—I am glad to hear that the honourable member does because I am not seeking to play politics on the issue. As I have said, it was a matter that we sought to approach when we were in government and, regrettably, it got caught up with this larger Mickey Mouse proposal which, as I have said, has the capacity however to arise to a shape greater than Walt Disney produced. We are unprepared to see any diminution of our national security. On balance, we are opposed to the Bill. I say `on balance' solely because I would have liked to have supported the propositions on waste and on testing. But I believe that the better approach is to oppose this Bill, to argue for stronger measures on waste and dumping and not to compromise this nation's security in regard to our duties, our obligations and our opportunities under our alliances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am privileged to be able to participate in the debate on the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill tonight. Let me say at the outset that I welcome the reference by the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) to Moscow because that subject is part of the contribution that I wish to make to the House tonight. Perhaps following my contribution the honourable member for Denison will be a little wiser about what is really happening in the world in the move towards nuclear disarmament and the promotion of world peace.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an extremely important piece of legislation. As I have mentioned on a previous occasion, if it receives a speedy passage in the Senate it will be a world first because we will be, as the Australian Government and the Australian people, the first country in the world ever to pass a law which will have the effect of banning testing of nuclear weapons, of banning the permanent stationing of nuclear weapons and, importantly, sending a signal to the world and to our neighbours that we will never acquire nuclear weapons for ourselves. For that reason I believe that this legislation ought to command the support of all members of this Parliament, not just the members of the Australian Labor Party.

I believe that it is appropriate to draw to the attention of this House the history of this legislation. I am not one of those people-I do not believe my colleagues are either-who seek to make this issue a single and narrow partisan party political one because it is well known that another party represented in the Parliament and another senator support the thrust of this legislation. If that be the case I give them credit for their past initiatives and I hope that they will give, in whatever form they deem appropriate, their continuing support to these initiatives.

Having said that let there be no mistaking that this piece of legislation is a creature of the Australian Labor Party. It is one of the most widely discussed pieces of legislation that has come before this Parliament in the history of the Hawke Labor Government. It is a product of consensus and a product of the unanimous sup- port of all members of the Australian Labor Party, and I think that needs to be put on the record.

The Australian Government has led the way with the implementation of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. I shall address myself shortly to some of the comments of the shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs about his perception of the lack of support that this treaty has received in international forums. Let me first of all for the record go through the outline the Bill. It seeks to give domestic legislative effect to certain of Australia's obligations under the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. I was privileged to be in Rarotonga on the occasion when the Treaty was concluded, and honourable member will be aware that the Treaty has received wide support throughout the world.

The Bill is supplemented by proposed amendments to the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act relating to the dumping of radioactive wastes and the provisions of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Bill relating to the application of safeguards to nuclear material, which cover Treaty obligations referred to but not provided for in this Bill.

Importantly, the Bill establishes offences relating to the manufacture, production and acquisition of nuclear weapons, research and development relating to the manufacture or production of nuclear weapons, the possession or control of nuclear weapons, the stationing of nuclear weapons in Australia and the testing of nuclear weapons. It also makes it an offence to commit any act which facilitates the manufacture, production, acquisiton or testing of nuclear weapons, extends these provisions beyond Australian territory in certain circumstances and provides appropriately severe penalties for the offences.

The Bill establishes the legislative framework for inspection in Australia by Treaty inspectors as required by the Treaty, and provides for the appointment by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) of authorised officers to accompany and assist international inspectors while they are in Australia. I believe that this is an important feature of the Bill. It means that it is not dependent on Australians alone for enforcement. It will set up an international regime which we hope will be followed and supported by all other countries which are parties to the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. The inspectors from the Australian Safeguards Office are provided with powers to assist the Treaty inspector and authorised officers in carrying out the Treaty inspections.

I emphasise that the enforcement of the Bill, in my opinion, could be improved. I take the view, as have many of my colleagues over a long period, that as much legislation of this Parliament as possible should confer standing on citizens of this country to enable them to ensure that the provisions of the laws of the Australian Parliament are complied with. While I strongly support the Bill, I hope that in future years the sentiments of the Australian Law Reform Commission, which strongly support the views that I have expressed today, will be followed and that the Bill will be amended accordingly.

The Bill is expressed to apply to the Crown in right of the Commonwealth, each of the States and the Northern Territory, and the prohibitions contained in the second part of the Bill bind the Commonwealth. Clause 7 further provides that the Commonwealth is not liable to prosecution for breach, but the prohibition is nevertheless enforceable against the Commonwealth or its agencies by way of a prohibitive injunction, which requires the person against whom it is issued to refrain from undertaking certain acts. Such an injunction could be obtained by a private individual if the individual can show that the Commonwealth's action involves the invasion of a private right of his or her that is recognised in law or equity, or by the Attorney-General if the action involves the invasion of a public right. The Attorney-General may act either on his own motion or in relation to a private individual.

I emphasise in addition that, although the Commonwealth may have an immunity from prosecution under the statute, its servants can commit crimes against the statute in certain circumstances. If the Commonwealth is immune from the statute as a whole, a Commonwealth servant acting in the course of his or her duties will share this immunity. If, on the other hand, the Commonwealth is immune only from the penal provisions of the statute but is bound by the rest of it, as in this case, Commonwealth servants are obliged to comply with the statute and may be held criminally liable for failure to comply.

Subject to the preliminary comments that I have made, the legislation creates offences that are binding on servants of the Commonwealth. Effectively it sets up a regime that no future Australian Government will ever be able to ignore.

In the course of the comments made by the shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs it was suggested that there had not been support for this concept in other forums throughout the world. I draw the attention of honourable members to the position of Indonesia. There has been a great deal of debate in recent times about Indonesia and its perceived threat to Australia or otherwise. I could not think of a more effective way of sending a signal to Indonesia that this country is not intent upon waging war in future and is committed to a policy of peace than the passage of the Bill. It is clear that, despite the sentiments expressed by the shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs, Indonesia shares the view of the Australian Labor Party Government on this issue.

Honourable members ought to know that the Association of South East Asian Nations, ASEAN, has decided to draft as soon as possible a treaty to create a nuclear weapon free zone in the region and that Indonesia is the main advocate of that zone. ASEAN Foreign Ministers at their annual meeting instructed senior officials and a working group to produce a comprehensive definition of the principles, objectives and elements involved. They noted with `special interest the conclusion of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty'. The Indonesian Foreign Minister, Dr Mochtar, the outgoing Chairman, made a strong plea for action on the zone in his opening address. He said:

The intensified arms race is diverting scarce resources and scientific talent towards destructive purposes instead of towards a revitalised world economy and accelerated economic progress for the developing nations.

He said that the global nuclear threat was holding hostage all nations, including the members of ASEAN, to the perceived security interests of a few nuclear weapon states. If the Leader of the Opposition had bothered to read the second reading speech of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, he would know that it is not only Indo- nesia and ASEAN that have expressed support for the Bill. In September last year, at the third review conference of the Non-Proliferation Treaty, in its final declaration welcomed the achievement of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty as consistent with article 7 of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. In October 1985, the communique issued by the 46 Commonwealth Heads of Government, following their meeting in the Bahamas, welcomed the Treaty as follows:
. . . an important step in global and regional efforts to prevent nuclear proliferation.

That is hardly a fringe organisation. The members of that organisation, ranging across countries and including members of the Western alliance, non-aligned countries and a whole cross-section of world opinion, have recognised the importance of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty, and this Bill forms an important part of this Government's strategy.

I turn to the Liberal Party's view about this Bill. There are people in the Liberal Party-decent people-who believe that the only moral position on this Bill that should be adopted by true Liberals is one of support. Unfortunately they are not in the majority and so we have an attempt by the shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), to resurrect Cold War rhetoric of the 1950s. He has talked about the perceived Soviet threat in the South Pacific and, if he had his way, he would have us believe that we were about to be subjected to some imminent invasion or threat by the Soviet Union. I direct his attention to the answers given by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs to questions that I have placed on the Notice Paper concerning the presence of Soviet naval vessels in the area covered by the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. The Minister said that there has been no record of a sighting of a single Soviet naval vessel in the whole of the area covered by the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty in either 1985 or 1986. I intend to pursue this matter further. However, one can hardly argue that such a statement by the Ministers of this Government could give rise to the notion of any Soviet threat. It is just rubbish.

The shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs, the honourable member for Kooyong, on this and other occasions has raised the actions of the small, usually impoverished island states of the South Pacific which are alleged to be jumping into bed with the Soviet Union because they have the gall to enter into commercial trading arrangements with it. Perhaps Australians will no longer accept those arguments as having any veracity, because, although the reported move by Vanuatu to establish some form of diplomatic relations with Libya is a relatively recent event which Australia should watch with interest, let it never be forgotten that it was the honourable member for Kooyong himself who established diplomatic relations between Australia and Libya. So if there is a Libyan connection in this country's Parliament it would have to be the honourable member for Kooyong. So let us have some balanced debate about the question of Soviet presence in the South Pacific because, after the action of the United States of America of selling subsidised produce to the Soviet Union to the detriment of all Australians and particularly the primary producers, it can no longer be possible for anyone to attack with credibility those small island states for getting the best possible deal for their fish and other resources.

I also asked another question, question No. 2948, of the Minister for Defence. I asked him whether or not any past government had opposed a nuclear component for the Australian Defence Force and whether there was any time in the past when a government had supported nuclear weapons being acquired by Australia. Of course, in accordance with the precedent of past governments, the Minister stated that he was not aware specifically, not having access to the Cabinet records of previous governments. But he highlighted a very important point that ought to be reiterated today: That it would be surprising if consideration had not been given by one or more of the Australian governments in the period between 1945 and the ratification of the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons in 1973 to this question of the costs of acquiring a nuclear capability. Let it be remembered that it was not the conservative parties which signed the non-proliferation treaty, but in fact the Whitlam Labor Government.

As I move towards the conclusion of the remarks tonight, I want to refer to what I believe to be the primary force that led to the Bill being introduced into this Parliament. It is to the credit of the Australian Labor Party, and especially to the credit of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, that they have responded to a certain force. That force was the power and the commitment of people in the peace movement in Australia, not just people in the Labor Party but people ranging right across the social and political spectrum. Let me tell the honourable member for Kooyong that a whole generation of people have had enough of phoney politicians. They have had enough of the cynicism and initiatives of politicians who do not make a real contribution to world peace and disarmament. They supported the enactment of this particular piece of legislation and it is to the credit of this Government that it has responded.

Let me also say in relation to the question of uranium that I know that other speakers on this Bill and other members of the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party, both in private and in public, have expressed their heartfelt and sincere view that Australian uranium ought not to be exported to France. I would be a weak and ineffective person if I did not on this occasion also reiterate my strongly held moral views on that issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —If it is that strong, will you vote against the Budget?

—If this provides some opportunity for the Opposition to make some short term cynical capital, let me tell honourable members opposite again that the Australian people are too smart. The peace movement knows what the Liberal Party of Australia would do in respect of Star Wars; it knows that it would support deep Australian involvement in MX testing. It knows of the Liberals' opposition to the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. What the people want is a principled stand by the Australian Labor Party and by all members of this Parliament in one of the most important moral and political issues of our time. I commend the Minister for Foreign Affairs and my own Party for their support for the peace movement as exemplified by the introduction of this historic legislation, a first for Australia and a first for the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just like to take up the remarks of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner), and remind him that he has a unique opportunity actually to demonstrate that he means what he says. He got up and lectured us about great moral imperatives, suggesting that this is one of the great moral decisions of the age. He has this terrific moral position about the exportation of uranium. He has a unique opportunity in this Parliament to demonstrate the strength of his moral commitment. I will have a couple of bob on the side that his rhetoric is far in advance of his actions. It is typical of the people from the Australian Labor Party to get up and pontificate about these sorts of matters. However, when it comes to the real test, when the pressure is really put on them, when they have an opportunity to stand up in public and vote on the issue, just watch them-they will scuttle out the door. I bet that if he is not in the House at the time he will be outside, not standing up the way he demonstrated today in his flowery talk about great moral issues. We will not see any of that.

SPEECH.PARA: At least three of his colleagues last night during the Budget Speech got up and walked out of the House. I did not notice the honourable member who just sat down walk out of the House to demonstrate his great moral commitment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am walking out now.

—He is now walking out of the House because he knows that when the pressure really comes on he will go along with the Party line because his bread and butter is determined by that. He has now walked out of the House because he is not even prepared to defend himself after having made the usual flowery statements which we hear from the left wing of the Labor Party. That is all they are-flowery statements. There is no real commitment. When the test comes they will vote in accordance with the Party line because that is the way in which their party endorsement is decided; that is where their bread and butter is decided.

SPEECH.PARA: The South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill 1986 is a Government effort to appease its left wing. We have just heard one of its members in this House mouthing the usual sorts of platitudes. At the same time it is an attempt to appease the political forces behind the communist-organised Pacific Trade Union Forum. The reality is that this is a unilateral measure which has only one effect and we should not forget what that effect is. It will encumber United States foreign and defence policy in the Pacific. The Labor Party came to power with a great deal of ignorance about the politics of the Pacific, except in so far as what was communicated to it by the left wing trade union leaders who were active in the Pacific Trade Union Forum.

Let us remind ourselves about the Pacific Trade Union Forum. It was organised by pro-Soviet trade unionists who are also affiliated with the World Federation of Trade Unions, and it is specifically directed at agitation designed to embarrass United States relations throughout the Pacific. The key New Zealand figures in it are also key figures in the Labour Party in New Zealand which, as we have no need to remind ourselves, has thrown out the ANZUS Treaty and placed United States-New Zealand relations in crisis. That is not too strong a word to use about the present relationship between the United States and New Zealand. The Pacific Trade Union Forum has been a principal instrument of agitation for a nuclear free zone.

Of course, the Forum's supporters are not satisfied with this treaty because it leads each participating nation to decide whether to accept visits by nuclear-armed or nuclear-powered ships. Article 5 of the treaty states:
Each party in the exercise of its sovereign rights remains free to decide for itself whether to allow visits by foreign ships and aircraft to its ports and airfields.

This has a number of predictable effects. First, it will focus political hostility on United States defence arrangements. The United States is to be regarded as a figure of suspicion. The treaty is saying: `If you want to pick on the United States, as New Zealand has done, go ahead and do so. We will even legislate to make that a valid exercise'. That is the real political effect of this document. Secondly, it is an open invitation to the Pacific Trade Union Forum, which I remind the House is a Soviet supported institution, to continue its propaganda war against the United States. Thirdly, and perhaps most importantly, it binds Australia internationally to the proposition that no facilities will be accorded to the United States which involve nuclear arms maintenance. That is the effect of it. It freezes the United States into a situation where it is required to look to other non-treaty areas in the Pacific if, for example, it should be forced out of the Philippines.

I mention the Philippines because the reality is that the United States bases there are under some political pressure which results from the present nature of Philippines politics. Those bases do a singular service to the security of the Pacific and Indian oceans. They are a prime political target and are made more exposed by this treaty. I wonder whether the Government wishes that to occur.

The United States has placed very important defence reservations into its constitutional relations with island governments in the mid-Pacific. The United States base at Guam is a vital link in the security chain. The significance of that chain has been remarked upon by Mr Caspar Weinberger, when he said that seven defence agreements to which the United States is a signatory are located in that chain. They include bilateral treaties with Japan, Korea and the Philippines, the residuals of the Manila pact which involves Thailand and the in-limbo ANZUS Treaty. He pointed out that over $US137 billion of trade in the Pacific accounts for almost 30 per cent of United States foreign trade. In effect, he says that the security of the United States has become increasingly interdependent on the security of each of its Pacific allies. Thus the linking of mid-Pacific politics with south-west Pacific politics is a dynamic which will carry important implications for the stability of United States relations with its mid-Pacific partners.

It is vital that this rash of anti-Americanism, which is emanating particularly at the moment from New Zealand, be contained. It is very doubtful whether, by meeting it half way, as this Government does, it will do anything more than aggravate the issue. I wonder whether that is what the Government wants to do.

I remind the House that the present United States Consul-General in Sydney, Mr John Dorrance, is a much-respected official who is authoritative on Pacific questions. He wrote an article which was published in 1984, and he pointed out that, in an emergency, the United States lines of communication in the Pacific would tend to move south out of the range of Soviet aircraft. He went on to make the point that the security of the former Pacific trust territories is a United States responsibility under the constitutional settlement that now governs them. The stability of that political relationship between the United States and island governments is important not only for the United States but for Australia. There are grave doubts that the pressures from the Soviets for a politics of agitation in the Pacific will be anything but increased by this treaty.

We heard from the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) that the Soviet Union is benign, that we have not seen any Soviet vessels around, and we need not worry about it and that there is no immediate threat of a Soviet takeover. I have heard that sort of talk for so long that it is becoming very repetitive. There is no looking ahead in that attitude whatsoever. Because a Soviet vessel has not been sighted in the Pacific during the past three weeks, two years or whatever it is, we are asked to believe that, in the longer term, nothing will happen. It is really leaving us hostage to fortune, and it is not good enough for any government charged with the responsibility of maintaining the security of this nation to have that sort of head-in-the-sand attitude.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Hughes is very short-sighted, too.

—He may be; he is certainly short-sighted politically. Essentially, the outlook of the treaty is neutralist. It says in effect that the Pacific can opt out of the great issue of maintaining strategic balance by going it alone in a nuclear-free zone. As an enticement to the United States to sign the protocols, the Pacific Forum has provided the option of opting out if there is an adverse change in the strategic situation. So the Australian Government is uneasy about the effect on the Indian-Pacific security system, but it has now gone too far to back off.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem is that this treaty throws an onus on the United States to prove its bona fides, but it does nothing to make explicit legitimate concerns about the Soviet outreach in the Pacific. The concerns arise from the political, economic and military activities of the Soviet Union. Economic pressures are evident in the desire of Pacific island governments to move closer to the Soviet Union by settling fishing arrangements with it. And it is true that there has been a certain concern expressed by this Government at these arrangements. Politically, the existence of this treaty reflects something of the agitation sponsored by Soviet propaganda, and the fact is that New Zealand has already been heavily impacted politically through its policies on nuclear-armed and powered vessels.

But the basic thrust of Soviet power is to neutralise the power of the United States fleet to support the security system of its alliances in Japan, South East Asia, and, of course, into the Indian Ocean and the Middle East. The Soviet Union has the asset of being able to secure the assistance of anti-United States political agitation in this country and in New Zealand, with the consequence that the real significance of ascendant Soviet power is downplayed. We heard a classic example of that in the speech by the honourable member for Hughes.

Let us have a look at the facts, because they are fairly stark. In the Melbourne Age Supplement on Defence 86, the Commander-in-Chief United States Pacific Command, Admiral Ronald Hays, argued quite sensibly that Moscow realises that democracy, peace and economic well-being among the Pacific nations will thwart Soviet regional ambitions. A stable environment, he thinks, is fundamental to the United States interests. I believe that this treaty has placed Australian diplomatic efforts in the wrong direction and instead of encouraging confidence in the United States intentions does exactly the opposite and feeds on prospects of instability. Admiral Hays listed the following Russian developments of significance:
A Far Eastern theatre nuclear force that fields one-third of their SS-20 missile inventory.
80 backfire bombers capable of striking targets throughout the Pacific with either nuclear or conventional weapons.
An increase over the past two decades from 20 to 50 modern mobile combat divisions.
In the occupied Japanese northern territories, improved and permanent military bases supporting more capable aircraft and nuclear-capable modern missiles.
A Far East arsenal of more than 1,700 sophisticated tactical combat planes, to include the latest MIG31 and SU27.
A rapidly growing Pacific armada-the largest of their four fleets. In fact, the Pacific fleet contains a third of their naval assets.

Those facts would not be disputed by any respectable analyst, but the question might well be asked: `Why does this information have to be made available to Australian public opinion through a United States source?' Why has not the Government alerted the people of Australia to these facts? What does the Government have to hide in relaying to the Australian public the facts about the increase in Soviet power and authority? An indicator of the difficulty that this Government has with its left wing is that it cannot confront Australian public opinion with the full facts. So the United States has to do it for us in our own country.

According to Admiral Hays, on any given day 40 to 50 Soviet naval units can be found operating throughout the Pacific and Indian Oceans. We all know the significance of the loss of Cam Ranh Bay facilities to the Soviets. It provides a port in South East Asia and gives the Soviets easy support facilities to Soviet operations not only in the Pacific but also in the Indian Ocean where the Soviets are also supported from bases in South Yemen and Ethiopia. The admiral, like us all, is concerned about the political manoeuvring in the Pacific. He observes that Moscow, with more nuclear weapons than any other nation, can feel only encouraged by the spectacle of the United States and New Zealand slugging it out over the visits of naval ships. Accordingly, he argues that the Soviet strategy in the Pacific is clear. He says:
Their short-range objective is to establish good relations and some dependence.

In this they have offered Fiji what the admiral describes as `a grab bag offer . . . including deals in sugar, fishing, trade and cultural visits'. In the longer run they hope to engender suspicion of all things Western and eventual alienation against Western influence. They are the views of the United States Pacific Command. I have no doubt that in the main the Government agrees with those views, but it is very much afraid of offending the left wing by saying so. Therefore, we have a situation where Australian public opinion is left to see its way clear to support the United States alliance amidst assaults on it by the champions of the Soviet arguments. Unfortunately we have had some champions of that Soviet argument taking part from the Labor Party side of the House in this debate.

There is a further concern that the Australian Government has led off on its own to draw up this treaty for a nuclear free zone. It is very clear that the United States is very reluctant about the concept. We have had to go to the United States on bended knee to plead with it to attach its signature to a protocol which has the dubious merit of inviting the United States to denounce the protocol if things turn out bad for the United States in the Pacific. We all know that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has been guilty of many misjudgments from the time that he blew out the Australian wage system, to its present day encumbrance on our manufacturing competitiveness and through this to our current economic tribulations. Let us hope that he can be justified in his optimism which led him to place more emphasis on concern about United States nuclear policy in the Pacific than on Soviet activities and intentions. I do not think he is right. I think he should be very careful to analyse in the longer term the Soviet ambitions in this part of the world and right throughout the world. In my view this treaty does nothing to thwart those ambitions and it does very little indeed to bolster up the support for our treaty partner, the United States. The chickens will inevitably come home to roost and it will be for some other government to bear the burden of coping with the mistaken approach to foreign policy represented in this sad legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Much of what the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) has said hardly stands up to scrutiny. I will deal with it a little later as I will deal with a few comments from the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) in his earlier address to the chamber. When Australia signed the Treaty of Rarotonga, on the fortieth anniversary of the world's first experience of nuclear weapons, it immediately undertook a number of significant international obligations. The purpose of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill, together with two complementary Bills, is to give statutory effect to those obligations. Indeed the package of related Bills goes far beyond the technical requirements for ratification of the treaty.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation provides a comprehensive legal framework giving support to every aspect of the treaty and is a demonstration of the most practical kind of the Government's commitment to global and regional security and arms control. It is appropriate at the outset to focus on the Treaty to which this legislation will give domestic legal effect. The South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty has been the subject of a great deal of criticism, most of it either contrived or based on ignorance or deluded understanding of international affairs.

The Treaty of Rarotonga represents a significant achievement, an important step forward, that has gained recognition and respect in international forums. The South Pacific Forum countries, and particularly Australia and the Hawke Labor Government, have demonstrated in this Treaty not only a commitment to and a desire for peace in a world free from the threat of nuclear weapons but also that they can do the hard, tedious and difficult work that progress on disarmament and arms control requires. The treaty demonstrates a growing maturity among the nations of the South Pacific. It shows a clear and rational appreciation of the delicate and difficult balance between the desire for isolation from the nuclear world and the realities of national, regional and collective security. As is the case with any and every measure, as a guarantee of preservation against the threat of nuclear war it leaves much to be desired. Nevertheless, it remains an important step.

Much of the criticism of the Treaty of Rarotonga, particularly the paternalistic platitudes from the Australian Democrats, condemns it on the grounds of inadequacy. Critics say that it does not go far enough, that it is not tough or far reaching enough and that it does not prohibit the transit or visits of nuclear-armed or nuclear-powered vessels or aircraft. Some have even ventured to say that without a comprehensive ban on all nuclear material, including ships, within the zone, the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty is worse than useless and that the region would be better off without it. Such comments reflect more on the ability of those voicing such criticisms to come to grips with the reality of life in an irreversible nuclear age than they do on the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty.

Much is often made of comparison with the Latin American nuclear free zone treaty known as the Treaty of Tlatelolco with the view of establishing that as more credible than the zone in the South Pacific. What must be clearly understood from the outset is that the Treaty of Tlatelolco operates as a land based treaty covering the sovereign jurisdiction of its member states in South America, which is entirely different from the geographic factors inherent in the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone which encompasses vast areas of international waters and shipping lanes.

For the South Pacific treaty to attempt or to purport to do what it would have no power to do-that is, to regulate the passage of ships in international waters-would be to damage the credibility of the entire treaty in the eyes of the international community. Similarly, the question of port visits was an issue that could have prevented any treaty being resolved had the South Pacific nations not recognised that every nation has a sovereign right to continue collective security arrangements with external powers. Indeed, one could say that those collective security arrangements that form the Western alliance have been a factor, some might say a major factor, in the peaceful development of the Pacific region to date. To compromise those arrangements, as some argue, in measures neither legally nor practically enforceable, would not enhance the reality of disarmament or arms control one inch.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I draw your attention to the state of the House.
—A quorum is not present. Ring the bells.
—What is the point of all this?
—Democracy.
—What a load of crap!
—Madam Deputy Speaker, I take offence at the language used by the honourable member.
—I call on the honourable member for Isaacs to withdraw that comment; it was entirely unparliamentary.

SPEECH.PARA: (Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is another group which, more for the attraction of political point scoring than intellectual commitment, has contrived to denigrate the South Pacific nuclear free zone because it goes too far. Most obvious in this minority is the former Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong. As I said earlier, I will refer a little later to the comments that he made in his previous address. The honourable member referred to the treaty in a radio interview on AM some time ago as both dangerous, a folly and a farce. Perhaps a more rational, objective and relevant view is that of Dr Robert O'Neill, a director of the International Institute of Strategic Studies in London. On AM on 8 August last year, speaking of the treaty, Dr O'Neill said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think the concentration of the treaty on nuclear testing, the actual stationing of nuclear weapons in the area, and the ban against the dumping of nuclear materials, is looking at the most sensible, the most deliverable parts of the whole array of anti-nuclear measures that can be taken.

I think Mr Hawke is on the right side of this issue. I think he will demonstrate to the rest of the world that there is a serious concern with nuclear activities in the South Pacific. I think it also helps to underline that the concept being implemented is a sensible one, one that does not infringe any international orders. It does not seek to deprive major maritime powers of their traditional freedoms of the high seas that they have been used to and, generally speaking, the role that Australia has played in trying to bring this kind or regime about is I think a highly creditable one.

The Government's South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Bill will take that highly commendable role one step further. It will enact, as part of a comprehensive package, a statutory obligation on Australia to prohibit the manufacture, production, acquisition, storage and stationing, and research and development into nuclear explosive devices. This applies regardless of whether these explosions are so-called peaceful purposes which is allowed under the Tlatelolco Treaty. This will extend to all Australian territories. Part II of the Bill provides severe penalties for offences related to the possession, control, stationing, testing and the nuclear explosive devices. The Bill further provides for complementary legislation to give effect to other South Pacific nuclear free zone obligations, specifically the prevention of the dumping of radioactive waste in the South Pacific and safeguards in relation to the handling of nuclear material. In accordance with the treaty obligations undertaken by Australia, the Bill provides the structure and ground rules for inspections to ensure monitoring and compliance of the treaty and procedures for the lodgment of complaints of treaty violations. Appropriately, the penalties for breaches of the Act reflect the gravity of the offences and demonstrate the seriousness with which the Government views the observance of the treaty.

Madam Deputy Speaker, I will refer briefly to some of the comments made by the honourable member for Kooyong in his earlier address to this House. He suggested that a conservative government would have home porting or permanently stationed missile or other nuclear weapons on Australian soil if that government felt that it was appropriate to do so. We have been through all that in the 1960s when the conservative government took us down the Vietnam road where over 500 Australians died. We are still trying to find the reason. This was engineered by a former conservative Prime Minister, not for the well being of the South East Asian area or for the well being of the globe, but purely for political reasons. `All the way with L.B.J.', said another conservative Prime Minister and the conservative government took us down that road.

Here we have the honourable member for Kooyong, the Opposition spokesman on Foreign Affairs and former Leader of the Opposition-he probably will be again after the next election-saying: `Yes, it is no problem. We will have home porting, we will station nuclear weapons on our soil if we think it is appropriate'. I am sorry to say to the honourable member for Kooyong that the vast majority of Australian people just do not agree with him. That is absolute nonsense. I hope he goes to the next election and the election after that with the sort of nonsense that we are to station nuclear weapons on Australian soil and that we will be in every scrap that is going. Australia has grown up and matured a little more than those days when we were carted in to every scrap by every conservative government that ever sat in this Parliament.

The honourable member for Kooyong also referred to New Zealand. In numerous debates in this House I have asked him what he would have done. He has still failed to answer that question in the hours he has spent on his feet in this House. He said today in effect that he would have gone to New Zealand on a big white charger and told the people there what they should be doing. I think the people of New Zealand would not have taken too kindly to that. The diplomatic politics of `thump them over the head hard and often and they will get the message', is well gone. That is why we have seen some diplomatic boo boos even from the United States of America at times when it occasionally has a rush of blood to its head and tries that sort of thing. It does not work. Equally, if any foreign nation came into Australia, if any foreign Prime Minister or Minister for Foreign Affairs from another country came in and said, `Listen you lot, it is about time you did this, that or the other or we will get heavy with you', the Australian people would not wear it. Equally, if someone did that to New Zealand, it would take offence too. We do not win battles or win people over by threatening to bash them into the ground. That is all that the honourable member for Kooyong was offering today. He would have charged in and he would have told them.

We have done a lot of work. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), who is at the table, has done a lot of work, as has the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). At this stage the people of New Zealand, through their government, do not agree with our position. We will persevere, but we cannot tell them what to do. New Zealand is a sovereign state and it will have to make its own decisions. We disagree with the people of New Zealand, but so be it. I agreed with one comment made by the honourable member for Kooyong during his speech regarding dumping. There could be a separate protocol in the treaty for dumping. Perhaps that should be looked at in the not too distant future. I think that is a good thought and perhaps it could be pursued.

The honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) talked all sorts of nonsense that really had no relevance to the legislation. He said it would disenfranchise the United States right across the board, which is rubbish. This Bill does not change the existing situation in the South Pacific; it enshrines the existing situation where there is no nuclear testing, no stationing of nuclear missiles and no dumping of nuclear wastes, et cetera. It enshrines that, and so that should be. It does not alter the situation regarding the United States or anyone else in their capacity to transit the waters, to keep their obligations under treaties or alliances such as the ANZUS treaty.

When the Hawke Government assumed office and started work on a South Pacific nuclear free zone, it recognised the difficulties that lay ahead. It was mindful of the abortive attempts of the New Zealand Rowling Labor Government in the early 1970s whose idealistic zeal wilted in the heat of international reality. Certainly those naive and ever hopeful of a dramatic, simple eradication of nuclear weapons remain disappointed and disillusioned by our efforts. For those so deluded, nothing short of their particular vision, no matter how hard fought, is ever enough. And yet to the majority of the Australian people an effective, responsible compromise has been reached. The Hawke Government has ensured that while preserving Australia's right as a sovereign nation to maintain its collective security arrangements, our region has made a rational, mature step on to the international stage.

This Bill and the Treaty to which it gives effect come at a time when there is little to speak of in the recent record of global or regional disarmament and arms control initiatives-and this is an arms control initiative. When the record, the reality and all the relevant factors are weighed, the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty remains in front as a worthwhile achievement, and as an important element in the Hawke Government's highly credible efforts in disarmament and arms control. I urge all honourable members on both sides of the House to support the Bill to demonstrate our collective support for the enacting into Australian law of the provisions of the Treaty of Rarotonga.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter The Hon R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My reasonably brief contribution to the debate on the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill will be based on an element which I regard as extremely important. I refer to the impression given to the world as to why this Government is enthusiastically supporting this legislation. My personal contribution to this debate is based on information I and others have gathered over a period of years. It is no good saying, as did the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner), that not a single Soviet vessel has been sighted in the South Pacific. That is absolute nonsense. I have had the advantage of a briefing, as has the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), with Admiral Hays. We were led by an eminent member of the Labor Party, the member for Brisbane (Mr Cross). We were given the facts clearly and precisely. What we heard was not just a political contribution. Admiral Hays had no political barrow to push. I had had a previous briefing from Admiral Long and both were totally in accord. The substance of that briefing was to the effect that the intrusion, manoeuvres or exercises by Soviet vessels in the Pacific at present are equal to the Soviet movements evaluated in the Indian Ocean. That ran to some 30-odd submarines alone. Is this some sort of communist kicking exercise or scare tactic? No, this came from the Commander-in-Chief of the Pacific Fleet, CINPAC, the Commander-in-Chief of the Indian Ocean area, and the Commander-in-Chief of the Persian Gulf area, to use the old term. Here were the facts.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, there was further information that can be checked out. One may ask what the Soviet Union has to do with all this. I am talking of processing this particular anti-nuclear zone and what sort of messages will go abroad. Will the message be that there are elements in the present Government who are more than anxious to create close relationships with the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics? I think the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) himself recently stated that now is the opportunity to take advantage of the situation in view of the difference of opinion with the United States of America over the wheat agreements. I do not think there are any members of this House who represent more wheat growers than I do. I have two problems. One is that I have a close affinity with-and I make no secret of it-and an admiration for the United States of America. Without the United States where would the sort of world we want be? Who would provide the safeguard? Who would serve warning on these tyrants who have a totally obnoxious philosophy? I face a dilemma. The wheat growers in my area are in real trouble and one of their greatest problems arises from the wheat agreements. One fact is always overlooked. What is said when dealing with the bases is that we should serve notice on the Americans, tell them to get the hell out of it, pack up and to get out of Pine Gap.

TALK.START.PARA: —No way.

—No way, as my honourable friend says. That is so for a very obvious reason. Our protection, our defence, our security and our capacity to go to bed at night with the feeling that we are pretty right for the time being at least rests very heavily on the one safeguard we have. I refer to an element of protection from one of the most powerful nations on earth. If the United States moves out, who moves in?

SPEECH.PARA: In dealing with this nuclear free zone I ask whether there is anyone in this nation who would support the possiblity of any sort of nuclear conflict, or anything that even suggests the possibility of a nuclear holocaust. No one would support that. Let us be reasonable about this. What concerns members on this side of the House-and I know that there are members opposite who are equally concerned-is that this legislation is not even-handed. Has there been a great uproar, a great outcry about Chernobyl? We have read about it in the media but there have been no demonstrations-or perhaps there were one or two. If Reagan were to drop one word somewhere, the media which seem dedicated to the destruction of American leader after American leader-one wonders about it-would scream to high heaven. They would say: `Here is the brutal arms runner, the international gangster who wants to cause a holocaust and star wars'.

I will tell honourable members something, and every newspaper, radio station and television station, if they are interested in the likes of me, can use it if they like. I say: Thank God we have Star Wars and that particular process and operation'. We have served notice on the Soviet Union that the sort of country that protects us is one step ahead of it. It has a technical advantage which, for the time being at least, will give protection. Those who lean towards the Soviet Union throw up their arms in despair and ask that Star Wars be got rid of because it is catching up with their mates in the Soviet Union. It is not catching up, but it is well ahead in that category. Star Wars is to them a dirty word.

In relation to the South Pacific, the toe in the door argument could be put forward. I am sure the honourable member for Hughes was not serious when he said there was not a single Soviet vessel in the South Pacific. He could not possibly have given thought to that comment. I am sure that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), who is at the table and for whom I have great respect, would regard that comment as an absolute joke. One adds to the argument the fact that heavily armed nuclear submarines are prowling around. They are in the area. Add to that the Soviet base in the vicinity of Japan in the north-west Pacific. That base is just as advanced as, if not more so than, the Soviet bases in Eastern Europe. It is every bit as capable of conducting a global war. One can take one's pick, one can have either a nuclear war or a conventional war. The Soviets are ready for it and are ready to press buttons.

There is another great danger, and it relates to the mentality of certain small countries. The psychological argument is, `Be red or dead'. The Soviets say to the emerging peoples of the world, who are feeling their way: `We are so far ahead of the United States, we in the communist world, we in the Eastern Europe group of nations, that you are gone if you stick with the United States'. When Libya was attacked they ran for cover. However, it was rather interesting that when that incident was over West Germany and some of those countries began to come back to the fold because they were not committed in any way. It is very easy to stand on the sideline and say `Go to it, Reagan, give them another burst', as long as we are not involved. But there are some countries that are involved-God bless them and God protect them.

Thus we have this combination of three elements-and I will go through them again. First, there is the intrusion, the toe in the door of the South Pacific by the Soviet Union; then there are the ships that prowl around; and then there is that giant organisation which the Soviet Union has up on the north west rim of the Pacific basin. If that does not add up to an obvious threat, I do not know what does.

My final comment is-and I will sit down after this-that we must be terribly careful that when this legislation is passed-regrettably it will go through-we do not serve notice on the world that we are not even handed. Let us not say `Well, okay we have created this situation' and add to it the attitude of the New Zealand Government and Mr Lange. In these circumstances why would the United States not say `It looks as if we are finished there; all we have left is Indonesia'? Let us face up to realities. If this country is to go in that direction, lean a little more towards Lange all the time and put up this umbrella, we must accept the consequences. Could it be that the trade consequences are a result of this attitude? I totally oppose the Bill on that basis of all the dangers that are involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The contribution of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter), provides a useful illustration of the difficulty of conducting a rational debate about these sorts of matters. I found his contribution extraordinary in that he referred constantly to the Soviet threat and the possibility of Soviet ships entering the South Pacific region, yet he made no attempt at any stage to demonstrate how the ratification or coming into force of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty would affect in any way the operation of United States forces in the South Pacific region. The Treaty and this South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill have been drafted arduously in order to avoid any possibility of placing an impediment in the way of the operation of United States forces in the relevant region. Therefore I really do not know what the honourable member is talking about. There is a legitimate area of debate about how much virtue one sees in the United States alliance and that has gone on extensively in the Australian Labor Party, but for the honourable member for Kennedy to try to infer that the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty has the consequences that he implies is utterly ludicrous. The Treaty has been carefully drafted to avoid any such consequences.

SPEECH.PARA: This piece of legislation is the Government's attempt to give legislative force to the substantive provisions of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. The Government has chosen a particular legislative path from several possible options. It has deliberately gone beyond what was minimally required in order for Australia to ratify the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. Were we to do the minimum in the legislative area to ratify the Treaty it would involve provisions regarding the privileges and immunities of inspectors, sea dumping and a couple of other matters. What the Government has in fact done is give legislative force to the substantive provisions relating to the non-acquisition, testing and stationing of nuclear weapons. I think that decision is to be applauded and I strongly support the Government's going down that particular path.

It is worth considering the sort of treaty that the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty is. Its title is the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty, but it is not that in the sense that it does not preclude all kinds of nuclear related activities from its area of operation. Obviously it allows nuclear powered or armed vessels to transit and to visit ports at the discretion of the signatory states. It also permits the stationing of facilities such as the ones we have in Australia which are part of a global nuclear war fighting apparatus. In that sense the Treaty is a little bit of a misnomer. On the other hand, it represents something more than simply a nuclear free weapons zone treaty in that it has provisions relating to dumping of radioactive waste and also the prohibition of the detonation of ostensibly peaceful nuclear explosions in the area. I guess if one were trying to think of a title for it one would conclude that this title is as appropriate as any, but it is a little inaccurate to describe it as a comprehensive nuclear free zone treaty.

Since the debate on this proposal was revived in 1983, various points of view have been put forward in the region as to what the treaty should involve. These range from the view held by Vanuatu, the Solomon Islands and New Zealand, which would prefer to see a more comprehensive type of treaty encompassing the transitting and visiting of ships, to the views of states such as Tonga and more recently the Cook Islands, which seem to have some concern that the Treaty would impede the operation of United States forces and the functioning of the ANZUS alliance in the region in some way, although no one has been able to point out in what way the Treaty would have those consequences. There is a range of viewpoints there.

I might add that the Treaty has aspects which are unenforceable in any legal sort of sense. The best indicator of that is the way in which the boundaries of the treaty zone are drawn. The boundaries do not consist of the areas-the land areas, territorial seas and so forth-where the signatory states have some power actually to enforce the provisions of the Treaty. The Treaty zone takes in a very broad area ranging from the boundary of the Treaty of Tlatelolco in the east, to the boundaries where the zone abuts the Antarctic treaty area in the south, to the Equator with a little variation to include Kiribati in the north and in the west it is essentially the boundary of Australia's territorial waters. That is a vast ocean area and it includes an awful lot of water that is not part of anyone's territorial sea. Obviously any provisions relating to those areas are unenforceable in any legal sense. In fact, the Treaty specifies that it is not intended to violate any aspects of the law of the sea or anything of that sort. In other words, to a considerable degree the Treaty has a symbolic significance and a so-called picture frame model for determining the boundary of the Treaty signifies the fact that to a large degree it is a type of political statement as distinct from something that is totally legally enforceable in the strict sense.

I wish to talk about the value of a treaty of this kind. Its critics from various sides claim that it is a `Mickey Mouse treaty' which has no real effect on the real world. The arguments put forward there are generally along the lines that all the signatory States are signatories to the Treaty for the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons which covers a number of significant aspects of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. A further argument is that there is no nuclear activity of the sort prohibited by the treaty within the treaty zone, apart from the French nuclear testing in Polynesia, which the French have made perfectly clear they have no intention of stopping, irrespective of whether the Treaty is adopted. It could be argued that the Treaty's impact on activity in the South Pacific nuclear free zone is minimal. In one sense that is true, although the adoption of a treaty of this sort would apply a degree of moral pressure on France which over time might exert some impact on the French to stop testing earlier than they might have done otherwise. It is arguable that there might be a benefit of that sort.

To say that the Treaty's coming into force will not change the status quo in the zone area does not imply, in my view, that the Treaty has no value. The main value of the treaty is in terms of impeding any future possible nuclear activity of the sort prohibited by the Treaty in the area, particularly in the territories of some States which might sign the protocols, which might otherwise like to station nuclear weapons or conduct tests. I think there is an impediment to such states engaging in such activities.

Australia's action in pursuing this Treaty sends a most important signal to a state such as Indonesia, which might be contemplating developing nuclear weapons, or might contemplate it at some future stage. It is an important and explicit signal that we have no intention of going down that path. Obviously, if Australia had actively and successfully pursued the adoption of this Treaty and were then to start to develop nuclear weapons, it would look pretty stupid. In my opinion, there is a major impediment and a major disincentive to states in the area going down that track. That sort of pressure arising from the regional context complements the provisions of the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, to which all South Pacific states are signatories. The most important aspect or benefit of the Treaty is in terms of placing some sort of impediment in the way of possible future nuclear activity in the region.

I referred earlier to the variety of positions taken by potential signatory states and ratifiers. A number of those states recently expressed some reservations about the Treaty, including some that initially were quite happy to sign it. One of the most important examples is Papua New Guinea, which signed the Treaty in September of last year, but since the change of government there has been a degree of ambivalence in its position. It is now tending to favour a tougher line along the lines of Vanuatu and the Solomon Islands. Those two states have reservations because they do not think the Treaty is tough enough. On the other hand, we have the statement by Sir Thomas Davis, the Prime Minister of the Cook Islands, indicating his belief that the Treaty might in some way impede the operation of ANZUS and that in consequence his country might contemplate formal neutrality. There are a number of non-sequiturs which escape me. I do not see how, if a country decides to go down the path of neutrality, that should be an impediment to its ratifying the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. The fact is that there are a number of difficulties in terms of potential signatory states and ratifiers and hopefully they will be smoothed out.

Whatever view one takes about whether a tougher type of treaty is more desirable than the one we have-frankly, I am somewhat sympathetic to that view personally, but that is obviously not the Government's position-it still remains the case that getting this Treaty in place, bedded down and accepted is of considerable value for the reasons I outlined earlier. It is a crazy approach to say that because the Treaty does not encompass all the elements one would like to see it encompass, one should regard the Treaty as having no value and should try actively to impede its coming into force. I do not think that is a rational course of action, even if one takes the view taken by New Zealand, Vanuatu, the Solomon Islands and apparently Papua New Guinea about the desirability of other elements in the Treaty.

Another question relates to the position of the states which might be expected to sign the protocols attached to the Treaty. The first of those protocols involves states which have territories in the area-the United States of America, Great Britain and France-and which adhere to the provisions of the treaty in respect of their territories in the treaty zone. There is no prospect of the French acceding to that protocol in the foreseeable future, but the other two states might go along with it. Another significant protocol is the one which is supposed to be signed by the five existing nuclear weapons states. They undertake not to use, or to threaten the use of, nuclear weapons against signatory states in the area. There are some obvious difficulties there. For example, the Soviet Union might wish to target the joint facilities in the event of a nuclear war breaking out. It is difficult to see how it could fail to target those facilities, which seems to suggest that it would be difficult for it to give an undertaking on that protocol, or an undertaking which is meaningful or credible. It seems to me to be a significant problem and I hope some formulation can be arrived at which enables that to be overcome.

We might be waiting for a long time before we get a definite response on the protocols, if the Treaty of Tlatelolco is anything to go by. Some of the signatory states to that Treaty did not endorse the protocols, notwithstanding that they had no objection to or problem with them, until a considerable time afterwards. We might be waiting for a long time, but hopefully not. The protocols do not have to be signed in order for the Treaty to come into force-basically the Treaty only requires eight states to ratify it before it comes into force-but we might be waiting a long time for a definite outcome on the protocols.

I think the Treaty has value. There may be some potential problems-we should not hold our breath on the protocols being signed-but it has great symbolic importance. The desirability of such arrangements is explicitly recognised in the Non-Proliferation Treaty and at the Non-Proliferation Treaty review conference last year the initiative in establishing the zone was applauded. I think it is a definite step in the right direction. I am happy that the Government has gone down the path of legislating the substantive provisions of the Treaty.

I conclude on a somewhat different note. I am among those in the Australian Labor Party who were very disturbed at our decision in effect to allow the resumption of uranium shipments to France before it ceases testing in the region. Given the great importance of symbolism, one could not imagine a worse type of symbolic gesture than that. Even if one takes the view that by continuing to adhere to the ban we are just giving the French the opportunity to get uranium on the spot market at a cheaper price than they would have had to pay under the contractual arrangements, the ban on uranium shipments to France was never a huge practical impediment to the French continuing a program to develop nuclear weapons. Any cost differentials that might emerge are pretty insignificant in terms of the decision of the French to develop or not develop nuclear weapons. In my opinion, the overwhelming importance of the ban on uranium shipments to France was what it signified about this country's stance on such matters and I regret the decision that has been taken as part of the Budget process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with my colleagues on this side of the House in expressing some considerable concern about this legislation and the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. This Treaty is, of course, the centrepiece of the Government's specific strategy and it really has to be seen in the overall context of the political, strategic and economic situation in the Pacific region today. Clearly, when one looks at that overall scene, one sees that, in the last two decades, the Pacific has been one of the power-houses of global economic growth. There has been an enormous increase in trade within the region and each nation, with very few exceptions, has enjoyed considerable economic growth internally. As a result of this change in the economic situation in the Pacific and its growing importance economically, the region has also assumed much greater political importance, and that assumption of greater political importance was inevitable.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is true to say that, in the main, over the last two or three decades, the Pacific, particularly the South Pacific, has in a political context enjoyed a great deal of stability. There are two real reasons for its achieving that stability and they are important to understand. First of all, that stability has been derived from the economic success of the region and from the growth in trade between the countries of the region which, as I have said, has been immense. Secondly, that region has remained stable because of the security it has been given by the network of alliances. I think it is important to emphasise that the ANZUS alliance has been the centrepiece of that network of alliances, be they formal alliances or informal alliances. It has been to the advantage certainly of the South Pacific that conflict between the super-powers has not really been a reality in that region. In fact, there has been effectively no Soviet presence in the South Pacific until the last few years. The exercise of the policy of strategic denial, as it is sometimes called by the United States of America, with the support of Australia and, in the past, New Zealand, has really been a policy of great success and, as I am emphasising, has provided tremendous stability for the region.

There is no doubt that that whole scene has begun to change quite significantly. If one were to go back 10 years I suppose that one could identify the starting point of that considerable change. From a position of great stability, we have now begun to move towards a degree of unfortunate instability in the region. I think that has two basic causes. One of the causes is certainly not a change in the economic circumstances of the region because economic growth in the Pacific is still going ahead, despite the problems that Australia has. The first of the two causes is a substantial change in domestic policies and politics in the countries of the Pacific. One has to look only at countries such as Vanuatu, the Solomon Islands, Papua New Guinea and New Zealand to see the way the political situation in those countries has changed so markedly. We had Father Lini of Vanuatu at the recent South Pacific Forum exercising a new sort of political muscle by concentrating his remarks on the situation in the Middle East and South Africa and apparently refusing to discuss the growing encroachment of the Soviet Union in the South Pacific.

This change in domestic politics and the domestic political flavour of these countries has led to a change also in foreign policy attitudes. There has been a growing feeling against the super-powers.
