There has been a growing belief in the concept of what is sometimes called moral equivalence, which is something I strongly oppose. There has also been a very strong growth in feeling against the French. I must say that I think some of that feeling against the French is quite legitimate, particularly in the context of their nuclear tests and their attitude to New Caledonia. There is also a growing feeling against countries such as Australia which are perceived to be the big brother, both economically and politically in the region; it is believed that a policy which separates their interests from those of a larger country is an assertion of independence and should be pursued. We have seen very recently reports of something known informally as the Melanesian association which includes Papua New Guinea, Vanuatu and the Solomon Islands. That sort of development at least shows a very significant change in foreign policy attitudes in the region and, in my view, it is not a terribly positive change.

It is also important to emphasise the growing role of the Soviet Union in the region. This has been emphasised by a number of my colleagues. It is indisputable that the Soviet Union has launched a diplomatic offensive in the South Pacific whereas previously it really had no interest or involvement in the region-at least not since the early part of the last century. In the last few years it has begun a diplomatic offensive which has concentrated on obtaining fishing rights in a number of countries. Of course we are all aware of the signing of an agreement with Kiribati in 1985, under which the Soviets agreed to pay, I think $1.7m per annum in rent. It has held talks with Fiji, Vanuatu, Papua New Guinea and Tuvalu with a view to developing fishing rights but the logical extension of that is to enhance its political influence. In doing that it is, of course, affecting the stability of the region, affecting the balance of power in the region, and that is something that, as Australians, we should resist and regret. It is interesting to recall the words of Moscow Radio on 15 July 1984, the day after Mr Lange was elected Prime Minister of New Zealand. Moscow radio said:
The Lange victory could set off a chain reaction leading to the collapse of the ANZUS bloc.

Of course that was said in the light of it being a good thing. So the Soviet Union has a growing interest and also growing political influence in the area. Others have spoken at some length about the buildup of Soviet military forces. I do not want to repeat all that but it is an important point to make. The Soviet Union's Pacific fleet is the largest of its four fleets. Some 32 per cent of the Soviet Union's naval assets are in the Pacific region; it has about 800 ships and 120 submarines in that part of the world.

I conclude by referring to Prime Minister Lange of New Zealand, who said that the Soviet objective in the Pacific was `to neutralise the Pacific'. I could not have put it better but it is ironical that a man such as Mr Lange should make that remark. The challenge for Australia is to meet these changing circumstances. We have to do what we can, as a significant nation in the region, to maintain the economic stability of this part of the world as well as its political and strategic stability. I do not believe that the Government has done that. It has done the reverse. First of all with the exception of this South Pacific treaty it has pursued a policy of virtual negligence in this area. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) has been very active in a number of areas of the world and he has done some very positive things but he has not concentrated on the Pacific. I think I am right in saying that he has visited the Pacific islands only once in his three years as the Foreign Minister. It has certainly not been one of his priorities. All of us noted the decision of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) not to attend the South Pacific Forum recently but to send his deputy. As the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) has pointed out, the Government has stood by and watched the ANZUS alliance crumble. I believe, as does the honourable member for Kooyong, that the Government should have done a great deal more to try to hold up the ANZUS alliance and maintain New Zealand's involvement, particularly in the light of the developments I have already described.

The Government has made one sole contribution and that is the subject of this debate-the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. Frankly much of this Treaty is quite platitudinous and much of it is already covered by other international agreements. Basically it reiterates a great deal of what is in the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, a treaty to which Australia is not only a signatory but also one which it has strongly supported on a bipartisan basis. The Treaty moves against testing and that is laudable. The Liberal Government under Malcolm Fraser opposed French nuclear testing; the present Government opposes it as did the Whitlam Government. There is a bipartisan position on that matter. The treaty opposes the dumping of nuclear waste and all of us on this side of the House agree with that. It allows the passage of nuclear armed vessels through the region and of course we support that. The Treaty also, with the permission of the host country, allows visits by ships and planes-under, I think, Clause 15-to the various ports and airfields of the region. All of those measures are supported by this side of the House and it would be wrong for honourable members on the other side to conclude falsely that we do not support them. I want to emphasise that point.

Why is it necessary to reiterate all these things in the form of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty? The answer is that the raison d'etre of the Treaty-this needs to be understood-is to attack the French and the French involvement at Muroroa, and possibility at a later stage in New Caledonia. I do not condone what the French are doing at Mururoa-quite the contrary-but I think this has to be understood as the raison d'etre of the Treaty. When we consider the Treaty in the context of other countries that are important to us as members of the Western alliance, that is a very significant factor.

I have two objections to the Treaty. One is that it is basically an anti-French treaty and little else, and except for the platitudes that we all support, it embarrasses a number of our major allies. Secondly, I think it could be described also as the first stone that has fallen from the edifice which is the Western alliance in our region. It could eventually lead to an avalanche which would swamp ultimately the Western alliance in the Pacific.

Let us consider the point about the Treaty embarrassing our allies and the Western alliance. It is important to note that the United States of America and Great Britain, as well as France, have been asked to sign the protocol of the Treaty. So, too, have the Soviet Union and China. The Soviets are very happy to sign the protocol. I quote from Izvestia of 7 August 1986. It said:
The creation of a nuclear free zone would contribute to the formation of a multilateral system of security in the Asia-Pacific region.
Actually, that is not something that we want. We have gained great stability through the ANZUS alliance in the region and the role that it has played. Izvestia also said:

At the consultations held in February 1986 in Moscow with a delegation of the South Pacific forum, the Soviet side declared that the Treaty, together with the protocols under discussion, basically meet the criteria which the Soviet Union put forward in regard to nuclear free zones.

There is much support from the Soviet Union, and doubtless it will sign the protocol, but for countries such as the United States and Great Britain, which are much more important to our security, our stability and our economy than the Soviet Union, it is a matter of considerable embarrassment. Great Britain is being asked to sign the protocol, and it must be understood that effectively it is being asked to denounce France. That is a difficult position for the British. They do not condone French nuclear testing at Mururoa, but at the same time they are allies with France in the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation. They are not in the militarily integrated part of NATO, but they are NATO allies. Perhaps more importantly, Great Britain is a partner with France in the European community.

The British support the concept of a nuclear free zone, but one of the criteria they use for their support of a nuclear free zone is that all the states in the region should agree with the zone. Clearly, in this instance France is one of the states in the region, and France, for its own reasons, believes that it cannot agree to the terms of the Treaty. The Treaty creates a very real dilemma for a country such as Britain and as a result it is not clear whether Britain feels that it can reasonably sign the Treaty. It has received, inevitably, strong representations from the French not to do so. The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) said recently in Fiji that the British were going to sign the protocol to the Treaty, as were the Americans, but that does not prove to be the case. As yet, neither country has made a commitment.

The Americans have similar problems with the Treaty, but they have additional ones. They are worried that the Treaty could be the beginning of the end of the concept of strategic denial in the region, and I have explained how that would happen. They are concerned also that this is part of what they describe as the nuclear allergy. In other words, they fear that it will spread and that there will be greater pressure on the Americans to support nuclear free zones in other parts of the world or, even if the Americans do not support them, for those nuclear free zones to come about.

There is a proposal for a Nordic nuclear free zone. Norway is a member of NATO, so clearly that presents a problem. There is a proposal for a South East Asian zone of peace, freedom and neutrality. That too, I think, would present a major problem to the United States in maintaining the balance of power in our part of the world and it would also present a problem for Australia itself.

One of the real problems with this Treaty is that it presents divisions for the Western alliance in the Pacific region-divisions between Britain and France, divisions between the United States and France--
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax: State Emergency Service of New South Wales-United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation-Television Reception in Mount Martha area-Australian Flag-Australian Bill of Rights Bill-Comments of Mr Lightfoot-Bicentennial Celebrations-Tasmania-National Awards for Innovation in Local Government: City of Moe-Small Business

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.15 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity during the adjournment debate tonight to raise a matter which has been the subject of some adverse Press comment so far as the Government is concerned and also to express my personal concern that the Government did not announce in the Budget last night any changes, either administrative or otherwise, to its most retrograde fringe benefits tax arrangements. I will read to the House a telex of which members of the State Emergency Service of New South Wales have recently been informed concerning the impact of fringe benefits tax on members of that Service. Honourable members will be aware that the State Emergency Service has some employees and it also has associated with it a large number of volunteers. The telex reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Fringe Benefits Tax and Personal Income Tax
Following a seminar with the Treasury and Public Service Board, the new FBT requirements has necessitated a change in personal income tax.
Payments of travelling expenses, meal allowances, mileage allowances and other determined benefits to volunteers and permanent staff will:
1. Be included as expenses on group certificates for permanent staff.
2. Be included on statements of earnings for volunteers.

It is imperative that all volunteers and permanent staff maintain a dairy in such detail that will allow the appropriate declarations when submitting income tax returns, to be provided. A precise record is essential.
Divisions will be required to maintain an exact record of all payments to volunteers, for advice to this office when clarification of records to be kept, etc is received from treasury consultants.
Finance Branch will retain the records for permanent staff. All records are to be maintained from 1.7.86.
Please note that this Department will not be keeping records of payments made by employees but rather payments made to repeat to employees and volunteers.
It is recommended that volunteers and permanent staff obtain the 3 booklets, Employee's Work Expenses, Travel Expenses and Car Expenses from their local post office or taxation office.
The details relating to the overall application of the fringe benefits taxation legislation will be the subject of further discussion with the Treasury's consultants.
Immediately any information is available, divisions will be advised accordingly.
Please ensure all volunteers are informed.

The date of that telex, which related to the fringe benefits tax that was to operate from 1 July, was 15 July. So not only are employees of that organisation to be affected by the fringe benefits tax but also volunteers in relation to any travel expenses, meal allowances and mileage allowances paid to them when acting in relation to emergencies. Those payments made to them are to be included in a statement of earnings. Everybody knows that recently in New South Wales we had some disastrous floods and storm damage and volunteers were called out to assist during that emergency. It was not until the emergency was over and the volunteers sought recoupment of these funds that they were advised that they may have to produce to the Commissioner of Taxation at some future time, in order to ensure that they do not have to pay tax on any allowances they receive, diary entries, log books and the like to prove, for substantiation purposes, that they actually incurred the expenses for which they later recouped an allowance.

I think this is disastrous for the State Emergency Service of New South Wales, but even more so for this Government. More particularly, it has been handled in a most inept way in that these people in New South Wales who give of their time and who volunteered to assist in emergencies have been put in a situation in which they are likely to be at the beck and call of the Commissioner of Taxation in relation to this matter. It may be--

TALK.START.PARA: —Is what you are saying true?

—I have a copy of the telex. I read it to honourable members so that they will be aware of the situation and so that they will be able to see the very nature of the nightmare that we have, that volunteers are affected in this way and that people who have given of their time are likely to be required to keep quite complex and detailed records for fear that amounts which are paid to them merely so that they can recoup out of pocket expenses are not taxed at a later point in time. That is the impact of this legislation. I did not think that this area could possibly be affected. I can forgive the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for his slip of the tongue when he referred to this measure as the `mad fringe benefits tax' when he was challenged on this matter on television in New South Wales. The fact is that when bureaucrats are charged with the task of administering legislation of this sort, situations like this do arise.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The flood of documents and papers crossing honourable members' desks this week has included the report of the Australian delegation to the twenty-third session of the General Conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation, held last November in Sofia, Bulgaria. This report was actually tabled in the House on 4 June this year. Perhaps this is not an appropriate time to urge further reading on honourable members. Nevertheless, I do urge honourable members to study this document. It is appropriate to record here that at this meeting Ambassador Whitlam was elected to the executive board of UNESCO, an appointment in which I believe all Australians can take pride.

SPEECH.PARA: A reading of the report will show the breadth of activities with which UNESCO is involved. But I must say that UNESCO has been under unprecedented stress over the past two years and I have no doubt that this stress will continue. It is a matter of regret that the United States of America and the United Kingdom have recently withdrawn from this international body. I firmly hope that these withdrawals, which took place despite the exceptionally wide range of reforms recently undertaken in UNESCO, are temporary. I believe that the United States and the United Kingdom decisions to withdraw from UNESCO were made on ideological grounds. There is a general disenchantment among conservative parties on both sides of the North Atlantic with multilateral arrangements. The United States has a history of withdrawal from international organisations, but it was a surprise and, indeed, a disappointment that the United Kingdom decided also to withdraw.

The Western media-and in this I must include the Australian media-have pursued a campaign of disinformation and destabilisation against UNESCO. It is a matter of regret that some members of Australian conservative parties have jumped on the bandwagon of misinformed abuse and criticism of UNESCO. We need to promote UNESCO more in this country, to understand the work it does and the benefits the world community gains from membership of this international body. In that respect I urge honourable members to take the time to look at this report and see the wide range of international activities with which UNESCO is involved. We must always ensure that information about UNESCO is correct and not hesitate to correct the flood of disinformation that appears in the Press. For example, there have been frequent insinuations of financial misappropriations and malpractice in UNESCO. Few people yet realise that UNESCO's accounts have been examined and certified by the British Auditor-General ever since 1951. Articles critical of UNESCO are still syndicated with no indication of the changes which the board has brought about since May of last year.

Finally, I might add how delighted I was with the announcement that Mr Charles Mott would be our next Ambassador and permanent delegate when His Excellency, the present Ambassador, Mr Whitlam, returns to Australia. Mr Mott is an assistant secretary with the responsibility for international organisations and humanitarian affairs in the Department of Foreign Affairs. That such a senior public servant was appointed to the post illustrates this Government's commitment to the work of UNESCO. From time to time, there is criticism of UNESCO's work because some honourable members have not taken the time to acquaint themselves fully with the work done by that international body. A reading of the Australian delegation's report which went to all honourable members' offices today or yesterday will at least make them better informed about its work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable members will be well aware, the Mornington Peninsula forms an important part of my electorate. Mount Martha and Safety Beach are two adjoining areas that would lay good claim to being some of the best parts of that electorate. They have a population of about 2,000, many of whom have retired there to enjoy the many wonderful attractions.

SPEECH.PARA: In June 1985, for reasons that have been the subject of some controversy, television reception in the Mount Martha area was completely lost. People in that area have been without television reception for over 12 months. The commercial television stations were contacted. I pay tribute to them for their work and commitment to install translators to improve the position. On 13 March 1986, technical details of translators were submitted to the Department of Communications. Then came what must be one of the most amazing pieces of bureaucratic red tape and blockage one could come across. The Department's response was that it could not provide licences for the new translators. It could not because the Government is changing the licence system, from one that requires licences for equipment to one that requires licences for geographical service areas. The application that was lodged was for a licence for equipment. The Government said: `We are not issuing those any more. We shall give you a licence for a service-based geographical area'. Because Mount Martha forms part of Melbourne, that would mean a service area licence for the whole of Melbourne. The service area licence for the whole of Melbourne is subject to an application for conversion from one sort of licence to another which will not be completed by the end of the year. When the licence conversion is completed, the current necessity for a licence application for equipment will be obviated and such a licence will no longer be required. At the end of the year, when another permit is issued, we shall not need the permit that we now need to solve the problem at Mount Martha. On 5 June, I received a nice letter from the Acting Minister and the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) who said that the new system that the Government had introduced would expedite licence applications. He said:
Contrary to your Press Statement on the issue, recent amendments to Broadcasting Legislation will expedite the establishment of these translator stations.

The Minister had a shot, as did the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy), at the commercial television stations for not providing sufficient information. On 16 July, the Minister for Communications told me:
In spite of many promises the Melbourne commercial television stations have still not submitted planning proposals to my Department.

It is embarrassing for the Minister that the final information required had been lodged prior to his signing and forwarding the letter to me. The only information that was really required by the Department was submitted on 13 March. We are faced with the situation in which basically we are told: `Red tape has stopped us from issuing you this licence. We would like to help you, but we cannot'. Then there was an interesting letter from the Department of Communications to Channel 7. Because of all the red tape and mucking around that has been going on, I want to put that statement on the record. It states:
Should any difficulty be experienced in completing the necessary procedures in time to commence operation by mid December other interim licensing arrangements will be instigated.

The cat is out of the bag. They told us that they could not fix us up until the end of the year, but now we have received this letter from Mr Knowles in the Department of Communications saying: `If the problems get out of control there is a way round the problem in the first place'. The people of Mount Martha and Safety Beach have been without television for over 12 months. There is no reason for them to be without television and it is about time the Government started to do something about it.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that red tape has been mentioned tonight. I reflect on an incident which occurred during the recess. I need another flag outside my office in Burnie in Tasmania. When I rang up and asked for it, they said: `That will be all right. You can have a flag, but you must have a flag pole'. I said that there was no great need for us to have a flag pole; we had had one for 10 years and it was very good. I asked them to send me the flag. They said: `You had better ring Hobart and check out the details there'. They said: `No. You must have a flag pole with your flag'. We thought that this was a bit ridiculous. They told us to check it out with Canberra. So we telephoned people in the administrative section here, and they said: `There is no way round it. You have to have a flag pole if you want a flag'. After about two hours of telephone calls to the administrative people, we decided to take the flag pole and the flag. It cost us $97 in postage for the flag pole and the flag, when all I wanted was a flag sent through the post. That is what red tape is like these days in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Another piece of red tape which I am glad to see will never be implemented is the Bill of Rights. That piece of legislation was knocked out of this country by people power. The people around Australia-not just hundreds or thousands, but tens of thousands-rallied against this type of legislation which was proposed by the Government. It is a great tragedy that the Minister for Resources and Energy and a former Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) said that this was a victory for troglodites, neanderthals, drones and thugs. That simply is not the case. There are tens of thousands of genuine Australians around this country of ours who believe that if we ever gave any government-it does not matter what colour it is-the task of defining people's rights, one day there would be a government which would take away those rights. Such a government would use it as a precedent and would say: `Once upon a time you gave us that responsibility to determine your rights; surely it is a government's responsibility to be able to take them away'. On that basis, the Australian people rejected this type of legislation.

Another reason why they rejected it was that they could see that unelected bureaucrats in Australia-I do not say that in derogatory terms, but simply to define them-would be able to determine what people could do. The Australian people rejected that. They also rejected the idea of bureaucrats determining what should be taught in our government schools. There is a great tradition in Australia that our Government schools are free of indoctrination. The people could see that Government schools would introduce indoctrination of values and beliefs of which they did not want any part.

If the Government has genuinely withdrawn the Bill and will not resurrect it in some other form, it has been a great day for democracy because the people have been able to influence Government decisions. That is what it is all about. It is a tremendous credit to the people that the Government has taken the step of withdrawing this legislation. Credit is also due to the Senate, which spent a long time debating it-the longest debate ever-so that the Australian people had time to investigate the legislation.The Government tried to rush it through here. It was passed through the House of Representatives at ten to three in the morning. Many people just did not know anything about it. The Senate held it up so that rallies could be held right around Australia. It is a great thing for this nation that that occurred and it shows the importance of having a Senate which has the will to hold up that sort of legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to make a few observations this evening about that disgraceful letter sent by a Liberal member of the Western Australian Parliament, a Mr Lightfoot--
—Light-headed.

—That was a good interjection-sleight of foot, light-footed and very light-headed. That letter emulated with magnificent similarity the type of behaviour and attitude we have grown to expect from members of the Opposition generally here in the national Parliament just the same as within the State legislatures. It reflects very unfavourably on the national sentiment and the national concern of conservative parties in Australia when spokesmen for those parties stoop so low as to send a letter deliberately intended to sabotage the markets that Australia has so seriously developed over many years in order to provide the sort of economic security and welfare for our great farming communities in Australia, which are supposed to be supported by these people who sit up here in cockies' corner.
—Not too many of them are here tonight.

—Not one is here at the moment. We might come more easily to accept and to understand that as well. I am glad to see, however, that four members of the Liberal Party of Australia have come in here to hear my comments about one of their colleagues over in Western Australia. We have appealed to the honourable member for O'Connor, Mr Tuckey, to repudiate that approach to the American Administration by one of his geographically and philosophically close party colleagues. At this stage he has failed to do so.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I ask the honourable member to withdraw that remark. The honourable member for O'Connor made a personal explanation this afternoon in which he dissociated himself from that position.
—I should have informed the honourable member for O'Connor.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: I ask that you ask the honourable member to withdraw that remark.

-The Chair is not in a position to know whether the honourable member for O'Connor did or did not do that, so I do not think that I am in a position to direct the honourable member for Charlton to withdraw; but the honourable member for Charlton might take cognisance of what the honourable member for Deakin has said and withdraw in his own way.

—I accept the sentiments that have been expressed by the honourable member for Deakin and I withdraw. In fact, the normal courtesy is that when a reference of that kind during the adjournment debate is to be made about another honourable member, the honourable member is at least advised. I failed to do so, and I withdraw that. The reason that I was not able to advise the honourable member for O'Connor that I would be making reference to him was that I did not know that I would be doing so. The attitude that has been adopted by Mr Lightfoot is simply in accord with the traditions of the Liberal Party. I make very quick reference to a couple of examples. Before the 1983 elections we had the notorious comments by the then Prime Minister, the Rt. Hon. Malcolm Fraser, suggesting that people would be better off putting their savings under the bed. He obviously intended to force a run on the banks, with all of the disruption to the Australian financial system that that would have brought about. At the same time the then, I think, National President, or at least the New South Wales President of the Liberal Party, a financial consultant and adviser, Mr John Valder, advised his clients to send their money out of Australia-again designed almost certainly to create financial chaos in Australia.
-Order! The honourable member's time has expired. I have called two speakers from my left. I will now call two from my right. I call the honourable member for Lowe.
—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. With great respect, the reason that you called two members from this side was that there was no person seeking the call on the other side.

—I can call the way I wish to call. I have called two from my left. I will call two from my right and that will balance the proceedings for the evening. The honourable member for Denison will get the call after that, if he rises.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the electorate of Lowe, as I am sure is the case in the electorates of all of my colleagues, there is great activity for the bicentennial celebrations in 1988.
—They have just cut the funds back for it.

—They will take their share of the cuts with every other group in society. The Australian people are looking forward to the two-hundredth anniversary of settlement of Europeans on the eastern coast of Australia. The Australian people will mark the occasion. But, during the recess, I did some research on the early settlement of our nation and on the arrival of the First Fleet at Sydney. There are a number of diaries and very detailed records and accounts of this. In fact, there are about four that were written before the end of the eighteenth century by people who came out on the First Fleet-people who made records, kept diaries and journals, and went back to the United Kingdom, or Britain as it was then-and wrote their memoirs. From reading one of these accounts by a major with the First Fleet, it came home to me very clearly that we must have the co-operation of the French nation, the French people, when we launch our bicentennial celebrations.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no intention tonight to discuss the resumption of uranium sales to France. But I believe that we must appreciate that, when the First Fleet arrived at Botany Bay, within a short time La Perouse and his fleet from France sent out by the King of France arrived at Botany Bay. Before the British Fleet had left Botany Bay to sail to Port Jackson, La Perouse was also at Botany Bay. La Perouse and the French remained at Botany Bay for months. While they were there, the British were in Port Jackson. For a long time Australia, or the settlement at Sydney Cove as it then was, was touch and go. There was starvation and shortages and always the chance that everyone would perish. Yet the French were there and provided camaraderie and friendship for the officer class on the British boats and transports. I feel that there must be a rapprochement with and a greater involvement of the French nation in our bicentennial celebrations. It had never come home to me until I read these diaries that we have this debt to the French people and that we had an enormous contact with the French at the time of founding our colony.

The French did not come to Australia to found a colony. They came on an expedition, an exploration, a voyage of discovery. They were surprised to find a British transport at Botany Bay ready to make a settlement. They had no idea that there were any white settlers in this part of the world. I commend to honourable members some of these early diaries. The distressing details in them reveal how soon after the white settlers arrived smallpox spread throughout the whole of the Aboriginal community, killing half of the Aboriginal community. The point is made by some of the editors that there was a delay. It is perhaps possible that the smallpox did not come to Australia from the white settlement, from the First Fleet; it may have been introduced by Malay traders coming to the north of Australia. But half of the Aborigines were decimated in that epidemic which struck the whole of what is now the east coast of Australia.

I wanted to raise this matter because there have been difficulties with France in this part of the world with the catching and apprehension of spies in New Zealand. But New Zealand had sorted out the situation. It has released the spies into the custody of the French Government. I put it to the Minister responsible for the bicentenary that we must have not only the co-operation of the United Kingdom in the bicentennial celebrations but also French involvement, because they were here. They came to Botany Bay at the time Governor Phillip-a very humane man-was there with his fleet. Before he had left Botany Bay to settle in Sydney-which was a lucky decision-the French had arrived. The French are part of our bicentennial. In my electorate of Lowe we had a settlement for the French Canadians who were sent out to Australia as convicts when the Speaker of the Canadian House led a revolt in French Canada.
I put these matters before the House because I have never heard them mentioned before and I trust some action will be taken on them.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —If New South Wales and Victoria did as well as Tasmania in earning export income Australia would not be experiencing the worst balance of payments figures since Federation. In short, if New South Wales and Victoria pulled their weight, and even equalled Tasmania's excellent per capita performance, our nation would not be in the terrible mess it is in right now. The figures speak for themselves. For the nine months ended 9 March 1985 Tasmania's per capita export income was $1,315. For the same period the per capita export income figure for New South Wales was a paltry $915. For Victoria it was only $1,115. In the nine months ended March 1986 Tasmania maintained its impressive record in earning export income. Again, let the per capita figures speak for themselves: Tasmania, $1,535; Victoria, $1,355; and New South Wales, trailing, $1,070. If Tasmania were assessed today as a claimant State against the traditional standard States of New South Wales and Victoria we would financially be on clover. Sadly this is not the situation, as recent history conclusively proves. Right now our State is suffering and 6,000 Tasmanian jobs are on the line as a direct result of the deliberate actions of the Hawke socialist Government in Canberra.

SPEECH.PARA: The Premiers Conference of 13 June 1986 saw Tasmania's funding slashed by $91m in real terms. In percentage terms Tasmania was cut worst of all, by a massive 6.5 per cent in real terms. Queensland was the next State most harshly treated, with a cut in real terms of 5 per cent. The all-States average cut in real terms amounted to 4 per cent. Why was Tasmania singled out for such harsh and discriminatory treatment? One can readily contemplate political reasons for this treatment-such as Denison, Franklin, Lyons, Bass and Braddon.

The call by the Premier of Tasmania, the Honourable Robin Gray, for an independent review of Tasmania's financial maltreatment and mistreatment by the Hawke socialist Government is fully justified, and is in fact supported by all thinking Tasmanians right across the political spectrum. The savage cuts of 13 June 1986 follow three earlier substantial reductions in Commonwealth assistance and spending in Tasmania inflicted during calendar year 1985. In the May 1985 mini-Budget Tasmania sustained losses of Commonwealth assistance totalling $20m. The major items were a cut of $6m in the air fare subsidy, a cut of $5.3m in the freight equalisation scheme, a cut of $3m in funding for the community employment program and a cut of $2m in local government assistance.

At the May 1985 Premiers Conference and Loan Council meeting worse was still to come. Total cuts amounted to $28.7m, of which a reduction in general revenue assistance of $20m was the major item. Again in the August 1985 Commonwealth Budget Canberra struck and Tasmania fared badly at the hands of Mr Hawke and Mr Keating, suffering cuts of $13m.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member will refer to Ministers by their titles.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The grant total of cuts in Commonwealth funding to Tasmania in calendar year 1985 was therefore a massive $61.7m.

SPEECH.PARA: It can be seen from the foregoing that Commonwealth assistance and spending to Tasmania has been cut by a staggering $152.7m in just 13 months. That figure is minuscule in the Commonwealth's $80 billion-plus annual budget, but will have a savage impact upon our tiny Tasmanian economy.

I turn briefly, without debating the entire Budget, because that will come later, to what happened in the last 24 hours. A government which pledged to be led by a man who was going to be Prime Minister for all Australians and to bring all Australians together has been responsible for cutting Tasmania's freight equalisation scheme by 12 per cent in the past two years, a massive cut which will place up to 2,000 jobs in jeopardy. Last Saturday at the State Liberal Party conference I predicted cuts to Tasmania in Commonwealth spending in last night's Budget of $40m, and I was wrong. We have checked the figures now.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—A total of $61m was robbed from Tasmania on top of $152.7m. I thought the crime State of Australia was New South Wales with this extortion and robbery, ripping off people and forcing them into poverty, but what has been done to Tasmania is criminal and disgraceful. It is guaranteed that Tasmania will not have a Labor member of the House of Representatives for the next quarter of a century, and the Labor Party will never get a vote from anybody on this side of the House.
-Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Wednesday in Adelaide the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) presented the national awards for innovation in local government. It was the first time that this award system had been developed and it was with great pride that I was able to be there to witness the winner of the national award for economic development as the City of Moe, the city in which I have my electoral office, comprising some 16,000 people. An award was presented giving recognition to a housing finance scheme. I bring this to the attention of the House as I believe that that award is something that will be picked up by other local governments around Australia because of its benefit to those people in the cities seeking to buy their own homes. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: The City of Moe developed and promoted an innovative scheme aimed at addressing the housing needs of lower to middle income groups. The scheme involved Council undertaking a new role as a `facilitator' and `advocate' for its community in the private housing market. Council negotiated a $2 million loan from the National Australia Bank for administration through a Co-operative Housing Society. The Housing Society was then able to lend to the target group of low to middle income earners at standard bank rates. The $2 million loan from the bank to the Housing Society was insured through the Commonwealth Government's Housing Loans Insurance Corporation.
Council then embarked on an aggressive marketing campaign through the local media, solicitors and estate agents to promote the scheme.
In 1984-85 more than 180 families were assisted through the scheme to find private housing.

The scheme has subsequently expanded with additional establishment loans from other banks resulting in further Co-operative Housing Societies being formed with further loans being available. The Housing Finance Scheme has broad applicability for local councils seeking to take on a more pro-active role in their community. It has been adopted by many other local authorities in Vic. and the Australian Council of Co-operative Housing Societies has claimed that the adoption of the scheme by other local councils made a significant contribution towards lending by major financial institutions to Co-operative Housing Societies in 1984/85.
The remarkable part about this is how it has developed. The article continues:

This lending increased by 540 per cent in 1984/85 to a record $120 million which financed 2,400 homes in Vic. While a number of other local authorities in other States have become involved in the housing finance area, this seems to be the most comprehensive and broadly applicable approach developed.

I have great pride in presenting this information to the House. Several councillors in my area have worked particularly hard on this scheme. No one has worked harder than Shire Clerk Peter Lerstang and the President of the Housing Co-operative, Councillor Peter Wells, who has worked particularly hard to make this a very important project. The city of Moe has initiated an award which has won the national award prize. I believe that this practice will eventually extend throughout Australia. At the national awards it was quite obvious that all the councils that were present and witnessed this event were very keen to see what this council had done in relation to local housing. I am sure that the award will initiate the spreading of this co- operative venture across Australia. I have great pleasure in bringing to the House the initiative of my local area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few remarks about the role of small business in the Australian economy. Last night we heard the Budget Speech. Business of any sort was not mentioned, especially small business. Ninety per cent of business activity is conducted by small business, which is by far the greatest employer in Australia. Australians tend to concentrate their interests on large organisations such as the BHPs and CSRs of this world, but the courageous and hard-working individuals of the nation, particularly those from a migrant background, tend to be in small business. They dedicate their lives to improving their lot, to making a success of an investment, to backing their judgment and skills against others and competing against them to build something for their future and for the future of their children. This process not only has contributed greatly to the enriching of Australia in practical terms but also has added a diversity and strength to technology, to our general pool of knowledge and to managerial expertise.

SPEECH.PARA: Small business around Australia has been particularly concerned about some of the measures the Government has taken over the last few months. In the first few days of this session I know that members of the Australian Labor Party would be very aware of the feelings of small business in the electorate. I suspect that even you, Mr Deputy Speaker, when you descend from that high place and resume your functions as an elected member for an electorate in Sydney, are made aware by those people you represent of the significance of small business. I suspect that you would even be aware of the recent by-elections held in New South Wales and of the results of those elections and that the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Barrie Unsworth, said that one of the main features that concerned the Australian Labor Party in the results of those elections was the problem of small business and particularly some of the taxes and charges placed on small business by this Government.

This is a matter of great concern. I have viewed the matter objectively and looked at the results of huge meetings held around the nation, with massive attendances. Since I have been a member of this place I cannot remember an issue which has aroused so much concern and strong feeling. To my knowledge such people have never risen up and taken such strong action against government. I cannot remember such firm action from the types of people now demonstrating against this Government at public meetings and national gatherings. The extent of the feeling is epitomised by the proprietor of a newspaper shop whom I met in the town of Pimpama in Queensland. It is not a large place; I suspect that there would be three or four shops. The area serviced by this newsagency proprietor was small. He said that he employed a teenage girl to assist him in the shop on Saturday mornings because business was really brisk at that time. This teenage girl, naturally, wished to receive some sort of recognition for the work she did, apart from her salary. She said to her boss on a couple of occasions: `I wonder whether I could have a paddle-pop?' Normally on a Saturday morning she would eat three paddle-pops.

The proprietor is liable for fringe benefits tax for the paddle-pops he gives his employee at cost. He has begun the practice of asking her to sign and initial the sticks of the paddle-pops and to date them. It is his intention at the end of seven years of saving paddle-pop sticks to send them to the Australian Taxation Office to find out how much fringe benefits tax he owes. That demonstrates the seriousness of the situation because the Tax Office can go back that length of time and force the payment of fringe benefits tax. It is a terrible tax. The Government fails to understand the important role of small business in Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 18 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) prepare a valuation of the plant and equipment at the Belconnen Mall, A.C.T.; if so, will he table the valuation in the House.
(2) Did the ATO valuation of the Belconnen Mall contain any component for redevelopment of the site.
(3) Is the apportionment, in the agreement for sale, of $8 921 710, which is listed as goods, for plant and equipment.
(4) If the ATO did not prepare a valuation of plant and equipment what steps did he take to verify the figure of $8 921 710.

(5) Is the Commonwealth now prevented from disputing the correctness of the figure of $8 921 710; if so, how does he reconcile this with his answer to my question without notice (Hansard, 14 February 1986, pages 585-6) concerning the sale of the Belconnen Mall.
(6) Did he read in full the agreement for sale prior to its execution.

(7) Is it a fact that if the figure of $8 921 710 for plant and equipment is maintained and upheld (a) there will be a tax windfall to the purchasers in excess of $2.4 million, (b) the purchasers will be entitled to claim nearly $5 million for further depreciation of plant and equipment which has already been depreciated by the Canberra Commercial Development Authority and (c) there will be an additional tax burden of $2.4 million imposed upon the Canberra Commercial Development Authority.
(8) Is he able to say whether the Canberra Commercial Development Authority is satisfied with the situation.

(9) Did he discuss the proposed sale with the Minister for Territories prior to the close of tenders; if so, (a) on what dates, (b) at what places, and (c) what were the material particulars of the discussions.
(10) Did he consider the arrangement of Commonwealth-funded bridging finance to facilitate the sale of the Belconnen Mall.
(11) Was the option of writing-up plant and equipment offered to any of the other tenderers prior to the close of tenders.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised by the Commissioner of Taxation that a specific valuation of plant and equipment at Belconnen Mall was not carried out by the Australian Taxation Office. A valuation of chattels was prepared for Stamp Duty purposes. Chattels for Stamp Duty purposes are substantially different from plant and equipment for income tax purposes.

(2) I am advised by the Commissioner of Taxation that a valuation of the Belconnen Mall by the Australian Taxation Office, prepared to assist in consideration of the tenders, did contain a component covering the present valuation of approved additional development rights.
(3) Yes: The extent to which the items qualify as plant for income tax purposes is, however, a matter for the Australian Taxation Office to decide.
(4) See answer to (1) above. I was not aware of the figure included in the Contract for Sale for the value of goods until 12 February, nor was there any reason why I should have been.

(5) Under the relevant taxation laws the taxation affairs of the purchasers of the Belconnen Mall are, of course, confidential. However, I am advised by the Commissioner of Taxation that in accordance with normal procedures the Australian Taxation Office scrutinises all contracts for the sale of real property to assess if the amount specified in the contract for goods and chattels which are claimed to be exempt from stamp duty are reasonable. If such an assessment took place in the case of the sale of the Belconnen Mall then the Australian Taxation Office has the power to adjust the amount on which stamp duty is paid.
In regard to the implications of the figure specified in the contract for the sale of the Belconnen Mall on future depreciation claims by the purchasers, see my answer to (7) below.

I should also point out at this stage that the difference between the figure specified for plant and equipment in the Contract of Sale, which was the value ascribed by a valuer appointed by the purchasers, and the value recorded on the Canberra Commercial Development Authority's last tax return for 1984-85, is the result of depreciation for taxation purposes, which is calculated on the original purchase price with no allowance made for subsequent inflation and other factors which might affect the actual market value of the items. Consequently, the depreciated value of plant and equipment for taxation purposes will, in many cases, be less than its market value.

As I have said in my answer to a question without notice by the honourable member for Fraser on 14 February 1986 (Hansard pages 582-583): `If, as a result of (enquiries by the Australian Taxation Office) it was the view of the Australian Taxation Office that the amount supplied by the purchaser for both stamp duty and income tax purposes was incorrect, appropriate assessments would be issued by the Australian Taxation Office in accordance with the usual procedures of the Australian Taxation Office.'
(6) No, nor was there any reason why I should have done so.

(7) If the figure of $8,921,710 specified in the contract for plant and equipment is, after scrutiny by the Australian Taxation Office, considered to be appropriate (i.e. it represents the consideration payable solely for assets upon which depreciation deductions are properly allowable for income tax purposes) then the purchaser will, of course, be entitled to obtain the taxation consequences flowing from the income tax law. The purchaser in this regard would be in no different position to any other purchaser. If the figure is considered to be excessive (i.e. some items did not qualify for depreciation deductions), the normal provisions of taxation law will apply and the benefit to be obtained by the purchasers would be reduced. It will be clear from the above that the purchasers of the Belconnen Mall were not placed in any more favourable position for taxation purposes than would apply in any similar commercial transaction.

In addition I am advised by the Commissioner for Taxation that the taxation law provides in such cases that the profit enjoyed by the vendor on the sale of the plant and equipment at a price which is greater than its previously written down value for taxation purposes is liable to income tax up to the amount of the original cost to the vendor. In the case of the sale of the Belconnen Mall, because the Canberra Commercial Development Authority was a public authority which paid tax, it received tax benefits through the depreciation provisions of the income tax laws to the extent to which plant and equipment was written down. These benefits were reflected in a greater amount being available to the Government from the resources of the Authority on its winding up. If increased taxation is assessed as payable by the Authority there will of course be no real loss to the Commonwealth. As I pointed out in my answer to the Member for Fraser's question without notice on this subject on 14 February 1986, it does not matter whether the funds in question come to the Commonwealth via increased income tax or direct from the reserves of the Authority (see Hansard, page 583).

In conclusion, it is worth noting that the so-called ``windfall'' going to the purchasers is no more, and no less, than could have been enjoyed by any other purchaser of the Mall or of any other commercial property. I would expect the purchase price offered would have been assessed by the purchasers on the basis of that commercial reality.

(8) The Minister for Territories has advised me that he did not receive any formal advice from the Canberra Commercial Development Authority about this matter other than the resolution of the Canberra Commercial Development Authority passed at its meeting of 17 December 1985 and referred to in my answer to part (6) of question number 3142. The Canberra Commercial Development Authority was a Statutory Authority of the Commonwealth and as such was expected to abide by Commonwealth Government policy.

(9) I had no discussion with the Minister for Territories concerning the proposed sale of the Belconnen Mall between the time the Government agreed to place the Belconnen Mall on the market and the close of tenders.

(10) It was part of the Government's budget strategy for the 1985-86 financial year that the sale of the Belconnen Mall would be completed in that financial year. Consistent with that, the tender documents made clear that settlement was required at about the end of March 1986. Any proposal to sell the Belconnen Mall on the basis of `Commonwealth-funded bridging finance', which presumably would have involved deferment of payment beyond the end of the 1985-86 financial year would have been inconsistent with the Government's budget strategy and the tender conditions.
(11) I am advised by the Minister for Territories that the answer is yes.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: General Computing System for Aviation Industry

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: My Department is installing a General Computing Network (GCN) to improve its management information systems, thus providing a basis for further improvement in staff productivity, service to the industry and in economy in the use of resources. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 29 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the extent of overservicing uncovered by the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) each month since it has had responsibility for this function.
(2) What additional overservicing has been deterred by the HIC each month since it has had responsibility for this function and how is this calculated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Health Insurance Commission has had responsibility for the administration of this function since May 1985. However, it is difficult to measure the extent of excessive servicing which has occurred since that time on a monthly basis.

The Commission is not empowered to determine that excessive servicing has occurred. Rather, it is the responsibility of the Commission to provide initial identification of practitioners who appear to be providing excessive services. This initial identification relies partly on retrospective study of statistical parameters and partly on observation at the point of claiming benefit. If following further examination it still appears that excessive servicing may have occurred, the matter is referred to a Medical Services Committee of Inquiry which may make recommendations to the Minister for Health. It is the Committees which have access, in medical confidence, to clinical aspects of the services and this represents the only point at which excessive services may be positively identified. Thorough examination of the servicing of a limited number of a practitioner's patients by a Committee may take several months, and a Ministerial determination and an appeal period will then follow where excessive services have been identified.

It will be appreciated that the time span involved in this process does not enable the uncovering of execessive servicing to be quantified on a monthly basis. In addition, requirements for medical care are not constant from month to month or even quarter to quarter. There are seasonal variations and there may be an unusual epidemic or other unusual circumstance, such as the NSW doctors dispute which makes statistical comparisons difficult.

Insofar as quantification is possible, the figures provided in response to Question No. 4162, asked by Mr Porter on 29 May 1986 and subject to the above qualification, are considered to provide an indication of the extent of excessive servicing dealt with by the Commission since it has had responsibility in this area.
(2) Much of the deterrent effect arises from practitioner's knowledge that invigilation occurs and from the publication of Determinations in respect of excessive servicing by particular providers.

In addition, the Commission's medical advisers counsel practitioners who are generating unusually high costs, or who appear to be providing excessive services. These visits provide an opportunity for features of the particular practice to be discussed, and can have a significant deterrent effect.
However, for the reasons already specified, the extent of deterrent effects on excessive servicing cannot be expressed on a monthly basis.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 4 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Will his Department initiate any prosecutions of persons who came to its attention during the course of the amnesty but who were not covered by its provisions; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: It is the longstanding policy of my department not to prosecute a person who has breached the Social Security Act if that person voluntarily brings the matter to attention. Such overpayments are, however, raised for recovery purposes. Cases involving overpayments revealed as a result of Amnesty claims but not covered by the Amnesty provisions are being dealt with according to this policy.

Other cases that came to attention during the Amnesty by means other than voluntary disclosure are being dealt with under the Department's normal prosecution guidelines. Briefly, these guidelines involve consideration of whether, prima facie, an offence has been committed, intent has been demonstrated and socio-economic or other factors relevant to a decision to proceed to prosecution are present.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 4 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What consideration has been given to the recommendations of the report `Supporting Service Families' released by him on 30 April 1986.
(2) What action has been taken to implement the recommendations of this report, other than the action announced in his statement of 30 April 1986.
(3) When will the recommendations of this report be implemented.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) During my press conference on 30 April 1986 I indicated my intention to implement all the recommendations contained in Mrs Hamilton's excellent report `Supporting Service Families' with the timing depending upon resources available. I have also accorded high priority to raising the self esteem of the families of Australian Defence Force Members.

The Defence Chiefs of Staff Committee at its meeting of 21 May 1986 considered Mrs Hamilton's report, together with a brief from the Department's Services Personnel Policy Committee on the report. The Chiefs of Staff Committee welcomed the report as a helpful and useful document and supported both the implementation of its recommendations and the provision of personnel for the implementation team.

(2) Defence Deputy Secretary A and the Assistant Chief of the Defence Force (Policy) have accepted joint responsibility for co-ordinating the implementation of the report's recommendations and financial cover has been programmed for the next five years to cover the estimates which relate to the proposed Australia-wide Defence Families Information and Liaison Service.
The Hamilton Report Implementation Team, headed by Brigadier Phil Davies, has commenced the task of examining ways to address the issues raised in `Supporting Service Families'.

The Team has no authority to implement those recommendations relating to conditions of service. This is the responsibility of the Department's Director General of Service Conditions. However, the team will monitor progress in this area and provide advice as to the impact that perceived conditions of service shortfalls have on families of defence force members.

The team's task is to co-ordinate within six months the implementation of those recommendations that can be given immediate effect, and to prepare within the same period a detailed strategy for implementation for those with longer term implications.
(a) To determine and implement those recommedations of the report which can be given immediate effect.
(b) To prepare a detailed strategy of implementation for those recommendations of the report with longer term implications.
(c) To establish the Australian Defence Families Information and Liaison Service.
(d) To prepare for the Minister for Defence, by 5 December 1986, a progress report on the strategy for implementation of the report's recommendations.
(e) To establish a National Consultative Group of Service Spouse to advise on the implementation of the report's recommendations.

(3) Mrs Hamilton's recommendation that `there should be a firm entitlement to at least two nights motel accommodation for a family leaving an area, rather than the variable local arrangements that currently exist', has already been approved. With effect from 17 June 1986 the first night's accommodation is granted automatically on the night of removal uplift, with a second night provided at the member's request-with no justification required.

The establishment of a small full-time secretariat to assist the relevant senior officers in pursuing the recommendations contained in `Supporting Services Families' was endorsed by the Defence Chiefs of Staff Committee on 21 May 1986. The Hamilton Report Implementation Team has been formed and is operating at Monaro House, Braddon. Details of the Team's objectives appear above at (2).

In conclusion, the team has been able to comence operations on a positive note because of the general acceptance of Mrs Hamilton's report. Their efforts will, however, be directed primarily at establishing the Defence Family Information and Liaison Service organisation as it offers practical support in the field, Australia-wide, to families of Defence Force members. Conditions of service matters on the other hand must be referred and processed through departmental and Government machinery, and this involves delay.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: International Year of Shelter for the Homeless

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 5 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: What was the
(a) Distribution, and
(b) The use of the funds allocated to the International Year of Shelter for the homeless in (i) 1984/85; (ii) 1985/86.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) (i) The approach to International Year of Shelter for the Homeless (IYSH), recommended by the United Nations Centre for Human Settlements and being followed by the Australian Government, includes an assessment of needs, the documentation of some good demonstration projects and the evaluation of existing housing policies and programs.

In 1984/85 $100,000 was appropriated to the Department of Housing and Construction for the development of the Australian strategy for the IYSH including a strategy to inform the community about the International Year and how they could participate. Actual expenditure in 1984/85 was $98,601. (ii) In 1985/86 $650,000 was appropriated for IYSH, actual expenditure was $458,554.

$69,887 to develop an IYSH information program including the planning, development and pre-production costs for a film to inform the community about the International Year and the Australian IYSH program
contribution of $19,620 to two national conferences on the housing problems experienced by women and youth.
$8,742 to develop a proposal for the development of housing education materials for inclusion in the curricula of secondary schools
(b) (ii) During 1985/86 $458,554 was spent in the following areas:

$187,907 to prepare IYSH project reports on 13 projects being funded under existing housing programs which demonstrate innovative ways of alleviating the problems of homelessness and inadequate housing; to conduct 10 research projects into areas of specific housing need, low-cost methods of building construction and current public housing arrangements, and to undertake 10 State Government and community projects to increase public awareness of IYSH and housing issues.

These projects were selected following advice from the IYSH Non-Government Committee and State Governments. Information generated by the demonstration and research projects will be widely disseminated to community groups and all levels of Government to assist in the on-going development and review of existing housing policies and programs.

$155,462 for the preparation of brochures and posters; advertising; the compilation of IYSH address list of community organisations; the development of a handbook for the documentation of IYSH projects; and the further development and production of the IYSH film
$36,000 for the initial drafting of housing education materials for consideration by the Curriculum Development Centre prior to their introduction into secondary schools
$3,372 for costs, including travel, associated with the conduct of four (4) meetings of the IYSH National Committee of Non-Government Organisations
$50,000 contribution to the United Nations Centre for Human Settlements (HABITAT) for U.N. IYSH projects in developing countries in the Pacific Region
$35,839 towards the cost of running conferences on the housing problems faced by women and foster children; and the World Planning Congress.
